uku_sym_cat: Other Side Effect That Does Not Fit Any Above
ae_narrative: Participant CU10006 is in the Step 2 acute phase portion of the study protocol, receiving 50mg of Nortriptyline daily. On a phone call with a study RA on Friday, December 8th at 3:50pm ET the participant reported that from Saturday December 2nd to Sunday December 3rd she was hospitalized at the Montefiore Medical Center located in Bronx, NY due to nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea that had been going on for about 3 days. According to the inpatient discharge summary, the patient also reported increased urinary frequency with burning at urination, lower abdominal pain, and feeling of incomplete voiding. The report indicates that the patient's nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea (likely gastroenteritis) improved with bowel rest, Zofran, IVF, and diet as tolerated. Workup of urinary symptoms revealed no UTI and retention (all PVRs <200cc). The participant was discharged on December 3rd, 2017 and instructed to follow up with her primary care provider regarding urinary symptoms.     The patient returned to the clinic on December 11, 2017 for follow up and to determine whether medication adjustment was required. The patient reported to have continued taking the study medication, 50mg Nortriptyline during her inpatient stay and after discharge. During the visit, the patient reported that her GI symptoms were much improved. Her mood was low (PHQ-9 of 14) which she attributed to flulike symptoms and the holiday season approaching as this is her first holiday since her mother's passing.     It is our impression that the hospitalization was not related to the study medication. The patient was sent home with instructions to continue taking the study medication and to contact us if any new symptoms appeared.     This SAE was reported to the NYSPI IRB on 12/12/17
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE
ae_action_other: Follow up with primary care provider. Continue study medication.

ae_narrative: Reported noticeable mouth tremor on 7/16/18. States that tremor has worsened over the past four months to the point that family members are pointing it out.
ae_relevant_info: Ambulatory Involuntary Movement Scale administered by Dr. Steven Roose on 7/25/18. Score of 2. Weekly monitoring will continue and patient case will be discussed on PI call.

ae_narrative: This patient is an 89-year-old female currently in the Step 1 Continuation phase of the protocol taking Bupropion 150mg and Risperidone 1.5mg. The patient has a pacemaker and is currently treated for atrial fibrillation by her primary care doctor. The patient's sister reported to the study team via phone call on 5/11/18 that her sister was hospitalized at New York Presbyterian on 5/8/18 for heart palpitations. She was unaware of when the patient would be discharged. The NYP EMR system notes report that the patient was admitted on 5/8/18 and discharged on 5/11/18. Per the EMR notes, the patient's heart rate was monitored during her time in the hospital. Her pacemaker was determined to be operating normally. She was instructed to increase her Diltiazem from 120mg to 240mg and was observed for two nights. On the morning of 5/10/18, the patient reported that her heart palpitations had decreased. She was discharged on 5/11/18 with instructions to increase her Diltiazem dose to 240mg daily, and decrease her Rivaroxaban dose from 20mg to 15mg daily. She was also given the following diet restrictions: 'Avoid added salt, canned vegetables, pre-made soups/entrees and salted snacks.' The patient has a follow-up appointment with her primary care doctor on 5/24/18.     On 5/14/18, the patient returned to the ER reporting that her heart palpitations had returned. Her EKG and laboratory results were within normal limits. The doctor encouraged the patient and her family to follow-up with a cardiologist. The patient was then discharged from the ER later that day. It is the impression of the study team that the hospitalization was not related to the study medication.
ae_relevant_info: Atrial fibrillation  Pacemaker
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: This patient is an 86-year-old female currently in Step 1 Week 4 of the protocol taking Escitalopram 10mg and Bupropion 100mg. Her PHQ-9 score on 7/25/18 was 7, and she reports no side effects from the study medication.     On 7/20/18, the patient tripped while stepping off a bus and fell onto the sidewalk.  The patient was taken to Long Island Jewish Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens, where she was casted for a broken arm. She reported to our study staff that she did not see the large gap between the bus and the sidewalk, and that is why she fell. She was not feeling dizzy or light-headed at the time of the fall. The patient has a follow-up appointment scheduled with her orthopedist in two weeks.     It is the impression of the study team that the patient's fall was not related to the study medication. She is scheduled for follow-up in the study on 8/7/18.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: The patient is a Spanish-speaking 70 year-old female with a history of recurrent major depression who previously failed anti-depressant trials of Fluoxetine 40mg and Paroxetine 40mg. This patient was evaluated on 02/06/2019. At evaluation, the patient reported a PHQ-9 of 12. She listed the following medical conditions: sarcoidosis, rheumatoid arthritis, occasional headaches, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, joint pain, urinary incontinence and her current medications were: Rivaroxaban 20mg, Ranitidine 150mg, Prednisone 5mg, Metoprolol 50mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Pregabalin 75mg, and Melatonin 10mg, and Paxil 30 mg. Her blood pressure was 149/67, pulse 58, with no abnormalities found on her bloodwork or EKG that were collected at this time (see recent blood work and EKG attached below). This patient enrolled into the OPTIMUM study on 02/06/2019 and was randomized to Aripiprazole augmentation to Paroxetine 30mg.  For the first 6 weeks of the protocol, the patient scored PHQ-9's of 3 (a value indicative of remission of depressive symptoms), stating that she was adhering to the medication regimen of Paroxetine 30mg and Aripiprazole 2mg and she reported no side effects or medical issues. At Week 8 (05/07/2019), the patient self-discontinued Aripiprazole due to worsening anxiety, agitation and weight gain. She reported cutting pills of Paroxetine to increase her dose of 30 mg, and it was assumed she was now taking roughly 40 mg daily. The patient was due to return to clinic in May for her Week 10 visit, but was unable to be reached to schedule an appointment. On 6/12/2019, the patient came to clinic with complaints of worsening depression, PHQ-9 = 19 on Paroxetine appx 40mg (taking a 30mg tab plus a partial tablet). She stated that she was also cutting Alprazolam pills that were prescribed by her psychiatrist, Dr. Balta, in 2019 and taking partial doses of these cut pills. Dr. Bret Rutherford spoke to this patient on 6/17/2019 due to reports of suicidality, but patient was deemed safe and was scheduled to return the next day for randomization to Step 2. On 6/18/2019, the patient was randomized to switch to Nortriptyline. She was instructed to taper off Paroxetine over 4 days and begin Nortriptyline 25mg after Paroxetine taper. The patient was also told to discontinue the short-acting Alprazolam and substitute it with long-acting Ativan 0.5mg twice a day as needed for severe anxiety. On 6/26/2019, the Nortriptyline dose increased to 50mg. At Step 2 Week 2 (7/10/2019), the patient reported adherence to Nortriptyline 50mg and scored a PHQ-9 of 9, and reported feeling much better. Her Nortriptyline blood level was drawn. One week after, on 7/11/2019, the patient came in for a follow-up visit and scored a PHQ-9 of 11. On 7/15/2019 the patient's Nortriptyline blood level was reported to be 100 ng/mL (therapeutic level is 80-120 ng/mL). At Step 2 Week 4 (7/18/2019), the patient scored a PHQ-9 of 11. She was seen with their husband and a Spanish-speaking interpreter. Patient reported seeing their cardiologist Dr. Stefano Ravalli on Monday 7/15/2019 for a regular follow-up appointment and stated that he told them to stop taking Nortriptyline. On Tuesday 7/16/2019 the patient took Nortriptyline 25mg and on Wednesday 7/17/2019 she took no antidepressant medication. Dr. Ravalli also directed patient to increase the Metoprolol from 50mg to 75mg. On Wednesday afternoon (7/17/2019), the patient went to the Emergency Department (unclear which one) because she did not feel well; She had an EKG, was not provided any new medications, and she was sent home with instructions to come to her next appointment at our clinic on 7/18/2019.  On July 18th, 2019 during the clinic visit, the patient endorsed sadness, anxiety, and some dizziness. At her appointment, there was a Spanish-speaking interpreter and her husband present. The patient's blood pressure was taken using the automated machine and was 179/86, Heart Rate: 94 bpm, at which point she reported chest pressure, headache, and dizziness. A repeated manual blood pressure reading was done by Galit Marcus, NP and was 183/103, Heart Rate: 106 bpm. At this point the patient lost consciousness for about 5-6 seconds while seated, with steady and strong breathing and pulse. After about 5-6 seconds, she regained consciousness. There was no evidence of any seizure activity. The patient was oriented to person and place, and answered questions appropriately with single word answers (per Spanish-speaker interpreter). Additionally, no asymmetry, CN II-XII grossly intact. After initiating the emergency protocol, which included calling security and eliciting help from the attending medical staff, the clinical team stayed by the patient's side until EMS picked her up within approximately 15 minutes. The patient was accompanied to Emergency Department by her husband. We spoke with New York Presbyterian Emergency Department and were informed the patient was being medically admitted.  Galit Marcus NP spoke with Dr. Ina Becker, a psychiatry attending doctor at New York Presbyterian who gave the patient's medical and psychiatric history, requested CL consult and possible psychiatric hospitalization for medication stabilization once she is medically stable. Dr. Becker agreed to CL consult and to evaluate whether the patient meets criteria for psychiatric admission. In addition to speaking with Dr, Becker, Galit Marcus NP also spoke to Dr. Stefano Ravalli, the patient's cardiologist. According to her cardiologist, the patient was first referred to him in May of 2018 for shortness of breath. At that time, he started her on Metoprolol for tachycardia and referred them to pulmonology for borderline pulmonary HTN. He did not start the patient on Rivaroxaban, and does not know who wrote the first prescription. The patient had a CT-angiogram in November 2017 that was normal and an echocardiogram in December 2018 that was normal. Patient was seen again in March 2019, and he reported no change in her status. On the cardiologist appointment on July 15, 2019, the patient was tachycardic with a blood pressure of 140/90, Heart Rate: 102. According to the patient, this was a scheduled follow-up appointment with her cardiologist. Dr. Ravalli stated that he thought this might be secondary to the Nortriptyline. He said he did not tell the patient to stop Nortriptyline, but suggested that she consider a second opinion for psychiatric medication management, and possibly re-start Paroxetine. Dr. Ravalli did not feel there were any acute cardiac issues.  We will follow-up with the patient's medical and psychiatric team at CUMC and remain in contact with the patient and her family.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: On 4/10/2020, the study RA called the patient to schedule an upcoming phone call and reached the patient's husband. Her husband explained that after 2 weeks of worsening depressive and physiological symptoms, she was taken to New York-Presbyterian/The Allen Hospital in an ambulance around 12:00PM on 4/10/2020. He explained that in the past two weeks the patient's appetite was severely low (eating less than half of a sandwich and drinking a cup of milk a day) and that she has not gotten out of the bed for any reason or speak to him or her children. The patient also developed mild breathing difficulties and mild fevers ranging between 99.8°Fon 3/29/2020 to 101.17°F on 4/10/2020. After speaking with the patient's primary care provider on the morning of 4/10/2020, the husband was instructed to call 911. According to the husband, the patient's primary care provider suggested calling 911 because they were 'worried about the depressive symptoms and newfound physiological symptoms'. The patient's husband was not allowed to go to the hospital with the patient given the restrictive COIVD-19 regulations and has not been provided any updates from the hospital. We will be in continuous contact with the patient's husband regarding any new details about the patient. We do not have enough information at this moment to deem if this adverse event was related to study medications. It is the teams impression that this patient may have contracted COVID-19.
ae_relevant_info: The patient is a Spanish-speaking 71 year-old female with a history of recurrent major depression who previously failed anti-depressant trials of Fluoxetine 40mg and Paroxetine 40mg. This patient was evaluated on 02/06/2019. At evaluation, the patient reported a PHQ-9 of 12. She listed the following medical conditions: sarcoidosis, rheumatoid arthritis, occasional headaches, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, joint pain, urinary incontinence and her current medications were: Rivaroxaban 20mg, Ranitidine 150mg, Prednisone 5mg, Metoprolol 50mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Pregabalin 75mg, and Melatonin 10mg, and Paxil 30 mg. This patient enrolled into the OPTIMUM study on 02/06/2019 and was randomized to aripiprazole augmentation to paroxetine 30mg.    The patient was in remission during the first 6 weeks of the Step 1 acute phase, evidenced by PHQ-9's of 3. She was adherent to Paroxetine 30mg and aripiprazole 2mg and she reported no side effects or medical issues. At Week 8, the patient self-discontinued aripiprazole 2mg due to worsening anxiety, agitation and weight gain. Since her depression returned, she then entered Step 2 on 6/18/19 and was randomized to switch to nortriptyline. She was adherent to nortriptyline 25mg until 7/17/2019, when her cardiologist told her to discontinue nortriptyline 25mg. At that point, the patient restarted paroxetine 40mg and aripiprazole 2mg. Any changes to her anti-depressant regimen were put on hold due to a left hand tremor that began on 9/4/2019. While it was possible that the aripiprazole 2mg was the cause of the tremor, when the aripiprazole 2mg was discontinued on 10/3/2019, the tremor persisted. Thus, until her tremor is examined by a neurologist, we made the decision to keep her on paroxetine 40mg QD, bupropion 150mg QD, and lorazepam 1mg PRN. She continues expressing depressive symptoms and scored a PHQ-9 of 18 on 3/25/2020. We have heavily emphasized the importance of the neurologist follow-up but her appointment has now been postponed twice due to the COVID-19 outbreak. It is the teams impression that the tremor is not related to study medications.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: This patient is a 77-year old female in the continuation phase following completion of step 1 in the protocol. She is currently on duloxetine 60mg and aripiprazole 5mg. This patient completed the acute phase of the study on 6/6/2019 as a remitter with a PHQ-9 of 4 on duloxetine 60mg and aripiprazole 2mg. During a follow-up phone call on 7/23/2019 the patient reported a PHQ-9 of 10, so her aripiprazole dosage was increased to 5mg. Her last PHQ-9 score was an 11, which was collected via phone call on 8/6/2019. No additional increase in medication dose was given at that time to allow the initial increase of aripiprazole 5mg to take effect.   On 9/20/2019, the patient went to the Beth Israel Medical Center ED with complaints of shortness of breath, fatigue, and difficulty walking. She was admitted the same day. During hospitalization, she was offered a colonoscopy but refused. No upper GI series was performed, according to her. She could not answer whether she was guaiac positive and stated that her stool 'looked fine' to her. She denied falling in the last few months. She states she was diagnosed with anemia, given two blood transfusions, and iron tablets. The patient states no other medication changes were made. She was discharged from the hospital on 9/23/2019 and has a follow-up appointment with an internist at Bellevue Hospital Center on 9/27/2019. During a scheduled study follow-up call on 9/24/2019, the patient was encouraged to keep her appointment with the internist and fax her discharge summary form to us.  It is the impression of the study team that the patient's hospitalization could possibly be related to the antidepressant medication, as medications which block the reuptake of serotonin are associated with increased risk of upper GI bleeds. Since the patient refused a GI work-up we cannot know if this was a source of bleeding. She is scheduled for follow-up study visit in October 2019.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: This patient is a 77-year old female in the Month 4 continuation phase following completion of Step 1 in the protocol. She is currently on duloxetine 60mg and aripiprazole 5mg. This patient signed study consent on 3/21/2019 and began study medications on 3/28/2019. This patient completed the acute phase of the study on 6/6/2019 as a remitter with a PHQ-9 of 4 on duloxetine 60mg and aripiprazole 2mg. During a follow-up call on 7/23/2019 the patient reported a PHQ-9 of 10, so her aripiprazole dosage was increased to 5mg. During a follow-up phone call on 8/6/2019 the patient reported a PHQ-9 of 11. No additional increase in medication dose was given at that time to allow the initial increase of aripiprazole 5mg to take effect.     On 9/20/2019, the patient was admitted to Beth Israel Medical Center ED with complaints of shortness of breath, fatigue, and difficulty walking. During her hospitalization, the patient was offered a colonoscopy but refused. No upper GI series was performed, according to her. The patient stated she was diagnosed with anemia, given two blood transfusions, and iron tablets. She stated no other medication changes were made. The patient was discharged from the hospital on 9/23/2019 and had a follow-up appointment with an internist at Bellevue Hospital Center on 9/27/2019. During a scheduled follow-up call on 9/24/2019, the patient was encouraged to keep her appointment with the internist and fax her discharge summary form to us. A copy of the discharge summary was submitted to the IRB on 10/1/2019.    During a follow-up call on 10/22/2019, the patient reported that she was hospitalized at Bellevue Hospital Center the past week for anemia-related problems. During her hospitalization, the patient stated that she was given a blood transfusion, an iron infusion, an endoscopy, and a colonoscopy. The patient stated that she was diagnosed with microcytic anemia, was given steroid creams for a rash by a dermatologist, and was also seen by a psychiatrist. The patient stated that she was discharged from the hospital on 10/21/2019. The patient is unable to provide more information and states that her discharge paperwork only contains follow-up appointments with no hospital summary attached. Follow-up appointments include hematology, dermatology, and GP, all at Bellevue on 11/14/2019. During this follow up call the patient's mood was also assessed. She reported a PHQ-9 of 5 on duloxetine 60mg and aripiprazole 5mg.     It is the impression of the study team that the patient's hospitalization could possibly be related to the antidepressant medication, as medications which block the reuptake of serotonin are associated with increased risk of upper GI bleeds. During her first hospitalization, the patient refused a GI work-up. The study team is uncertain whether a GI work-up was conducted during her most recent hospitalization. We placed a call to the psychiatrist on 10/22/2019 in order to learn about the patient's hospital course and are awaiting their call back.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Participant was a 77-year old white non-Hispanic female who signed consent into the protocol on 3/21/2019. She was randomized to aripiprazole augmentation and began Step 1 study medications on 3/28/2019. The participant completed the Step 1 acute phase on 6/6/2019 as a remitter on duloxetine 60 mg and aripiprazole 2 mg. The last assessment completed was her Step 1 Month 4 assessment on 10/22/2019. She remained a remitter while on duloxetine 60mg and aripiprazole 5mg.     After numerous failed attempts to reach the participant via phone and email between 10/29/2019 and 2/14/2020 , we reached out to the participant's PMD on 2/24/2019 to obtain collateral information. We made contact with the PMD on 3/5/2020, who stated that the participant had attended a podiatrist appointment on 12/18/2019, but had missed her PMD, vascular, hematology-oncology, and dermatology appointments, all scheduled between 12/30/2020 and 1/15/2020. The PMD stated that she was going to reach out to her team's social worker and update us with any relevant information.    On 3/11/2019, we received a phone call from the PMD. Over the past week, her team's social worker called the police to complete a wellness check on the participant. The police informed the social worker that the participant was deceased and found in her apartment on 1/14/2020. Her PMD was not contacted to fill out a death certificate. The body is currently at a medical examiner's office where cause of death is being determined. The PMD has faxed a letter to the ME office to obtain records of their findings and will update us when the report is obtained. Date of death will be entered as 1/14/2020 but will be changed when we obtain more information.
ae_relevant_info: Medical comorbidities extracted from the participant's medical history form are past anemia, an appendectomy at age 14 and hysterectomy at age 50. She was diagnosed with the following during her non-psychiatric hospitalization in October 2019: macrocytic anemia, eosinophilia, MDS (myelodysplastic syndrome of unknown specificity), and MGUS (monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance).

Patient was not feeling well on 3/28/20. He fell and could not get up. EMS was contacted and he was transported to the local hospital. Patient had cellulitis on left leg, as well as elevated creatinine and A1C levels and low potassium levels. Of note, this was his 3rd bout of cellulitis in his lifetime (and subjectively reported the worst episode thus far). Patient was given IV antibiotics and stayed in the hospital for 11 nights. He was discharged on 4/8/20. He continues to take antibiotics and potassium medications. His diabetes medications were switched to long and short acting insulin pens. He has been attending check-ins with his doctor regarding the hospitalization and may undergo reconditioning physical therapy. He continued to take study medications throughout his hospitalization and continued to do so now that he is recuperating at home.

ae_narrative: During a follow-up call on 11/14/19, the patient reported that she went to the New York Presbyterian Allen Hospital Emergency Department on 11/11/2019 due to worsening back pain after bending over. She informed us that she underwent a CT scan, where they found a filling defect in her distal ascending arch. The patient was then transferred to cardiology for a consultation with Dr. Hiroo Takayama. There, she denied ever experiencing severe upper chest or back pain apart from the current episode and reported no history of stroke or acute limb pain. She was diagnosed with aortic arch mural thrombus likely from a complex plaque and was recommended anticoagulation. Cardiology stated that her back-pain symptoms were likely unrelated to the thrombus in the aorta. She was discharged from the hospital on 11/13/19 and was instructed to take Eliquis 5mg BID. The patient was also instructed to schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Hiroo Takayama in the Aortic Clinic and a hematology consultation within the next two weeks.   It is the impression of the study team that the patient's hospitalization is not related to her antidepressant medication. During the follow-up call on 11/14/19, we encouraged the patient to schedule her recommended appointments and she verbally agreed to do so. The patient has also agreed to bring her discharge summary to her now delayed step 1 week 4 visit on 11/20/19.

Patient came in for in-person appointment on 1/23/2020 after being discharged from the hospital.

Wife of subject called about husband's fall on March 7th. He was initially admitted to SMUCLA and went to Ronald Reagan. He does not remember how and why he fell, but received 19 staples in his head, broken ocular bones/clavicle/shoulder which resulted in pulmonary embolisms on both lung. He was placed on heparin and developed a hematoma in his right thigh.   Subject has been discontinued from study medication (lithium) by ER doctors as of the 7th as he kept saying that was the cause. However, wife and treating doctors disagree. PI conference call on 03/22/18 for study determined lithium use was unlikely correlated with the fall.

The subject was randomized on January 31st 2018, into the Step 1 arm of 'Augmentation with Abilify'.   The subject was not active in the study as we encountered some logistical issues with receiving provider consent, and getting in touch with the subject thereafter. We were able to make contact with the study doctor, and paged him as a reminder of the subject's suggested randomized treatment Friday, May 18th. Study staff was notified that subject was deceased upon return on May 22nd.   The subject's PCP has clarified to his study doctor that the official cause of death is unknown. The subject was found dead in his apartment with a contusion and scratch on his head, and the floor was wet. The subject had been taking a blood thinner (Eliquis) for atrial fibrillation and doctors suspect an accidental fall that may have preceded an intracranial bleed as a possibility. The subject's family however is declining an autopsy. The subject had been randomized and enrolled at the time of his passing, but not active as he had not yet received the prescription for suggested treatment.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Study team was notified on 2/12/2020 that participant passed away on Saturday 2/8/2020. He had chest pains that worsened on 2/8 and had had a heart attack on 1/31/2020. Developed cold symptoms around 2/5. Had coronary problems and several stents. He was in Step1 Continuation and was not currently taking a study medication.     Participant died at age 80. He was a Hispanic or Latino, White male. He consented to the study on 9/5/2018 and was randomized to Augmentation to Abilify. After speaking further with his PCP, he decided not to start the study medication, but increase his index medication. He started this on 3/14/2019. He was not eligible for Step 2. He completed all Week 10 assessment on 6/12/2019. His last assessment was his Month 4 MADRS on 9/27/2019. He was due for his Month 8 and missed his appointment. He called to reschedule.     He had diabetes Type 2, high blood pressure (controlled by medication), anemia (controlled by medication), high cholesterol (controlled by medication), Chronic Kidney disease, Coronary artery disease (under control), coronary stents placed and leg stents, and neuropathy in legs. Had Left heart Cathetarization surgery in December 2019 with stent placing.

On 5/16/19 this participant fell and hit his head/side of his face while at home.  He was unable to get up and lay there for 16 hours before his neighbor found him and helped him into bed.  After the fall he was feeling very weak / unable to walk or move by himself / and at one point was apparently having visual hallucinations.  He was admitted to the hospital on 5/20/19 with generalized weakness and pain with movement, no blurry vision or dizziness, no nausea or vomiting, no slurred speech or vision changes.   Was found to have AKI.  Lithium was discontinued and patient was discharged on 5/23/19.  Creatinine was 2.12 mg/dL on admission on 5/20/19 and had lowered to 1.21 mg/dL by 5/22/19.  Lithium level on 5/20/19 was 0.300 mmol/L.

Participant started feeling weak and shaky with a hand tremor after starting Lithium 150mg (augmenting with Bupropion 300mg).  Participant took the dose for 3 days before self-discontinuing due to the side effect.  Tremor stopped after discontinuing Lithium.

Participant reported at Step 2 Continuation Month 4 that he had fallen about 5 times in the past 4 months due to dizziness.  Three times he experienced only minor bruises/cuts, but once was hospitalized.  This fall (reported here as an SAE) occurred on 7/23/2019.  The participant reports he was feeling dizzy and fell to the left, hitting his left arm and left side of his head on the floor.  He was taken to the ER with left sided headache, earache, and jaw pain, and admitted to the hospital.  Per medical chart reported as 'a syncopal event with trauma to the L side of the head, CT Brain and CT face negative for acute trauma.' He was discharged from the hospital on 7/25/2019, but continued to report ear pain, per medical report 'On exam, L ear diffusely swollen but not erythematous. Tympanic membrane difficult to visualize 2/2 pain and swelling but no perforations seen.' Ear pain has since resolved as of 9/6/2019.
ae_relevant_info: At baseline this patient had reported two falls in the previous 6 months due to dizziness.  He had had a stroke prior to study start and reported experiencing occasional dizziness and falls ever since that time.

ae_narrative: Voluntary dental surgery involving implants (dental bridge).  Full recovery with no adverse effects.

Dental work, teeth taken out. Has dry mouth and talks slower due to this dental work. Reported to have happened 6 weeks ago from 6/14/19. So, approximately on May 3, 2019.    Had more dental work done around 1/13/2020. Had to take antibiotics for abscessed tooth. Work in progress for the three teeth implants needed. Currently in pain from procedure. Past procedure went wrong and it caused a lot of dental pain. Plans to have changes made with another dentist.

Fell about four weeks ago from 10/16/19. Twisted ankle and her thumb nail broke her fall. Had bruising on thigh and her fingernail fell off. Went to Urgent care and was given a thumb brace for her right thumb. Had pain on her thumb and it is currently sore. Has to cover her hand and brace while showering. Luckily, she is left handed.

Started Brand name Wellbutrin and therefore not experiencing mood swings.    She described mood swings as feeling elated and then discouraged and irritated easily. It brings her down.

He isn't sure if lowering the dose helped directly, but he relates it to now having fewer nightmares.

ae_narrative: Participant had been taking 450mg dose of Bupropion for 3 weeks and reported he started getting tremor in his hands, involuntary movements in his legs, and slurred speech.  Went to the ER and they 'couldn't find out what was wrong even after MRI, blood tests, and EKG.'  Only recent change in medications had been the Bupropion increase in dose, so the emergency department recommended he decrease the dose back to 300mg, which he did on Friday 3/22/19.  Since that time (5 days since) his symptoms have almost completely resolved: some minor 'jerkiness' in his left leg, with no tremor or slurred speech.  Participant will now stay on 300mg dose for 1-2 weeks per PI recommendation then be considered for Step 2.

ae_narrative: Participant's gums started bleeding about two weeks ago.  Participant thinks it is due to stress.  He is not currently taking the study medication. Patient told his wife to hide in the bathroom because he was feeling the urge to harm her, and he called 911.  He was admitted the same day to a pyschiatric hold.  Per chart review, he had been progressively more verbally aggressive towards his wife over the past 8 months, which has escalated from calling her names to throwing and breaking plates and grabbing her by the arm.  He reported being increasingly depressed and suicidal over the same period.  When admitted, he denied feeling SI or depressed, just 'frustrated' because of severe back pain and weakness that has been impacting his daily functioning since October 2018.  He was also upset that his back surgery had to be postponed due to hypercalcemia.  This participant had never started the randomized treatment with the study because although he agreed to be willing to take the randomization before enrollment, he decided against it once he was randomized to Bupropion switch.  He was instead followed on the preferred treatment of Duloxetine 90mg with Mirtazapine 30mg in Step 1.  He was deemed ineligible for Step 2 due to exclusionary EKG values.  At the time of this SAE he was in Continuation phase.    Update on 8/3/19: participant was re-admitted to a psychiatric hold for aggressive behavior, assaulting his wife and caregiver.  This was a continuation of similar symptoms following his first hospitalization on 7/14/2019 from which he was discharged on 7/19/2019.  Due to multiple hospitalizations, difficulty with reaching participant for phone followups, and his reticence to answer study questions, it has been determined by the PI that he is no longer appropriate for the research study.  Termination form completed on 8/9/2019.
ae_relevant_info: Besides everything noted in the narrative description, it should be noted that the same patient was voluntarily admitted to the hospital for severe back pain and leg pain on 2/24/2019, noted in a separate SAE on 2/26/2019.

This participant was randomized in Step 1 to 'Augmentation with Aripiprazole' and started Aripiprazole 2.5mg as an addition to his ongoing Escitalopram 10mg on 8/14/19.  For five weeks following the start of Aripiprazole the patient stopped responding to calls or emails and a followup was not able to be completed until 9/18/2019.  On that date study staff became aware that the participant had been experiencing dull left lateral side and chest pain for which he had been seen in the emergency department on 8/25/19, 8/27/19, and finally was admitted to the hospital on 9/8/19, 'admitted for management of uncontrolled pain and expedited workup,' 'noted to have extensive bulky abdomina/pelvic lymphadenopathy suspicious for lymphoma.' Discharged on 9/13/19. Following bone marrow biopsy and excisional lymph node biopsy, he was diagnosed with mantle cell lymphoma.  At this time, participant wishes to remain in the research study.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Participant experienced a heart attack on 4/18/2020 and passed away. Study team became aware of this on 8/12/2020 after finding his obituary after his phone was disconnected. He was in Step 1 Continuation, and was currently taking the medications recommended from his provider (please see notes regarding randomization).    Participant died at age 68. He was a White male. He did not identify as Hispanic or Latino. He consented to the study on 9/5/2018 and was randomized to Switch to bupropion on 9/30/2019. MD was not willing to prescribe recommended medication. Instead of switching to Welbutrin (i.e. increase dose to 450mg), Lexapro 20mg was added to augment his current antidepressant regimen (Trazodone 50mg + Welbutrin 300mg). He was not eligible for Step 2. He completed all acute assessments on 12/19/2019. His last assessment was his Month 4 Call on 4/16/2020. He was due for his Month 4 MADRS and missed his appointment. We were unable to reach him to reschedule this. When attempting to schedule his Month 8 Visit, participant was still non-responsive to calls and phone was now disconnected.     In his medical history, he was currently experiencing arthritis, back/joint pain, prostate disease, allergies/sinusitis, and plantar fasciitis; no past conditions were noted. For prior surgeries/procedures, he had a lumbar fusion in 2017. He also wore bilateral hearing aids.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

Pt made a suicide attempt on 2-5-2020 by overdosing on a medication cocktail of unspecified medications due to feeling like 'nothing was worth it'. The event was reported as not being premeditated. She called 9-1-1 and was taken to the ED where they told her she had abnormally high levels of acetaminophen in her system. She was awake and conscious, no serious medical complications were noted. She stayed in a non-psychiatric hospital for 4 days before being transferred to a psychiatric hospital for 1 week. Study medication (Welbutrin 300mg) was discontinued upon hospitalization and pt has been compliant on Viibryd 40mg qd since discharge.    PCP is aware and followed up with participant on 3/14/2020. Upon discharge, participant reached out to adult children and ex-husband for support. She is now living with ex-husband and his wife in Fresno, where she started seeing a psychiatrist once a week. States she feels much better now with no SI/PDW and is happy she is not alone during this time of shelter at home. She feels comforted that there are people there to support her. This participant has not reported SI since baseline but did report a past SA via overdosing when she was 16 yo. Passive death wish was expressed at Week 10 (January 2020) with no desire or plan to harm or kill self. Pt was aware and acknowledged resources available to her if she were to feel like hurting herself again.

Had a catheterization procedure to observe any heart blockages (around 2/12/21); a week later, experiencing shortness of breath, numbness, nausea, dizziness shortly after this and went to the hospital. Did EKG, stated she had a 3rd degree heart block. Was in ICU for 8 days, was on kidney dialysis during this time. While in ICU, a temporary pacemaker was implanted around the time she was initially admitted, then after she was out of the ICU, an ICD defibrillator (3/11/21) was implanted. Discharged on 3/12/21. Has been to the emergency room outpatient three times since for same symptoms, also three follow-ups with the cardiologist to check the implanted device.     Since then, pt. has been recovering and has a lot of weakness, fatigue. Couldn't walk when she came home from the hospital; she is walking now unassisted, but needs to build strength with physical therapy.    7/24/2021 - Still continuing PT; seems more stable now. Iron deficiency is now being treated.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Pt. had a colonoscopy on 7/2/2021; shortly after was experiencing excessive bleeding as a complication of the procedure. Bleeding was controlled and pt. was discharged on 7/5/2021 around 9pm. No complications since discharge; repeated labs to check blood counts and was still low afterwards. Is currently in treatment to regulate this.

uku_sym_cat: Other Side Effect That Does Not Fit Any Above
ae_narrative: with PMHx unspecified connective tissue disease, inflammatory arthritis, fibromyalgia, MDD/ADHD, hyperparathyroidism who presents for chest pain.      States she normally has chest pain once weekly. Described as chest pressure, substernal in center, 2/10 severity, no radiation, non-exertional, non-pleuritic, non-positional, usually lasts minutes. Today, however, she developed the same chest pressure at 2:30PM and did not go away for which she decided to come to ED. Endorses intermittent palpitations. Also states that 2 nights ago had brief, sudden numbness in her L arm, unclear trigger, spontaneously resolved. Denies fevers, chills, URI symptoms, SOB, N/V, diarrhea/constipation, urinary symptoms. Endorses bloating pain in abdomen, chronic. States she also has intermittent numbness/tingling in her BL feet. Pt states that lately she has been feeling anxious about her health, and is currently anxious.      Hospital Course:       The patient was admitted for chest pain. On admission, patient was ruled out for ACS with serial troponin and EKG, all which were normal. On further discussion, she believes the (resolved, subacute) chest pain was worse after eating. She also described burning epigastric pain. Her noncardiac chest pain that she presented with was likely GERD, gastritis, or a motility problem. An EGD done in 2019 noted hiatal hernia, likely causing symptoms. By discharge she was symptom free. She was started on PPI and maalox PRN and discharged with these medicines. She is interested in a referral to nephrology to discuss chronic polyuria.    Participant was in hospital less than a day.    She was told that she has nodules in her lungs. They thought she was having a heart attack, but it was the nodules.     1/31/2021 went to urgent care due to chest pain (shortness of breath and dizziness); chronic pulmonary aspiration. Discharged the same day. Dry daily cough and chest tightness. Prescribed Amoxicillin-pot Clavulanate 875-125mg     Saw Pulmonologist and this physician thinks it might be due to asthma or constructive airway disease. Prescribed inhalers such as Advair and Albuterol. Still waiting for official diagnosis.
ae_relevant_info: Discharge meds:  aluminum-magnesium hydroxide-simethicone 200-200-20 mg/5 mL suspension  Take 15 mLs by mouth every six (6) hours as needed.  Notes to patient:  For gas pain     pantoprazole 40 mg DR tablet  Commonly known as:  Protonix  Take 1 tablet (40 mg total) by mouth daily.  Notes to patient:  For stomach upset, GERD   Stopped taking it after 1.5 weeks because it made her sick    1/31/2021  Prescribed Augmentin for 7 days.

In short, he had persistent diarrhea and dizziness and was admitted to the hospital for a colonoscopy tests and observation then discharged    Discharge Information   Discharge Summary:          Admit Date: 3/23/2018.         Discharge Date: 3/26/2018.      He presented to the Emergency Room with a 4-week history of progressively  worsening diarrhea, fatigue, dizziness, and lightheadedness when he stands  up.  He states he has had multiple bowel movements about 8-10 bowel  movements earlier this morning.  He does admit to some mucus with the  stools.  He does occasionally have blood mixed with the stool, but not  always.  He denies any cramping abdominal pain.  No fevers or chills or  sweats.  He denies any dysuria or difficulty urinating.  No nausea.  No  vomiting.  He denies any melena.  No hematemesis or coffee-ground emesis.   His appetite has been pretty good.  He denies any unexplained weight loss.   He has never had a colonoscopy.  He did recently see his PCP.  He did have  stool cultures done as an outpatient, revealing stool for Giardia was  negative and stool for enteric pathogens, Salmonella, and Shigella are  negative.  The stool for ova and parasites and stool for Campylobacter are  pending.     He does tell me that when he gets up and stands up and walks initially does  feel a little lightheaded and dizzy.  He denies any syncope.  No chest  pains or chest pressure.  No orthopnea.  No PND.  He does have a history of  severe LV dysfunction/cardiomyopathy.  He has been compliant with his  cardiac medications.  He denies any nocturnal angina.  No orthopnea.  No  PND or edema in the legs.     He was seen here in the Emergency Room on March 18.  He was given IV  fluids, discharged home and came back with worsening symptoms.  His white  count is 6.7, hemoglobin 10.2, hematocrit 30.5, MCV 88.5, and platelet  count 194,000.  Sodium 138, potassium 4.3, chloride 112, bicarbonate 18,  BUN 34, and creatinine 2.97.  He had a serum creatinine of 2.88 on March  18, 2018.  Blood sugar 142.    The patient's problem list while here in the hospital included the following last updated on the day of discharge:     1. pancolitis for colonsocpy today   Diarrhea has resolved  Appreciate GI input can be discharge of colonoscopy not show any acute finding  2.  Cardiomyopathy/coronary artery disease/severe left ventricular  dysfunction/defibrillator, stable, well compensated.  Currently on lisinopril and Coreg blood pressure is tolerable  3.  Type 2 diabetes mellitus requiring insulin. On 12 units of Lantus insulin blood sugars are stable with lower dose however patient has not been eating as well in the hospital may need to increase after discharge to home  4.  Hyperlipidemia.  Low-cholesterol, low-triglyceride diet.  Continue  Lipitor therapy.    5.  Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease/tobacco abuse.  We did discuss  tobacco cessation program at the bedside, he declined at this time.   Albuterol 2 puffs q. 4 hours p.r.n. shortness of breath.   6.  Peripheral artery disease, stable.  Continue aspirin and Lipitor  therapy, walking program daily.  7.  Deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis, subcutaneous heparin   8. Acute on chronic renal failure no nsaids     Patient seen and examined with case manager and discussed with nursing staff will discharge him home today after colonoscopy  To see us in the office in one week's time  Will order home care

After an appropriate timeout was performed, the                      patient was identified and procedure was verified.                      After I obtained informed consent, the colonoscope                      was passed under direct vision. The                      CF- HQ190L 2513574 was introduced through the anus                      and advanced up to the terminal ileum. Biopsied.                     - Biopsies were taken with a cold forceps for                      evaluation of microscopic colitis. ae_narrative: He does tell me that when he gets up and stands up and walks initially does  feel a little lightheaded and dizzy.  He denies any syncope.  No chest  pains or chest pressure.  No orthopnea.  No PND.  He does have a history of  severe LV dysfunction/cardiomyopathy.  He has been compliant with his  cardiac medications.  He denies any nocturnal angina.  No orthopnea.  No  PND or edema in the legs.

Patient reported to the ER complaining of shortness of breath and productive cough. They admitted him for 4 days for treatment and observation, determining he had possible pneumonia and pleural effusions, neither related to either bupropion or aripiprazole treatment.     Hospital Course      Patient is a 64-year-old male who was recently at the  hospital, admitted on March 23, found to have a pancolitis, had diarrhea,  he did improve, also found to have COPD, discharged home on March 27.   Following this he did develop, per patient report, pneumonia.  He was given  10 days of antibiotic. He began  to throw up some small chunks of blood.  He indicates he gradually got  increased shortness of breath.  Upon interview in the Emergency Room, he  was noted to be on oxygen at 2 liters.  He indicates that he is feeling  better on that oxygen.  During the workup, he was also noted to have  bilateral pleural effusion.  Per records, there is also bilateral  pneumonitis for which he did receive antibiotics while in the Emergency  Room.  Currently, he does continue to complain of shortness of breath.  He  denies any fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or chest pain.  He did have a  bedside echocardiogram done, which did show no pericardial effusion.     The patient's problem list while here in the hospital included the following last updated on the day of discharge:     1.  Bilateral pleural effusion. appreciate pulmonary input.  s/p drainage.  on IV lasix. Can be changed to by mouth  On 4 L per discussed with pulmonary they do return down to 2 L will check laboratory pulse ox and patient to be discharged home  He is to follow-up with them in 4 weeks time  2.   pneumonia--started on cefepime 2 doses given will transition to  po   3.  CHF secondary to systolic function EF of 20-30% is currently in IV Lasix to transition to by mouth  4.  Acute on chronic kidney disease Kidney  appreciate renal imput.    Follow with Renal As an Outpatient  5.  Hypertension, added norvasc 2.5 (home dosing is 5mg).  added coreg at reduced dosing also--will increase 12.5 twice a day  6.  Hyperlipidemia, treated with Zetia and Lipitor  7. Leukocytosis resolved with antibiotics  8.  mood: added abilify and wellbutrin.    Can be restarted on his trazodone     Patient is requesting discharge discussed with pulmonary they feel that he is stable for discharge we'll need to follow-up with us closely as an outpatient in one week's time  Follow up with renal in 1 week  Ambulatory pulse ox today  Will update case manager

ae_narrative: On 2/15/18 pt SD who is in remission in continuation step 1 contacted staff to report she has been experiencing nausea in the evenings for the past two months (see clinical notes) after she takes her index medication of Trintellix.  Nausea was reported at baseline.  On 3/16/18 at the 8 month continuation call she reports continued nausea which she feels is related to the Trintellix.  It has lessed a bit in severity since she contacted OPTIMUM on 2/15/18 but is still present.  Therefore, she plans to discontinue Trintellix 10mg.   She does feel it is a side-effect to Trintellix (and could be possibly related).  She does not feel it is a side-effect to Wellbutrin.  She takes Trintellix in the evening and Wellbutrin in the morning.  Nausea is present in the evening within a few hours of taking Trintellix.
ae_relevant_info: As of 7/13/18 (S1C12M) she still reports nausea but feels that it is now 'mild'.  She continues to believe that it is related to the Trintellix as she mainly gets the nausea in the evening after she has taken her Trintellix and Maxzide.  She does not get nausea during the day after taking Wellbutrin qam.  She does wish to discontinue Trintellix.      Participant has completed participation, AE of nausea was ongoing at study completion.  Participant felt the symptom was related to her index medication.

ae_narrative: On 11/27/17 the patient didn't arrive as rescheduled for her NIH toolbox appointment for S2W10. She reports that last week she was hospitalized for an ischemic stroke. It's not clear where she was hospitalized: we do not have access to medical records related to this event. She reports feeling like something wasn't right and slurring her speech. She says her daughter took her to the hospital and they admitted her 11/21/17 and discharged her 11/23/17. She used the words 'ischemic stroke' when she said what they told her she had. She said they're doing some follow-up to see if she has an arrhythmia that is throwing clots and may have a cardioverter implanted. She'll be following up with a cardiologist next month and with her PCP this week.
ae_relevant_info: UPDATE 12/1/17: She followed up with her PCP, who confirmed the event and that she was admitted to Jefferson Hospital, which is why we don't have records. Here's the text of his note:    This is a very pleasant 69-year-old female with past medical history of stroke in 1995 and multiple episodes of TIAs after that came to the office for follow-up after recent hospitalization, where she was admitted to Jefferson Hospital on 21/11/2017 because of TIA. In the morning of that day she had what it seems like Broka's aphasia. Workup during last hospitalization was unremarkable.   MRI showed no acute pathology that could explain her symptoms at that time. Carotid artery duplex was unremarkable bilaterally.  The patient was compliant with her aspirin 81 mg and Lipitor 40 mg. The aphasia lasted for more than a day and was resolved completely after that.  She is still complaining of mild weakness in the right leg which is a residual of the stroke she had in 1995. She uses a cane for ambulation. And she had multiple episodes of falls.  30 day event monitor was also ordered last month, results of which are not available at this point. We faxed the cardiology clinic at White Oak requesting to make the results available for us.     fReview of Systems   Constitutional: Negative. Negative for chills, fever, malaise/fatigue and weight loss.   HENT: Negative. Negative for congestion, ear pain, hearing loss, sinus pain and tinnitus.   Eyes: Negative for blurred vision, double vision, photophobia, pain, discharge and redness.   The patient complained of visual field defects, which showed a residual of the occipital stroke she had in 1995   Respiratory: Negative. Negative for cough, hemoptysis, sputum production, shortness of breath and wheezing.   Cardiovascular: Positive for palpitations. Negative for chest pain and orthopnea.   Gastrointestinal: Positive for heartburn. Negative for abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.   Genitourinary: Negative. Negative for dysuria, frequency and urgency.   Musculoskeletal: Negative. Negative for back pain, myalgias and neck pain.   Skin: Negative. Negative for itching and rash.   Neurological: Positive for focal weakness. Negative for dizziness, tingling, tremors, sensory change, speech change, seizures, loss of consciousness and headaches.   Endo/Heme/Allergies: Negative for environmental allergies. Does not bruise/bleed easily.   Psychiatric/Behavioral: Positive for depression. Negative for hallucinations, substance abuse and suicidal ideas.     # TIA     Etiology: still unknown.   Carotid dopplers are normal. We are working up the pt for atrial fibrillation.  The patient had a 30 day event monitor the results of which we couldn't access.  If the results came back normal the next step is to 2 loop recorder to evaluate for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.  The patient is already taking aspirin 81 mg and Lipitor 40 mg.  We added Plavix for the regiment for better management of stroke risk and TIAs.  In case we confirmed that the patient has atrial fibrillation, especially that she complains of frequent palpitations, we'll start her on appropriate anticoagulation.        # GERD     Patient uses Pepcid to manage her symptoms.  Since we started the patient on Plavix on top of the aspirin, we switched the Pepcid to Protonix for GI management and better GI prophylaxis against thick ulcers.        # Depression      The patient was on Prozac for depression management.  She says that her symptoms are under control with Prozac. However, whenever she tries to come off of it she experiences relapse of major depression.  Since we started patient on Plavix, there was an interaction between Prozac and Plavix. Apparently, Prozac will decrease the effectiveness of Plavix. To avoid such a complication, we started the patient on Lexapro 5 mg.   The patient is involved in a study at UPMC for depression in the elderly. On switching Prozac to Lexapro we assumed a class effect. In case the researchers at UPMC are concerned about the alternative therapy that we started, they can contact the UPMC McKeesport clinic.   We believe that the benefit of dual antiplatelet therapy and prevention of TIA and stroke, outweighs the risk of increased bleeding. We believe that Lexapro will control the depressive symptoms, and that the stroke prevention is the more persistent issue at this point.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_title: Dizziness reported at outpatient appt w/ Endocrinologist
ae_narrative: On 9/6/17 JMK e-mailed Dr. Karp:  I attempted to call pt today for her week 10 call as scheduled but she did not answer so I have not spoken to her yet.  However, in checking EHR I noticed that she was evaluated yesterday for dizziness at her Endocrinologists who reported that  7 years ago, she had an episode of dizziness and was diagnosed with reactive hypoglycemia on oral glucose tolerance test.       Their eval:    Dizziness: Resolved.   - Orthostatic are neg. A1C 6.3%. Episode likely no related hypoglycemia as dizziness improved with rest, not food.   - encouraged to seek further evaluation for PCP as dizziness can be caused by various reasons - benign, dehydration, medications, hypotension, arrhythmias, stress, medication
ae_relevant_info: Pt does have PMHx reactive hypoglycemia as well as a similar episode 7yrs ago.

uku_sym_cat: Other Side Effect That Does Not Fit Any Above
ae_narrative: She reported that the first 3 or 4 days on Lithium her brain felt clearer but then she started feeling 'foggy' liker 'her brain isn't on full alert, almost lethargic'.  She said this is a different feeling from being able to concentrate and it does go away when she becomes involved in an activity (like when she is talking with a group of people) and she can follow through with tasks once she gets started.  However, this foggy feeling does make it more difficult to get going/get started on tasks.
ae_relevant_info: Dr. Karp said that it is most certainly possibly related to lithium.  Some people feel it causes mental slowing.  But the majority don't.  It's more with bipolar people who complain of this, and it just may be that their brain is not so racy and 'bright' but actually more normal.  But it could be a negative side effect.  We will monitor closely.  She is currently on 300mg Lithium qhs.
ae_action_other: No change to study medication at this time.

ae_narrative: On 11/6/17 she called to say that she has had increased difficulty staying asleep and that she feels exhausted.  She feels this is a side-effect of increasing Lithium to 600mg.  She would like to decrease to 300mg (see clinical notes).    03/28/18 Her main concern currently is continued difficulty staying asleep.  She reports going to bed around 10:00pm with wakening after @ 5hrs followed by restless dozing until she finally getting up for the day around 6:30am.  She also reports daily low energy/tiredness and will frequently need to take a short nap after lunch.  She recognizes part of her trouble sleeping may be due to arthritic pain in her hands and back.  Dr. Karp suggested 'If anything, she can increase the dose of Wellbutrin up to 450 mg in the morning to see if it helps decrease sleepiness.  I do think she should stay on the lithium though.'  On 7/27/2018 she had not increased to 450mg Wellbutrin.   Endorsed daily trouble staying asleep and feeling tired/little energy.  This has been reported for quite some time.  She will fall asleep for @ 4-5 hrs and then wake up.  It is hard to fall back asleep because her mind races and she will just doze until it is time to get out of bed.  She reports her sleep is better than when she first joined the study.  Overall, she feels her mood is pretty good, she is functioning and active but tired.   S2C12M  11/26/2018. Continues 450mg bupropion XL (300mg plus 150mg) and 300mg Lithium.  Also taking 2.5mg diazepam qhs.  Denies side-effects or falls.  PHQ-9 = 6.  Overall reports doing about the same, not sleeping well but it is better, mood has improved some.  Staying asleep continues to be her most frequent problem, averaging 4-5hrs/night with several awakenings where she will get out of bed to get a drink (dry throat from Barrett's esophagus) and using restroom, will only doze off & on afterwards.  She does feel reasonably rested unless she is very active (i.e. feels very tired after exercising). She tries not to nap to avoid impacting sleep.
ae_relevant_info: Ongoing at time of study completion (Lithium had been reduced from 600 to 300mg, Wellbutrin was increased to 450mg)

uku_sym_cat: Other Side Effect That Does Not Fit Any Above
ae_narrative: She reported at the 8month call on 7/27/18 that 'lately' she is concerned that she may not be getting enough water (dehydrated) even though she drinks plenty of liquid in a day (full glass of water with her thyroid medication, a full glass of water with Metamucil, coffee/tea, milk, and 1-2 glasses of water at night).  She says that she read that a way to tell if you are dehydrated is if you pinch your skin and it doesn't bounce back, which she says that her skin does not bounce back and is more saggy under her arms.  She was concerned this could be a side-effect to lithium because her doctor said based on some blood work that she didn't want to go higher on the dose.      Dr. Gebara wrote on 7/27/18:  I don't think dehydration is related to either medication. But lithium is associated with increased frequency and a feeling of thirst which can feel like dehydration. Another thing to check is if she is tachycardic that would be more suggestive that she is dehydrated.   Does she have polyuria? Is she urinating frequently? It depends where you pinch the skin for this test to be reliable. It might be a good idea to let the PCP know as they might want to check BMP, serum and urine osmolality. I think it would be a good idea to increase Wellbutrin ( 3 tablets of 150 mg).
ae_relevant_info: She was no longer reporting this symptom at the 12M call on 11/26/2018.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

She noted at the call today 7/27/17 that this is slightly increased & is more persistent rather than periodic & that her whole body feels shaky rather than just her hands.   This has continued if not slightly worsened even through study end S2C12M on 9/5/18.  She reports this does hamper some activity but is not present constantly and it does seem to worsen with stress.      On 9/14/18 Jordan Karp wrote:  BM: Decrease lithium to 300 mg.  On 9/14/18 JMK sent update to Dr. Karp:    completed in-person S2C12M LAST WEEK on 9/5/18.  Continues augmenting Cymbalta 120mg with Lithium 600mg.  Continues to feel that hand tremor is a possible side-effect but recognizes that tremor increases with stress.   Hand tremor was present at baseline but she does feel that it has gotten worse as now it is hard to carry beverages, etc.  She also reports that sometimes she feels 'shaking' in her whole body. ae_narrative: From: Karp, Jordan   Sent: Wednesday, November 29, 2017 3:29 PM  To: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon); Stack, Jackie  Subject: bXXX maXXXX     Hi,  I just talked to the geriatric fellow who said she is at Heritage Nursing Home for rehab after a fall.  I don't have more details, but wondered if you should investigate to see what happened, and report this as SAE, or else just wait till her next follow-up call, and document it then.  The latter is probably ok, but wanted to share this before I forgot.     Again -- these falls and admission rates are mind-boggling.     Jordan      Joelle reviewed medical records and based on ER & admission reports, this patient had a mechanical fall on 10/31/17 when she slipped from one of the plastic bin lids on the floor.  The patient did not lose consciousness, there was no syncopal episodes, no associated chest pain before the fall.  She did however sustain L humerus fx and L rib fxs.  She was therefore admitted to the local medical hospital and received orthopedic surgery.  She was discharged on 11/10/17 to a skilled nursing facility for short-term rehabilitation.
ae_relevant_info: She was discharged to home on 12/4/17  At Study Completion (S2C12M) on 9/5/18 she reported that she had to have a follow-up surgery on 6/15/18 to remove the plates & screws that were placed in her left shoulder as a result from breaking her shoulder during the fall.  She continues to have limited range of motion in her left shoulder.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

She does not feel this is similar to orthostatic hypotension but she is unable to check her BP as her machine does not work.  She was concerned this could be related to the increase in Cymbalta from 60mg to 120mg on 6/28/17.  This is unlikely.  It is also unlikely related to Abilify or the combination of Cymbalta & Abilify.  Of note she did start taking 20mg Lipitor on 7/25/17 (the day prior to this event).  She contacted her PCP and they noted that she has had rhinitis and postnasal drip x several months & sounded congested so they suggested to add Sudafed to see if this improves symptoms.    Of note at Continuation Month 4 she reported continued issues with vertigo which her doctor felt was vestibular and for which she went to see a vestibular specialist.  This symptoms is now resolving.  In light of this information I will change the relationship from possibly related to not likely related.

ae_title: Fall with laceration and ER visit
ae_narrative: he fell out of bed tonight striking his right eyebrow over the night stand. No loss of consciousness. He denies any other injuries.   He went to the ER on 8/7/17 & received sutures for the laceration and was discharged the same day.  Sutures were removed at a follow-up visit with his PCP on 8/11/17.  At a follow-up call with OPTIMUM staff on 8/14/17 he reported his injury has healed and he has had no other complications.   Of note he was being tapered from his antidepressant medications Effexor & Wellbutrin and was scheduled to start Nortriptyline switch on 8/8/17.  Therefore the event may be related to the study procedures of tapering off of his existing medications but not related to the study medications as he had not yet started taking nortriptyline.

8/22/17- He did mention that over the past week he has been slightly more emotional and will easily become tearful but can usual stop from crying if he is able to divert from the topic.  He feels this has been manageable.
ae_relevant_info: He had tapered off of Effexor and Wellbutrin in order to switch to NTP.    By 9/5/17 he 'He feels 'pretty good'.  He has no complaints and feel the medication has been helpful. '

ae_narrative: He also mentioned that he is starting to become more anxious about his breathing mainly when he goes to sleep at night when it is quiet.  He stated that this has happened years ago where he was very conscious/almost 'paranoid' that he was not getting enough air and felt like he couldn't catch his breath.  He even had gone to the doctor to get checked and when they looked at his blood O2 levels they felt that he was actually hyperventilating due to panic/anxiety and was getting too much O2.  He feels that this panic/anxiety is starting again.  He has needed to sleep on his side more rather than on his back as his anxiety about his breathing is worse when he lays flat on his back.  He did have a routine follow up with his PCP on 8/21/17.  He mentioned to his PCP his anxiety about his breathing and asked if there was a medical reason for feeling like he can't catch his breath.  His doctor examined his lungs/breathing and felt that medically his lungs sound fine (his airways are open, no wheezing ) and at this time does not feel he needs a 'scope' or additional tests.  His doctor did recommend that he begin using Breo on a regular basis rather than prn as of 8/14/17.   Of note he does use a C-PAP at night and has a history of COPD & lung cancer.  He also has needed to 'clear his throat' more frequently over the past couple weeks.
ae_relevant_info: His PCP wrote on 8/21/17 'His COPD is not in exacerbation. He does have persistent dyspnea on exertion but this is unchanged. He will continue on the Breo ellipta.'   This may be a somatic anxiety which is expected given his medical history and the pts report that this happened years ago.  He had recently tapered off of Effexor and Wellbutrin and was switched to NTP.

ae_title: ER visit for painful swelling in elbow (DVT)

Inner leg area, which seems to have subsided some but now, very painful to the touch at my right elbow and up my arm.  Has been puffy (swollen) at the elbow area also'.  He had contacted OPTIMUM to ask if either the chest cold or painful swelling could be related to NTP.  Dr. Karp felt that this was not related.  ER discharge diagnosis was cellulitis versus lyme disease.
ae_relevant_info: Had blood work to check for Lyme Disease.  Was given a prescription for an antibiotic, Augmentin x10days.  He followed-up with his PCP on 9/22/17.  Lyme test was negative.  PCP determined he had a DVT in his upper right extremity.  He was started on Eliquis 5mg BID.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_title: Expressive Aphasia/Medical Hospital Admission/Acute Infarct Right MCA
ae_narrative: Daughter brought him to the Greenville emergency department for confusion (per daughter) and difficulty with speech over the past 2 days.  He reports some word finding difficulty lasting several seconds for the past 30days (of note this was not mentioned nor evident during the OPTIMUM phone calls).  Expressive aphasia is now prolonged and apparent for the past 2 days.  He was admitted to UPMC Passavant for further evaluation and observation.  He was discharged to home on 10/18/17.    Although the hospitalization resolved as he was discharged to home on 10/18/17, he had residual symptoms of expressive aphasia until the time of his death on 1/2/18.
ae_relevant_info: Past medical history significant for left-sided pulmonary adenocarcinoma, status post left lower lobe resection, hypothyroidism, dyslipidemia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, recent diagnosis of right upper extremity DVT started on Eliquis on 9/22/2017; recent diagnosis of pneumonia.  About 1 month ago he developed a nonproductive cough for which he was seen by his primary care physician and started on Augmentin x10days, then started a course of doxycycline on 10/6/17 and prednisone on 9/28/17.      MRI w/o contrast on 10/17/17 suggest infarct that is at least 1 day old.  Acute infarcts predominantly in the right MCA distribution, with dominant infarct involving the right insular cortex and subcortical white matter, the posterior right temporal lobe, and the right inferior parietal lobule.  Multiple infarcts in multiple vascular distributions suggest a cardioembolic etiology.   He also had an ECHO which showed a small PFO.  Concern for hypercoagulability syndrome.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: In preparation for a 4 month continuation call scheduled for 2/20/18, OPTIMUM staff looked in the medical records for participant UP10029.  He passed away on 01/02/2018.  Preliminary Cause of Death:  Ventricular arrhthymia due to lung adenoca complicated by pneumonia.  Since his STEP 2 WK 10 call on 10/23/2017 he has been admitted to the hospital 3 times (12/2/17 for orthostatic hypotension; 12/24/17 for shortness of breath/dyspnea; dx pneumonia & a-fib; and 12/30/17 for confusion, dysphagia, SOB, pain).   In December 2017 it was determined that  lung adenocarcinoma was recurrent and had metastasized.  The death certificate listed as cause of death: atrial fibrillation to fatal arrythymia; pneumonia; lung adenocarcinoma; smoking/tobacco abuse.    Treatment in OPTIMUM was switch to NTP.  He did well and entered continuation as a remitter.

ae_narrative: He reports that he has had a chronic constant headache daily which spans across his eyes for the past 2 months.  He has seen his PCP and had 'all kinds of tests' including an eye exam, MRI, and biopsy with negative results and does not seem to be sinus related.  He denies the headaches being debilitating, he denies associated nausea/vomiting or visual disturbances.  He reports his BP has been normal.  The headache clinic is booked until March.  He reports that no over the counter medication has been successful in alleviating the headache. When asked which OTC medications he has tried his response was 'all of them'.   He is currently taking 300mg Wellbutrin & 20mg Prozac.  He is in the process of moving and sounds as if he has made good progress in organizing the 40+yrs of accumulated belongings.  His plan is to move to Shenley Gardens around Jan 15th.  He states that although the move may be a stressor he does not feel the headache is stress related.
ae_relevant_info: At the 4 month call he reported that the headache clinic gave him some medication to try.  He finished out the prescription and his headaches have not come back.  He saw headache clinic on 1/10/18.  They had him take olanzapine 2.5 mg nightly x 2 weeks to try to break headache cycle.  Headaches are now resolved.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

Patient went to her PCP, Dr. Steiner, yesterday for a regular check-up. She reports her doctor noticed some hand tremor and ordered an EKG while she was at the office. The EKG revealed new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response that was not present at her EKG from 8/8/2017.  Also new on the read from the 9/21/17 EKG was 'Nonspecific ST abnormality, probably digitalis effect.' and QTcB had increased to 504 from 453 ms on the 8/8/17 EKG. Her PCP started her on 5 mg of warfarin immediately. Patient remained on treatment and atrial fibrillation was an active problem on her med list at study end

P ?  RR/PP 378/150 ms  P/QRS/T ?/36/28    Interpretation: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, nonspecific ST abnormality, probably digitalis effect, abnormal ECG. 'New A Fib. No Acute ischemic change, DRW pt @ OV'

ae_narrative: This patient is not currently on study medication. He stopped about 2 weeks ago in response to an earlier SAE of high blood pressure. Patient has been receiving treatment for a boil on his side that was lanced by his PCP and hasn't been healing up. He went to get it checked yesterday and though they put some nice dressing on it, it bled through multiple dressings causing him to go back to the ER multiple times. Patient is on Coumadin and his INR was a little high, which is probably what is causing the bleeding.     UPDATE 11/20/17 - patient has been discharged and his bleeding is under control. Changing outcome to resolved. The patient reports that this was actually not a boil at all, but he'd forgotten about a tube that he'd had inserted years back to help with some kind of liver drainage. He may need later surgery to fully heal.
ae_relevant_info: From the medical record: Addendum by DURGAMPUDI MD, CHANDRA SEKHARA R on November 16, 2017 3:49 AM:  I saw and evaluated the patient. I agree with the findings and the plan of care as documented in the CRNP/PA's note  This is a 65-year-old male with multiple medical problems usually Who is known with chronic atrial fibrillation on Coumadin history of coronary artery disease on Plavix presented with bleeding abdominal wound. He has been followed up with primary care physician for his boil with started couple of months ago recently he had wound packed by his PCP because of mild bleeding then he started bleeding again when he came to the emergency department today evaluated by surgery and had wound packing and was discharged from the ED with a follow-up with his surgery in 2 days time his INR was elevated at 3.5 at the time and he was advised to hold Coumadin. His bleeding recurred after going home so patient came back to the emergency department and after discussing with the surgery he was placed on dressing and abdominal binder and subsequently admitted currently bleeding is stabilized on examination obese unable to examine the wound when dressing removed he has a coating of blood which was packed back again and abdominal binder was placed with which his bleeding has stopped.  A/p: Abdominal wall bleeding: c/w dressing and abdominal binder. Hold Coumadin and Plavix. Surgery follow-up

ae_narrative: I had been trying on multiple days to contact R.WAL to confirm her STEP 1 WEEK 10 appointment scheduled for Wednesday 12/20/17.  After several unsuccessful attempts I checked the medical records.  She went to the ER on 12/16/17 and was admitted for dehydration and general weakness.  This is a 69yo lady with PMHx of COPD, diastolic heart failure.  She had been asked by her doctors to reduce her fluid intake due to bilateral lower extremity edema.  She is augmenting 250mg Zoloft with 150mg Wellbutrin (we had recommended that she increase to 300mg but this was not implemented by her providers at MYCS due to their protocol that they typically meet with the patient prior to making medication changes).  I did reach out to the daughter-in-law today to extend our well wishes.  She is actually relieved that R.WAL is in the hospital to address some of the health issues she has been having.  They may consider transferring her to Presby from McKeesport as her cardiologist is at Presby.  Her daughter-in-law also said that they think R.WAL also may have an infection but have not identified the source.      Unless she is released this week I will be unable to do her Week 10 next week in person (she had done the toolbox at baseline).  I can still complete a phone call next week if she is discharged to home.      This is a serious adverse event, severe, unexpected, unrelated.  Dehydration is not listed as a side-effect of Wellbutrin.
ae_relevant_info: Upon further examination of the admission report, it appears she reported her symptoms started about a week ago with watery diarrhea with a frequency of 4-5 times per day.  She did not have any fall, syncope, or dizziness.  There was no evidence of organ failure.  AKI resolved with fluid therapy.  Diagnosis:  Given the history of diarrhea, response to fluid therapy,...the most likely cause (of progressive weakness & hypotension) is dehydration.  The most likely cause of diarrhea is viral gastroenteritis.  She was transferred to ICU for hypotension.  They plan to check for C. difficile & check stool for source of diarrhea.    She was discharged to home on 12/22/17 with home health care, PT & OT.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE
