ae_title: Fall with admission to ICU and later death
ae_narrative: Patient fell down 15 stairs breaking numerous bones and was admitted to the hospital/ICU. He does not report feeling dizzy and reports he did not lose consciousness. He crawled back into bed and family found him about 20 hours later there, bloodied.     UPDATE 11/13/17: we learned this morning that the patient died on 11/10/2017. He went into cardiac arrest twice that morning and was in respiratory distress. Family/POA decided on palliative care, he was extubated, and passed away. It was also newly noted in his records from 11/10 that the patient had brain trauma from the fall in addition to the broken bones: a left subarachnoid hemorrhage and bilateral intraventricular hemorrhage.  Our previous determination on whether this SAE was expected in terms of nature, frequency, and severity at time of initial report had been that it was expected, but having learned this additional information on 11/13/17, we now have determined that the event is unexpected in terms of severity and I have changed the response on this report.
ae_relevant_info: Patient has complained of orthostatic dizziness, which he has reported started prior to study onset. Patient has a pacemaker and is on blood thinners including a elaquis, aspirin and Plavix. Patient was evaluated for nutrition de    Injuries:   - Left subarachnoid hemorrhage, bilateral intraventricular hemorrhage   - C1: Acute fracture involving anterior arch, bilateral lamina    - C2: Acute type II dens fracture with 5 mm posterior displacement of the dens   - Fractures of the right lateral 2-5 ribs   - Fracture of the lateral left 6-9 ribs   - Fractures of the posterior 8-11 ribs   - Fractures of the posterior 6th, 7th, 8th, 9th, 10th ribs on the left.    - Acute nondisplaced extraforaminal fracture involving the right S1-S2 ala.   - Acute fracture involving mid right inferior ramus the right pubo-acetabular junction    DIAGNOSIS:   1. SAH with ventricular extension  2. cervical fx including C1 and type 2 dens  3. extensive rib fractures  4. hypoxic respritory failure s/p intubation  5. pelvic fractures    Visit Information   Death Summary Details:   Reason for admission: Fall, polytrauma.   Admit Date: 11/8/2017 .   Consult Services: Neurosurgery, Orthopedics.   Preliminary Cause of Death: Cardiac arrest.   Procedures: Bilateral chest tubes, intubation, R femoral central line.   Hospital Course: Hospital Course/Details: Patient is a 71-year-old gentleman, with history of COPD, heart failure with ejection fraction of 25% with pacer, who presented for hospital after sustaining a fall. Per history, it was said that the patient fell roughly 15 stairs. Upon arrival, the patient had significant polytrauma, which involved a left subarachnoid hemorrhage, bilateral intraventricular hemorrhage, C1 fracture, C2 dens fracture type II, numerous rib fractures both on the left and right sides, and a fracture to the right sacrum and a fracture involving the right inferior rami. In his course in the emergency department however the patient did have some difficulty breathing, and the patient was intubated for airway protection. The patient was also found to have aspiration pneumonitis as well on CT, and the patient was started on empiric antibiotics upon arrival to the ICU. In the ICU, the patient remained in stable condition, did not require vasopressors, however his mean arterial pressure was around 60-65. He remained stable overnight, however this morning at approximate 7 AM, the patient appeared to be agitated, and was in respiratory distress. He then became unresponsive, and had cardiac arrest. 5 minutes of CPR was performed, and ROSC was achieved however the patient rearrested later, and PEA, and after 2 rounds of epinephrine, we were able to achieve ROSC. During the arrest, bilateral chest tubes were placed for suspected pneumothorax. He continued to require high dose pressors, his respiratory status improved mildly. We contacted family to help with decision-making given injuries, age, and poor prognosis. Upon speaking with palliative care and their consultation, we collectively made agreed to make the patient comfort measures only. He was subsequently extubated, and expired on 12:09pm at 11/10/17.     .   Death Pronouncement (CTB) Information:   Date/Time of Death: 11/10/2017 12:09:00 PM .   Respiratory Breath Sounds: Absent.   Pupils: Fixed/Dilated.   Heart Sounds: Absent.

ae_narrative: Patient went to the hospital and was admitted, found to be in atrial fibrillation. Though recent EKGs were within safety range of the study and patient was not found to have atrial fibrillation at baseline, patient has a history of postoperative atrial fibrillation. Patient had recently stopped the lithium (last week) due to other side effects.
ae_relevant_info: DISCUSSION AND PLAN: The patient has symptomatic paroxysmal atrial  fibrillation with fast ventricular response. She was previously on  antiarrhythmic therapy. We will restart IV and p.o. amiodarone. We will  give amiodarone bolus and continue drip at 1 mg q. 6 hours and then  decreased per protocol. I would like to use diltiazem for rate control and  start Cardizem 30 mg p.o. 4 times a day. Discontinue Norvasc and  propranolol for now. In view of recurrent atrial fibrillation and  borderline troponin, we will restart IV heparin. The patient has prior  history of GI bleeding and will need to be watched. She is on Pepcid for  GI protection. Continue enteric-coated aspirin. Would recheck CK-MB and  troponin. The patient did have nuclear stress test in 2016, which showed  no evidence of ischemia or scar. Depending on further cardiac enzymes and  hospital course, we will decide if further workup is required.     Thank you for allowing us to participate in taking care of this patient and  we will continue to follow her along with you. I discussed this case with  Geriatric team in details.

The humeral head arthroplasty appears intact without   peri-hardware lucency. Bones are osteopenic.     IMPRESSION  1.  New mildly displaced acromial fracture.  2.  Chronic osseous remodeling of the osseous glenoid and   posterosuperior subluxation of the humeral head arthroplasty.  3.  The humeral head arthroplasty itself appears intact. ae_relevant_info: Hospital Course      Judith Arnowitz's symptoms of anxiety and depression are stable and well controlled on her current medication regimen.     Ms. Arnowitz is a 79 year old female with complex PMHx including HTN, Afib on amio and eliquis, depression/anxiety, osteoporosis, lumbar spondylosis, prior R subcapital proximal femoral fracture post screw fixation who presented with uncontrolled pain following a recent fall with multiple pelvic fractures. She sufferred multiple fractures (superior and inferior rami, ventral right and left sacral ala) from a fall ~3/31, seen in the ED at that time and discharged home. She had very limited miobility upon returning home due to poorly controlled pain, was completely reliant on her son for all tasks. Her PCP added a fentanyl patch to her chronic pain regimen, but she still was unable to function so she returned to the hospital for pain controlled. CT pelvis in the ED showed mulitple nondisplaced fractures as above as well as severe osteoporosis. No other new symptoms on presentation, still with right elbow pain from the same fall that was improving. Her fentanyl patch dose was increased from 12.5 to 25 mcg/hr and oxycodone frequency was increased from 10mg Q8H to 10mg Q4H. Full regimen below. This resulted in adequate analgesia. Seen by chronic pain team while here who agreed with plan. She worked with PT/OT while here, demonstrated skilled needs for both. She continued to have regular bowel movements on her bowel regimen. She was discharged to SNF for rehab in stable condition.     Individual issues upon discharge:     #Pelvic fractures  From fall sustained 3/31 with multiple nondisplaced fractures- uperior and inferior rami, ventral right and left sacral ala. In the setting of osteoporosis.  -Pain control  -Acetaminophen 1000mg Q8H  -Cont venlafaxine 75mg daily  -Lidocaine patch to low back  -Oxycodone 10mg Q4H PRN; continue at this dose for 5 days      -She can return to previous home dose (10mg Q8H PRN) after 5 days  -Fentanyl patch 25 mcg daily  -Chronic pain consulted, appreciate assistance  -Bowel reg: senna 2 tabs BID, miralax BID, fibercon; having BMs regularly  -Continue PT/OT at SNF; ok to ambulate  -No need for surgical involvement at this point given nondisplaced fractures     #Osteoporosis  -Osteoporosis treatment; last DXA 2015 with osteoporosis, osteoporosis noted on imaging  -Continue vitamin D,       -should supplement Ca if dietary intake inadequate  -Patient has been on and off zoledronic acid since 2008 - 2016; complicated by ?jaw osteonecrosis at some point circa 2008, also has a history of GERD, UGIB; nasal calcitonin was considered but not pursued      -Probably can restart bisphosphonate outpatient; follow up with PCP regarding this      -Can consider other agents (teriperitide, denosumab) if absolutely unable to use bisphosphonates    #Recent fall  Pt is unable to give a clear description of events, no clear mechanical cause or pre-syncopal prodome. Recent TTE 11/2017 without evidence of outlet obstruction. Numerous CNS depressing medications increase her risk. Vision has been gradually deteriorating from macular degeneration. EKG 4/4 NSR.  -Unable to tolerate orthostatic VS here; would repeat at outpatient follow up  -Outpatient providers are well aware of her fall risk and numerous sedating meds, working on titrating down  -Vision evaluation if needed    CT pelvis without contrast 4/4/18     IMPRESSION:  1. Acute minimally displaced right superior and inferior rami   fractures.  2. Acute near anatomically aligned fractures involving the ventral   right and left sacral ala.  3. Osteopenia.  4. Severe right greater than left bilateral hip osteoarthritis.   Healed right subcapital proximal femoral fracture post screw   fixation. Fracture has healed with mild impaction.  5. Low lumbar scoliosis and spondylosis.        XR R elbow 3/31/18     IMPRESSION:     1.  Osteopenia. No acute fracture or dislocation.  2.  Chondrocalcinosis.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: We learned yesterday that our patient called her PCP complaining of unsteadiness with increased frequency of falling:    'Patient called stating that she is falling. States when she stands up she has tremors and her body is like 'a leaf in the wind'. States she is having trouble thinking and writing and is having trouble with her speech. States this has been going on for the last 2 days. C/O constipation for the last few days.'    She was instructed to go to the ER and was admitted to Montefiore hospital. Here is a summary of their evaluation:    'Assessment and Plan   Diagnosis: Falls (ICD10-CM W19.XXXA, Working, Diagnosis), Erythema of lower extremity (ICD10-CM L53.9, Working, Diagnosis).      Patient is a 63 YO F with h/o IDDM, CKD (BL 1.5 - 1.7), gastric bypass surgery, depression, OSA, and recurrent falls presenting with increased fall frequency over past 5 days.     #Increased frequency of falls: She does have a history of falls that is likely related to her deconditioning + significant peripheral neuropathy. Her frequency, however, has increased over the past few days. The falls do not seem to be related to the classical syncope or pre-syncope symptoms, except for some dizziness when standing sometimes. She thinks her falls are more likely related to her generalized weakness and 'feeling off'. Neuro exam in non focal. EKG was normal. No signs of structural heart disease. She does have a very significant medication list with many psychiatric meds and also some opioids that could be contributing. High suspicion the etiology of these falls is multifactorial with worsening neuropathy, overmedication, and deconditioning to blame. Will need to rule out orthostatic changes.  -Performed medication reconciliation and patient reports she has been tapering the MS contin - will discontinue this and just continue the oxy for chronic pain  -Check a set of orthostatic vital signs  -TSH is normal. Checking B12/folate and vitamin D  -PT/OT'
ae_relevant_info: Normal EKG, continuing to evaluate.

ae_narrative: Patient presented to the ER with chest pain and high blood pressure. After a full evaluation and 20 hours of observation this was determined not to be a cardiac event. It sounds like the most likely explanation is a panic attack possibly brought on by racing/irregular heart beats.  She was not admitted to the hospital. She was safely discharged home after no more events over 20 hours of observation, so it appears to have been resolved. We don't believe this likely panic attack to be related to the study medication.
ae_relevant_info: CHIEF COMPLAINT: Chest pain     HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: 64-year-old woman with past medical history of hypertension, diabetes, anxiety, depression who presents to the emergency department with chest pain. Patient was scheduled to have eye surgery today. Initially, was noted to be hypertensive with a systolic blood pressure around 200. After that, developed left-sided chest pressure. She states she has been having this chest pressure since last evening, with some associated shortness of breath. She states that she attempted to take her antihypertensives this morning, but was nothing by mouth for surgery, and vomited them up. She states she has been having intermittent episodes of nausea and vomiting since last weekend, when she struck her head on a cabinet. She was seen and evaluated, had a negative head CT, and was diagnosed with a postconcussive syndrome. States she does have a prior history of concussion.  She denies fevers, chills, productive cough, diaphoresis, abdominal pain, changes in appetite, changes in bowel or bladder habits, focal neurologic complaints.   PHYSICAL EXAM: Vital Signs reviewed nurse's note   PATENT STATUS: alert and comfortable   HEAD: atraumatic, normocephalic   EYES: PERRL, EOMI. No conjunctival injection or exudate   THROAT: Airway Patent. Mucous membrane pink and moist. No oral mucosal lesions. No pharyngeal inflammation, exudate or tonsillar hypertrophy.   NECK: Supple with FROM. No palpation tenderness or lymphadenopathy.   LUNGS: Respirations unlabored with good air entry bilaterally. Breath sounds clear without stridor, wheezing or crackles.   HEART: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmur, gallop or rub.   ABDOMEN: Non-distended with active bowel sounds. No tenderness, rebound or guarding. No hepatosplenomegaly or mass.   SKIN: Warm, dry, without rashes   MUSCULOSKELETAL: Extremities are symmetrical, FROM, without tenderness or edema   NEUROLOGICAL: Alert and oriented. Cranial nerves intact. Motor and sensory   functions intact.      DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES:           Per my interpretation:  Electrocardiogram (ECG)  RATE:  83  RHYTHM:  Sinus with PACs  AXIS:  left  INTERVALS:  QTc 444  ST-T WAVE CHANGES: No elevation, poor baseline, poor R wave progression  ABNORMALITIES/COMPARISON: No acute ischemia               Impression and Plan      MEDICAL DECISION MAKING: 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with the above complaint. Initially, was hypertensive with a systolic blood pressure of 180. However, did improve spontaneously to the 160s. She did receive aspirin and nitroglycerin prior to arrival. She remained chest pain-free while in the emergency department. Her initial troponin is negative. Given her risk factors, will be placed in the CDU overnight for cardiac monitoring as well as serial troponins.      CDU plan: Serial troponins, cardiac monitoring     DIAGNOSIS: Chest pain      DISPOSITION: To the CDU     CLINICAL COURSE IN THE UNIT (CDU):  Patient denies any acute events overnight. Was placed in observation for evaluation of intermittent chest discomfort and hypertension. Patient states that these episodes chest discomfort are sudden, left-sided, brief and associated with anxiety. They have been ongoing for the past one week. While in observation, blood pressure has improved. She has had additional one or 2 episodes of chest discomfort per troponins have remained negative. EKG appears unchanged. No acute events on cardiac monitoring. Overall, unclear etiology to explain the patient's discomfort, does not appear from ACS. Patient strongly encouraged follow-up primary care physician. It is possible that the patient is having occasional PAC causing her discomfort which then causes anxiety. Can, she is symptom-free for evaluation this morning and has had no acute events on cardiac monitoring. Believe she can be safely discharged home     OBSERVATION LENGTH of TIME: 20 hours

ae_narrative: Received call from CW on 4/3/18.  She is on 300mg Effexor (increased from 150 on 1/28/18) and 7.5mg Abilify (since 12/20/17).  Has appointment with Ari Gildengers, MD at BGC on Friday 4/6/18 @ 11:00AM (Ari, I am cc'ing you as a head's up).  She reports that for the past 4 weeks with progressing intensity, that she is experiencing inner restlessness.  She describes this as an inability to sit still (she denied motor akathesia).  Recently her husband commented that she is fidgety (tapping foot constantly).  She did not mind this feeling as much when it was only present during the day as she was able to accomplish more.  However, it is also occurring in the evening when she would like to relax but cannot.  It has starting impacting her sleep which is now reduced (if fact she started the phone call with 'I can't sleep, it is almost as if I were a child with ADHD).   She is curious as to whether it could be the Effexor increase or the Abilify that is contributing to this symptom?  If you have any recommendations for her prior to her appointment with Ari on Friday please let me know and I will convey this to her.    THIS SOUNDS LIKE AKATHISIA.  PLEASE HAVE HER NOT TAKE THE ABILIFY TODAY (OR IF SHE ALREADY TOOK IT, DON'T TAKE IT TOMORROW).  THEN DECREASE THE DOSE TO 5 MG/DAY.
ae_relevant_info: She decreased abilify to 5mg on 4/6/18 and symptoms resolved.

ae_narrative: On 7/30/18 pt called to state that since January after she increased her dose of Effexor to 300mg (150mg capsule BID) she has been experiencing bothersome dry mouth.  She has been using Biotene since February but this symptom has become progressively worse and not something she is willing tolerate anymore.  She has recently seen a dentist and it sounds as if the dentist suggested her dry mouth was medication related.  She would be willing to reduce her dose of Effexor or perhaps switch to a med that would be less likely to cause dry mouth.  She did mention that one reason why the dry mouth is so bothersome is that she needs to open her mouth more and then move her jaw side-to-side.
ae_relevant_info: Thought was that dry mouth was related to Effexor (non-study med) and recommendation was to decrease dose from 300mg to 225mg.      On 10/16/18 she called to report that since starting Wellbutrin 150mg on 10/11/18 dry mouth has worsened to the point that she went to the ER on 10/14/18.  She does have a history of Thrush.  She was told to use warm salt water rinses and was given a prescription on Nystatin.  She stopped taking Wellbutrin on 10/15/18 and is planning to reduce dose of Effexor as well.      On 1/23/2019 at S1C12M she reported continuing bothersome dry mouth.  Her antidepressant has changed from Effexor to Prozac in November 2018.  It is unlikely related to medications but that is still a possibility.

Rick is concerned that the increase in BP could be due to NTP.  I said we will keep an eye on it and I will check back with him next week as he is scheduled to increase to 50mg NTP on Monday.   I DON'T THINK IT IS RELATED TO THE NTP.  On 5/11/18:  He did see his PCP this week due to issues with his BP which was elevated but also seems like he is having increased HR. ae_narrative: At WK 6 on 1/24 he reported shakiness in both hands for the past two weeks.  Describes it as more of a jolt/twitching when doing fine motor movements.  It is daily throughout the day, bothersome, and impacts functioning somewhat (dropping things, etc).  Plan was to alternate 600mg with 300mg Lithium qod.  At WK 8 on 2/7/18 he says the shakiness has gotten worse.  Plan is to stop Lithium for 2 nights, and then take 300mg over the weekend with a follow-up on Monday 2/12 and repeat Lithium levels next week.   ON 2/12/18, pt said that shakiness stopped on the days when he did not take Lithium but then started again when he took 300mg over the weekend (shakiness wasn't as bad but still not tolerable).  ON 2/12/18 Dr. Karp said 'No lithium for the rest of the week'.  JMK will check in on him on Friday, and then we can decide.

Pt admitted to UPMC Medical Hospital on 2/14/18 for 1month of tremor and more recently SOB, cough, disorientation secondary to acute exacerbation of COPD and pneumonia.  Of note, we knew about the tremor as he has been reporting this as a side-effect and for which we made adjustments to his Lithium dose and finally told him on 2/12/18 to discontinue taking.  I was to check-in with him on 2/16/18 to see how the tremor was since stopping Lithium.  When I couldn't reach him, which was unusual, I looked in the medical records and saw that he had been admitted.  As there was some reference in the admission reports about Lithium toxicity, Dr. Karp clarified with the inpatient psychiatric resident that this patient's lithium level has always been within therapeutic range, and that the team d/ced it on Monday 2/12/18 because of tremor, but his mental status at all phone calls with the OPTIMUM team have been clear.  Mental status change was not a problem prior to acute infection and low O2 stats resulting in his presentation to the ER on 2/14/18.  He was discharged to home on 2/23/18.  Event is possibly related, severe, expected.
ae_relevant_info: The week 10 call was due on 2/21/18 but was delayed due to hospitalization at UPMC Presby from 2/14/18 to 2/23/18.    His daughter's took him to the ER after he had had 3 falls within a short period of time (received some minor bruises, and continues to have some subsequent pain).  He does not drink alcohol.    Hospital Course   Admitted from: from emergency department.     Transferred via: by car.     Admitting diagnosis: Right lower lobe pneumonia (ICD10-CM J18.1, Working, Diagnosis).     Admission disposition: admit to ICU.     Length of stay: days  9.     Mr DH is a 65 yo WDM with a pmhx of DM, COPD (no home O2), OSA (CPAP @ 10), bladder ca in remissio, active smoker who presented with 1 month history of worsening SOB, dizziness, and tremors, most likely d/t COPD exacerbation with R>L LL pneumonia and Li toxicity. He was originally requiring 15L NC in ED, so was admitted to MICU for further care. In MICU, he was covered with unasyn and azithro for RLL, LLL PNA (?aspiration), as well as steroids for COPD exac. He was weaned down to 10L NC,  Despite low Li levels, his tremors persisted. CTH was negative. Originally had mild AKI that resolved with fluids.  tx to 10 D 2/15/16  using his home cpap unit - increased pressure to 14 cmH2O and patient tolerating well.   continued on antibiotics  psychiatry consulted - celexa 20 mg daily   cardiopulmonary rehab    Requip started for RLS with improvement of symptoms.    2/22/18 pt went into atrial fibrillation with a controlled rate, at night his heart rate was decreased into the 40s, but when awake during the day 2/22/18 atrial fib with a heart rate 70-105   started 12.5 mg bid lopressor => heart rate was in the 40 around 8 pm and pt did not receive evening dose of lopressor on 2/23/18   cardiology consulted - no need for rate controlling meds, agree with anticoagulation   pt for discharge to home today 2/23/18   Per medical records, discharge also stated:  'atrial fibrillation with slow ventricular response. Based on this patients' atrial fibrillation onset and course, it is most likely paroxsysmal afib.   Etiology is hard to determine at this time, however hx of OSA may be associated.  Patient's hx of Lithium may also explain why he has slowed ventricular response.'    Medical records also list delirium d/t multiple etiologies as he was having visual hallucinations and confusion.       During our phone call on 2/26/18, he stated that 'the doctors at the hospital feel he should have never been on Lithium in the first place and that was the cause of a lot of his symptoms due to toxicity'.  I did clarify with him that his levels were never above the normal limits.  Regardless he is glad that he discontinued Lithium on 2/12/18.  He continues to take 20mg Celexa.

ae_title: Medical Hospitalization d/t hypotension & acute delirium
ae_narrative: UP10070 has been admitted to the hospital on 3/13/18.  Presented from PCP's office for hypotension with relative hypoxia in the setting of 3 days of productive cough and visual hallucinations with increased tremors.  Found to have AKI and hyperkalemia.  Behavioral health consult feels presentation is consistent with acute delirium, likely multifactorial.  Report reiterates 'it is unlikely that past lithium use is contributing to current delirium or tremors, as his last reported use of lithium was 2/10/18 and his lithium level was not detectable on admission labs.'  He recently entered STEP 2 CONTINUATION on 2/26/18 and had been hospitalized from 2/14/18 to 2/23/18 for pneumonia and similar symptoms as current admission.
ae_relevant_info: Hx for similar presentation 2/14/18 to 2/23/18.    Pre-morbid history of COPD  Discharged on 3/19/18 to a SNF (hypotension resolved w/ IVF, likely related to dehydration; tremor/hallucinations improved, suspected to be related to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy, recommended to stop requip as this is know to cause hallucinations but pt is unwilling; AKI resolved suspected to be pre-renal secondary to dehydration as creatinine improved with IVF).
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

Making   Patient is an 87-year-old female who presents to the emergency room after a fall. Patient was evaluated by myself, vital signs are normal. Patient's ordered head CT. Patient was also ordered laboratory testing, CBC, BMP and troponin. Patient's was ordered EKG due to dizziness and 2 falls. Case is discussed with Dr. Wilson.     EKG was completed and shows normal sinus rhythm with PACs. Patient's laboratory testing was completed and reviewed. It is unremarkable for any acute process. Patient negative troponin. Patient had creatinine at her baseline 1.38. Patient's head CT was completed was negative. Patient's laceration will need to be stapled closed. Patient was able to get up and ambulate with mild difficulty. Patient has a walker at home so she'll be using it. Patient wants to be discharged home and I feel that is reasonable plan. Patient was informed of wound care instructions as well as monitoring wound for signs of infection. Patient was advised follow up with PCP. Patient was advised if she continues to have fall she is to return to the emergency room for further evaluation. Patient discharged in stable condition with the husband and son.     Patient is discharged with head injury, fall, scalp laceration.Patient was advised to follow-up with her PCP in the next 3-5 days for reevaluation of symptoms. Patient was advised to return to the emergency room with any new or worsening symptoms. Patient verbalized understanding of instructions and is agreeable to treatment plan. Patient was given a copy of her discharge instructions along with follow-up information. Patient was discharged in stable condition with no further questions.     LACERATION REPAIR:  Patient, procedure, and site were verified immediately before the procedure.  Appropriate neurovascular exam was performed to test sensation, motor function and perfusion.   [The skin around the wound was prepped with Betadine.]  Anesthesia was provided using 1% lidocaine without epinephrine.  Wound was irrigated with a copious amount of [saline].  Wound was explored to its base. [There was no visible foreign body in the wound.]  The laceration was repaired by means of a [single] layer closure. [Skin] was closed with [3 staples]    Total wound length was [2] cm.  [Good hemostasis and cosmetic result.]  Patient tolerated the procedure well.   [Wound was dressed with bacitracin and gauze].                  Impression and Plan   Diagnosis:  Fall  Scalp laceration  Head injury.    Plan:  Discharge.    Discharge Status:  Stable at discharge.

ae_narrative: Please see clinical notes.  On 12/28/17 staff spoke with C.STE.  She was very distraught stating she was having vivid dreams, feeling very anxious, and angry.  Dr. Karp felt this was related to discontinuation of Cymbalta & worsening of her depression.  He instructed her to restart 30mg Cymbalta (taking 1/2 capsule of 60mg) x 1 week, then every other day x1 week, then stop.  As of 1/2/18 she was feeling much better.
ae_relevant_info: Dr. Karp attempted a slower taper but she could not tolerate discontinuation so she was restarted on original dose of index med (60mg Cymbalta) on 1/26/18.  By the WK 6 appointment on 2/1/18 all symptoms reported from discontinuation were gone.
ae_action_other: Cymbalta was restarted for slower taper

ae_narrative: On the week 2 call on 1/5/18, she reported that on some morning (not every morning) she feels very anxious/jittery.  She states this will dissipate once she gets started about her day.  She does not experience this at other times during the day.  She is unsure whether this is related to the taper from Cymbalta or to the Wellbutrin.
ae_relevant_info: Update:  on 1/19/18 at the Week 4 visit she reports that this has continued and is daily.  I am changing severity from mild to moderate as it does impact functioning.  She says that it typically happens @ 2-4hrs after she has taken Wellbutrin in the morning.  She is uncertain whether she would like to continue Wellbutrin.    Update:  on 4/18/18 she called to say that she is no longer having any side-effects (no anxiety/jitteriness)
ae_action_other: No change to Wellbutrin dose of 300mg on 1/19/18

ae_narrative: Reports feeling nauseous about 2-4hrs after taking Wellbutrin for the past week.    On 2/1/18 she reports nausea is gone.  Of note she had restarted Cymbalta on 1/26/18 and is now not sure if nausea was related to discontinuation of Cymbalta or to Wellbutrin.

At week 10 she reported a mild intentional tremor in her hands (left>right) which started a few weeks ago.      Update, she called on 4/18/18.  Said she is no longer having any side-effects (no more tremor)

ae_narrative: She recently completed inpatient rehabilitation from May 22, 2018 to June 19, 2018 for alcohol, opioid, and benzodiazepine dependence. She was never taking medication that was not prescribed to her. She was only taking her medication. She tried to take herself off of her Norco, but as she did this she replaced the Norco with alcohol. She continued to take the benzodiazepine with alcohol. On a Monday, she drank so much alcohol that she blacked out. She woke up Tuesday with a black eye and a broken toe. She went to the emergency department, where she was given oxycodone. She went to work the next day and was ordered to complete a breathalyzer. She states that she blew 0.01. She was ordered that she needed to complete rehab
ae_relevant_info: During the course of participation she did not report misusing any of her prescribed medications of either Norco or Ativan (taking 3 tabs of 0.5mg qhs for sleep).  Towards the end of STEP 1 she did mention that she felt Norco wasn't necessary anymore and was going to try to stop taking it.  Also during the course of participation she acknowledged that due to her gastric bypass she needed to be careful about alcohol intake and would limit alcohol to a max of 2 drinks which was infrequent.   During the course of participation she only reported 2 drinks at Week 2 and denied alcohol use during the other decision support calls.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: At STEP 1 END on 5/15/18 during an in person visit she reported @ 2 months ago a increase in tremor (she has a history of benign essential tremor more prominent left than right, now is progressing to right side).  At the moment mild and manageable.  Could possibly be related although more likely progression of essential tremor.  She is not on meds for it yet and may try to speak with her PCP soon about it.  Of note when she was doing the pegboard task and concentrating on hand motion, essential tremor was visible in her head).    Essential tremor was visible to the clinician particularly in her left hand.
ae_relevant_info: PMHx of benign essential tremor    ONGOING AT STUDY COMPLETION.    At S1C12M on 5/17/19:  She has noticeable essential tremor and she feels propranolol 40mg has not been helpful in controlling her tremor.    On 6/9/2020:  Spoke to her today for ONSS.  She mentioned something that she was interested in your thoughts.  She had premorbid essential tremor that was at first only with intention.  Now tremor is resting, both hands, legs, head, mouth & jaw.  Sees a neurologist who suggested worsening tremor may be related to her antidepressant medications (completed OPTIMUM in May 2019 on 40mg Prozac & 450mg Wellbutrin), at that time was very off balance with frequent falls, found to be B12 deficient, received injects, balance or falls are no longer an issue).  Per neurologists encouragement she tapered and stopped both Prozac and Wellbutrin about 3 months ago.  She reports her mood is stable, tremor has improved somewhat.  She was taking for essential tremor both propranolol and primidone but also discontinued those.  I recommended making appointment with neurologist to ask about restarting medications for tremor.  She mentioned that neurologist is considering Parkinson's among the differential.    Her question is should she need to restart an antidepressant, is there one you could suggest that would be least likely to contribute to tremor?    I am scheduled to complete ONSS Baseline with her on 6/22.  I am cc'ing OPTIMUM NEURO as she has 24M ON scheduled for next week. At week 4 on 6/6/18 and again when she called on 6/15/18 she reported an increased lack of emotion 'I just don't care @ anything'.  This has impacted motivation to even do basic ADLs & household chores like brushing her teeth, making the bed, etc.  In addition, she has reported some increased agitation again (new within the past 2 weeks where she has been more easily irritated).  She had reported the irritability during step 1 acute on wellbutrin and is reporting it again on Lithium.  Rather than change the previous AE, it seems appropriate to consider her current symptoms as generalized worsening of depression.      In fact, at her Step 2 Month 4 call on 11/14/18 she again reported an 'uncomfortable and bothersome' sense of apathy.  She states that for the past couple months she has no interest in anything at all, even the simplest of tasks.  This is an anxious uncomfortable feeling.  She has difficulty concentrating and feels spaced out.  'I don't feel right....I don't feel like I am living'.   This is bothersome to the point where she feels she needs to do something about it.  She feels that this could be a side-effect of Abilify and is wondering if she should reduce her dose or stop taking it all together.  Her hesitation is that she no longer feels that deep sorrow/depression but said that she is just not thinking that way...'actually not thinking about much at all'.     Considering that she has reported this even prior to starting Abilify, this is not related as a side-effect to her medications.
ae_relevant_info: As of 7/5/18 she is Currently augmenting 20mg Celexa with 2mg Abilify.  Feels great!  Denies side-effects,

She is taking 60mg Cymbalta & 300mg Wellbutrin.  She wanted us to know that she saw her ENT on 3/22/18 for low-pitched tinnitus (bilateral) which is associated with reduced hearing and some pressure in the ears.  She also reported to them some episodes of mild dizziness yesterday and today.  She was prescribed high dose prednisone taper (60mg x9d, 50 x1d, 40 x1d, 30 x1d, 20 x1d, 10 x1d).  Apparently this has resulted in elevated blood glucose (she does have DM Type I).  She read that prednisone and Wellbutrin could have possible interactions and wanted to let us be aware of this med change.    1)	This is not the first person on Wellbutrin who has reported some type of 'ringing, humming' in their ears.  Is tinnitus related to Wellbutrin?  If not AE will be reported as not related, mild, unexpected.  It is not a 'listed' side-effect and she did not report it as a side-effect.    2)	Is there a contraindication of Wellbutrin and Prednisone?
ae_relevant_info: 4/16/18:  JMK changed severity from mild to moderate.  She does have some bilateral hearing loss associated with the tinnitus (ambient noise/humming) in both ears. At WK 10 on 4/25/18 she reported that last Thursday (4/19/18) she saw the ENT again and received another steroid injection in both ears.  She feels that the background noise 'roar' has lessened and her hearing is starting to improve.  She continues on 40mg prednisone daily. ae_narrative: Update 9/5/19: patient was discharged from hospital on 8/29/19. She will continue hemodialysis 3 days/week for the kidney inury, outpatient Hepatitis C treatment for the liver problems, and plan to follow-up at a walk-in clinic for hopefully inpatient rehab for opioid use disorder.    I spoke with patient briefly attempting to schedule Step 2 Continuation 12 month on 8/9/19, which patient declined, noting she intended to go to rehab on Monday, 8/13/19, and that her friend was with her. On 8/12/19, she had a relapse of heroin use along with crack cocaine. Use continued to the next morning, when she was found unresponsive by her friend, who administered narcan. Patient was transported to the ER and admitted for the overdose and treatment of sequelae including kidney injury and liver imbalance. It is unclear at this time if this was a suicide attempt. ER suspected possible tylenol OD as well due to liver imbalances, but acetaminophen/tylenol levels came back negative. Patient is noted as having been abusing alcohol for some time (1 bottle of wine per day). Hospitalization is ongoing as of 8/16/19.
ae_relevant_info: Patient has history of alcohol and IV drug abuse, which was noted as in remission during Acute study participation, but alcohol use was increasing and near full relapse at Step 2 continuation 8 month. We provided the following PCP update at that visit:  She reports her alcohol use has increased since we last spoke though, which may explain why the dose increase at last visit has not provided benefit to her. She reports drinking about 3 glasses of wine per day to cope with depressive and anxiety symptoms. Twenty-one drinks per week is in the moderate-high risk category, especially considering this patient's history of drug abuse. I educated the patient on the effects of alcohol on depression, including that since it is a depressant it can directly worsen symptoms and that it may interfere with treatment response to antidepressants like Lexapro. I encouraged her strongly to reduce her use. She said she'd 'taken to heart' this advice and would be willing to cut back.     Dr. Gebara and I have communicated the following plan to the patient to address her alcohol use and depression:  1) Continue or re-establish NA meeting attendance  2) Reduce current alcohol use to 7 drinks per week or less  3) We've provided referral to a therapist who specializes in depression and alcohol/drug abuse in seniors, Taffie Bucci 412-453-3127, who can provide assistance and support in this effort.  4) We will plan to check in with her in 2-4 weeks by phone, and if she has cut back her alcohol use and still remains depressed, we will recommend augmenting her Lexapro with aripiprazole 2 mg at that time.  I followed up with the patient the following day (5/2/19) to provide these instructions. I was unable to reach the patient for the planned extra visit (she has been chronically difficult to reach/schedule since entry in continuation).    Inpatient evaluation:  Basic Information   Visit Information:  Patient seen on 8/13/2019.       Chief Complaint   Heroin Overdose      History of Present Illness   61yo female w/ Hx of reactive arthritis, HCV, alcohol abuse, and polysubstance abuse (heroin and crack) who presented to the ED following heroin overdose and loss of consciousness. Patient reported that she snorted a bag of heroin last night and went to sleep feeling completely at baseline. She woke up today and her roommate brought her another bag of heroin, which they both injected at 10am. She was then reportedly found unresponsive by her friend, in the afternoon, who administered her Narcan and called EMS. She recalls EMS arriving and reports refusing initially to report to the ED but was eventually amendable to the transport. She reports a similar previous episode where she overdosed on heroin back in june 2017 and was taken to Forbes Hospital, where she reports remained for several days under observation. Patient reports that she does not follow up regularly with her PCP and has not received treatment for HCV. She states that her HCV has resolved spontaneously. She reports no CP, SOB, abdominal pain, skin discolorations, tremors, headaches, lightheadedness, fever, wt loss, dysuria, diarrhea, hemoptysis or hematemsis. She does endorse n/v which she reports started after she was administered Narcan.      Of note, patient reports a hx of a mechanical fall 2 weeks ago where she tripped on her cat after snorting heroin. She reports that she fell, hit her head and hurt her neck as well. Since then she has experienced head and neck pain which have persisted and worsened today. She denies any weakness, numbness, tingling, urinary or fecal incontinence.      On arrival to the ED, patient's vitals were remarkable for temp 37.1, HR 74, BP 105/71 and saturating 97% on RA. Initial work up was remarkable for transaminitis w/ ALT >5000 and AST> 10000, hyperkalemia (K 5.2), elevated Creatinine (2.1), lactic acidosis (lactate 2.3) and AG metabolic acidosis (AG 15.4). BP continued to decrease to 80s/50s. EKG was remarkable for sinus bradycardia and left axis deviation. Pt had 1 blood streaked stool. Rectal exam showed several external hemorrhoids. No gross blood but she was hemoccult + which i suspect is related to hemorrhoids. Patient was given 2L crystalloids and administered N-acetylcysteine for possible acetaminophen toxicity. Toxicology screening labs including tylenol, salicylate, ethanol, and CPK as well as CT abdomen and pelvis were ordered and patient was admitted to medicine for further workup.          Histories      Past Medical History   1.  Inflammatory arthritis:  Follows with Dr. Mary Wasko at West Penn Hospital.  2.  Depression  3.  History of Barrett's esophagus     Assessment and Plan   Diagnosis: Overdose (ICD10-CM T50.901A, Working, Diagnosis).      61yo F history of opioid polysubstance abuse, alcohol use disorder, HCV who presents after opioid overdose with acute liver injury, AKI, and rhabdomyolysis.     #Respiratory +/- metabolic acidosis  In setting of heroin overdose. S/p narcan in the field  - Respiratory status: RR10, satting 95% on 3L NC  - VBG 1AM: 7.21/54/37/19. Acute respiratory acidosis with inappropriate metabolic compensation i/s/o AKI vs. mixed acidosis   - Repeat VBG 6AM  - Mental status AAOx3, protecting airway. Denies SI/HI.  - Continue to monitor     #Acute liver injury  AST 10000 ALT 5000. Patient denies acetaminophen ingestion. First tylenol level at 5PM negative. Started on 20-hour NAC protocol in ED. Suspect other tox etiology vs. shock liver vs. less likely acute viral hepatitis. She has a history of chronic HCV that was spontaneously resolved according to chart review. INR 2.1, no asterixis, does not meet criteria for acute liver failure.  - Trend Q4hr LFTs/coags  - N-acetylcysteine per ED protocol   - Hep A IgM, Hep B sAg sAb cAb, Hep C Ab and viral load, HIV pending  - Consider tox consult in AM     #AKI  Cr 2.1, baseline <1. Suspect ATN 2/2 myoglobin pigment +/- pre-renal. Making urine. Expect improvement with fluid resuscitation.  - s/p 3L crystalloid in ED  - NS @ 100mL/hr     #Rhabdomyolysis  CPK 1900. Patient was found down for several hours.  - IVF as above  - CTM     #Hypotension  80s/50s in ED, improved to 90s/60s after fluid boluses, which appears to be her baseline pressure. Lactate was 2.3 on admission, now downtrended to 1.8, will CTM.     #Alcohol use disorder  Last drink was today. Consumes at least 1 bottle of wine daily + maybe beer and hard liquor.  - No tachycardia, tremors, diaphoresis at time of admission  - CIWA     Chronic issues:  Depression - holding home escitalopram 20mg in setting of concern for acute toxidrome and liver injury        #Access - PIV  #Lines - foley  #Diet - Regular  #PPx - INR >2   #Code - full  #Dispo - ICU      Professional Services   Credentials Title and Author     Credentials: MD.     Title: Resident.     Addendum by OKWIYA MD, VICTOR KYLE on August 16, 2019 11:25 AM:      I saw and evaluated Ms Ama, night of 8-13-19. 61 yo female admitted due to drug overdose with noted heroin. Cocaine metabolites also isolated from his urine. I agree with the findings and plan  of care as documented by Dr Tang - ICU HS. Crystalloid hydration w/follow up reno-metabolic data. I spent 34 minutes in critical care time. The details of that care have been noted above.

ae_narrative: DATE OF ADMISSION/SERVICE: 05/09/2019 22:05:00   DISCHARGE DATE: 05/10/2019 18:42:00   DEPT#/ROOM#/BED: JH5WEST 5145-01 PATIENT CLASS: O   HISTORY AND PHYSICAL     CC:   ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: ALAN DAVID BRAMOWITZ, MD     AHN - Jefferson Hospital    HISTORY AND PHYSICAL    DATE: 05/10/2019    HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 68-year-old woman who came to the hospital because of chest discomfort.     The patient states that she had nonexertional sharp pain in her precordial area, lasting for a number of hours. Because of symptoms, she came to the hospital. Also, she was worried because she felt that she had palpitations with extra heart beats.     The patient has a history of multiple sclerosis. She has no personal history of hypertension, diabetes, or knowledge of lipid abnormalities. She is not a smoker. There is no history of valvular heart disease or myocardial disease. There is no history of TIA, CVA, or claudication.     The patient states there is no family history of premature coronary artery disease. A brother was treated for coronary revascularization in his late 60s.    MEDICATIONS: The patient's home medications have included Xanax as needed, Ampyra 10 mg, Abilify 15 mg, atorvastatin 40 mg, Avonex 30 mcg/0.5 mL, , calcium, Tegretol, Flexeril 10 mg b.i.d., Relpax 40 mg daily, vitamin D 50,000 units once a week, Flonase 50 mcg, Neurontin 300 mg t.i.d., interferon is injected, Synthroid 0.075 mg daily, Provigil mg daily, vitamin D, Nexium, Paxil 40 mg, Restasis eye drops, VESIcare.     Additional history reveals the patient has had a plate placed in her low back. She has had carpal tunnel release, oophorectomy, and sinus surgery. She has also had past T and A. She has had past pneumonia. She has had surgery on her wrist. She is on thyroid replacement, has history of gastroesophageal reflux, history of depression, history of sleep apnea.    PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  GENERAL: Reveals a well-developed obese woman, who appears in no apparent distress.   VITAL SIGNS: Current vital signs include blood pressure of 110/70, heart rate 70.   HEENT: Negative.   NECK: No carotid bruits or jugular venous distention.   CHEST: Clear. Heart tones are normal. There are no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No chest wall tenderness.   EXTREMITIES: Free of edema, cyanosis, or clubbing.   NEUROLOGIC: Intact.    LABORATORY DATA: EKG is normal. Troponins are normal.    ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: The patient will have a Lexiscan stress study. If normal, I suspect that she will be discharged.

ae_narrative: Hospital Course   Mr. Salvati is a 71 Y/O M admitted after he had an episode of loss of consciousness at a baseball game. He says that he was sitting in the stands and it was very hot outside. He had a sudden urge to defecate, after which he blacked out. He says he slumped over in his seat per his wife. He does not remember how long he was out for, but did not have any weakness when he got back up again. No bladder or bowel incontinence. He went to the medical stand, where he had cold towels placed on his forehead. He continued to feel somewhat lightheaded until they let him go to the bathroom, after which he says he felt comfortable.     He had one similar episodes a few years ago when he was very sleepy, but none otherwise.     No fever, night sweats, weight loss/gain, headache, blurry vision, neck stiffness, chest pain, SOB, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria, LE pain, LE swelling.     His EKG in the ED showed a RBBB. Pt had echo today which showed enlarged left atrium.    With abnormal EKG and echo I did run the case by cardiology who did not think cardiac abnormalities were related to the syncopal event, but with RBB and ectopic atrial rhythm he could follow-up as outpt.  Given number for Dr. Generalovich.
ae_relevant_info: see narrative above

The side effect reportedly resolved after stopping the medicine, though patient has only been off the medicine for 10 days so it may be too early to tell. It's emergence and continuation happened months after the patient had tolerated the medicine without significant side effect and it continued despite decreasing the dose into ranges that were previously tolerated. Patient states on 7/13/18 her cat kitten were playing she went to stop them and went to the kitchen where there was a wet floor and slipped landing directly on her left hip. She went to the ER on 7/15/18 because of continued severe pain unresponsive to OTC meds. They did CTs/X-rays and nothing was broken. She was not admitted. They gave her some pain medication at the ER and told her to follow-up with her PCP. Patient reports the pain is interfering with her sleep - not sleeping at all.
ae_relevant_info: History of Present Illness        Patient is a 71-year-old female history of anxiety depression presenting with 2 days of significant discomfort to the left hip. Patient states 2 days ago her cat kitten were playing she went to stop them and went to the kitchen where there was a wet floor and slipped landing directly on her left hip. Patient states she did not lose consciousness she was able to get herself up and has noted persistent pain with everything to this left hip. She's been taking Tylenol no improvement. She's been very nauseated with this pain states feeling warm but no confirmed fever, chills or vomiting.     Radiology results   X-ray: X-ray of the lumbar hip and pelvis were obtainedThere is no evidence of any acute fracture or subluxation of the   visualized bones. The bony structures are intact. The bony   alignment is maintained. The joint spaces are preserved. The soft   tissues are unremarkable. No sclerotic or lytic lesion is identified.  IMPRESSION:  No evidence of any acute fracture or subluxation.    Medical Decision Making   Patient will receive some Tylenol in the emergency department she was still having considerable amount of discomfort with this hip as well as pain out of proportion. X-rays were unremarkable as identifying no fracture of the hip or pelvis. I didn't CT of the left hip and pelvis concern for an underlying fracture. Radiology reviewed the CT scan as negative. Patient did experience some relief of her symptoms with 2 mg of morphine I did add after review of the Pennsylvania drug database system 5, Percocet 5 mg tablets to be utilized for severe pain. Recommended she follow with her primary physician for physical therapy if this is not resolving. Patient is very comfortable with this plan she will use ice to the hip area continue with stretching   Impression and Plan   Diagnosis: Left hip contusion.   Plan: Discharge.   Discharge Status: Stable at discharge.

ae_narrative: UPDATE:  On 8/7/2019 The University of Pittsburgh IRB, after reviewing all of the information, concluded that this Reportable Event did not represent serious or continuing non-compliance in accordance with University of Pittsburgh policies or federal regulations, nor did it meet the definition of an unanticipated problem involving risk to subjects or others. This matter is now considered to be closed.    UP10132 called me today to tell me that she was experiencing shivering, body aches, and a racing heartbeat, as well as feeling hot (she was unaware if she had a temperature). She is taking wellbutrin 450mg and effexor 75mg (started 6 days ago), and said she believed the Effexor contributed to these symptoms, and because she seemed to be in fairly acute distress, I recommended that she be seen at the Emergency Department. She presented to the ED on 6/25 and was admitted with a working diagnosis of acute kidney injury, bradycardia and hypotension, and a 1st degree AV heart block was found on EKG. It is unknown whether the antidepressants she was taking contributed to her symptoms, and we are pursuing consultation from the pharmacy. The hospital team has advised her to discontinue the Effexor.    On 6/26/19 this participant died while in-patient due to cardiac arrest secondary to acute myocardial infarction.    Per consultation with a geriatric clinical pharmacist, the following information from literature and case review was provided.  There is a chance that venlafaxine may be associated with the patient's hypotension, but it's not very likely.  Patients in a previous study did not experience bradycardia nor did they experience a concomitant AKI.  In both the literature and case reports, the symptoms of increased venlafaxine exposure do not mimic the symptoms described by UP10132 who presented to the hospital with AKI, bradycardia, and hypotension.  Overall, although there is a chance that UP10132 could have experienced a paradoxical episode of hypotension secondary to venlafaxine, it's difficult to attribute the patient's complete presentation to her antidepressant therapy.

Pt called about 2:30p complaining about constant nausea since taking the bupropion at 5:30a on an empty stomach.  She also complained about sweating which was starting to subside and SOB which had subsided.  She denied vomiting and any other effects.  She had only managed to eat a few strawberries and some tea up to that point..  Dr. Karp was informed.  She is willing to try again Tuesday.  I suggested that taking the medication with food may decreased the nausea and reminded her that many sx's subside over time.

Took medication with food as directed, but continues to have nausea and some sweats.  She doesn't want to take any more bupropion.  Dr. Karp suspects she is having discontinuation sx's from the venlafaxine and instructed her to take one 150 venlafaxine, which she did.  I followed up with her a few hours later and she reported feeling less nauseated.  We will restart the venlafaxine at 150, taper to 75 and then 37.5 before restarting the bupropion.

Patient presented to ER on 7/1/19 with shortness of breath. She was diagnosed with a litany of health problems (including CHF, respiratory failure, emphysema) none of which appear to be related to study participation, especially since she returned to her index medication during Step 1 almost 1 year ago and has declined any of our treatment recommendations since.
ae_relevant_info: Basic Information   Visit Information:  Patient seen on 7/1/2019.       Chief Complaint   'I couldn't breathe'      History of Present Illness         86yF, hx of grade 2 diastolic CHF, atrial fib not on ac, prior cva/tia, hypothyroidism, copd, presents with progressive SOB/DOE/ found to have pulmonary edema likely 2/2 acute chf     Pt reports that she has had a terrible last few months. She attributes this to a change in her synthroid (200-> 175mcg) but this was recently reverted without much change in her sx's. She reports increased lethargy, feeling drained, fatigue. Outpt note from 6/20 says pt presented not eating, drinking, not brushing teeth. She was diagnosed w depression, dehydration, and hypotension (amlodipine and hctz/ triamterene stopped)       She reports over the last few days having progressive shortness of breath and wheezing. It has gotten to the point that she cannot walk from her bedroom to the restroom w/o having significant shortness of breath. This progressive of DOE started maybe 6 weeks ago but has progressed much more in the last 2-3 days. She reports orthopnea that is worse. Reports some edema in feet and ankles.      Denies fever, chills, n/v. She had 2 episodes of loose stools prior to admission.     In ED, per their note, she was given 'She was initially treated with methylprednisolone, albuterol, ipratropium prior to x-ray which showed evidence of pulmonary edema. BNP was elevated at 413 which is close to where was several days ago. We will treat for pulmonary edema and possible CHF. I'm unable to appreciate JVD or significant peripheral edema. Given the patient's hypertension, she was given 10 mg of hydralazine by mouth as well as 1 inch of Nitropaste. She will also be diuresed with Lasix'     After arrival to floor, pt developed episode of chest pressure and rapid afib with new st depressions in lateral leads.              Of interesting note; PCP's outpt note on 6/20 regarding her hypothyroidism (by Fiorillo, Anthony B, MD)  'Hypothyroidism with excessive replacement for the last 20 years I have struggled with this woman to get her to understand that she does not need to be over replaced.  In spite of that she is contributing her current situation to be under replaced in spite of me showing her clear physiologic data demonstrating over replacement even at 0.175 mg.  After much discussion with her daughter I agreed to increase her to 200 mcg and talk with her in 6 weeks.  I explained to her she can develop worsening osteoporosis cardiomyopathy arrhythmia and death related to excessive thyroid use.  Patient states she is fine but she would like to to return to her previous dose.  I agreed to do this out of the lack of any other methodology to see if I can improve her current condition.Hypothyroidism with excessive replacement for the last 20 years I have struggled with this woman to get her to understand that she does not need to be over replaced.  In spite of that she is contributing her current situation to be under replaced in spite of me showing her clear physiologic data demonstrating over replacement even at 0.175 mg.  After much discussion with her daughter I agreed to increase her to 200 mcg and talk with her in 6 weeks.  I explained to her she can develop worsening osteoporosis cardiomyopathy arrhythmia and death related to excessive thyroid use.  Patient states she is fine but she would like to to return to her previous dose.  I agreed to do this out of the lack of any other methodology to see if I can improve her current condition.'      Histories      Past Medical History   -hypothyroidism  -htn  -chronic sinusitis  -osteoporosis  -anxiety  -hld  -stenosis of carotid artery  -basal cell ca of nose  -afib  -emphyema/copd  -depression  -cva/tia      Past Surgical History   -right total hip  -cataract  -laminectomy  -shoulder surgery  -tonsils/adenoids      Family History   -cancer  -arthritis  -migraine      Social History   -quit smoking early 2000's  -denies etoh, drug use      Review of Systems      Positive: per HPI above     Constitutional:  denies fever, chills, weight loss.    Eye:  denies change in vision.    Ear/Nose/Mouth/Throat:  denies change in hearing.    Respiratory:  Denies apnea.    Cardiovascular:  Denies palpitations.    Gastrointestinal:  denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation.    Genitourinary:  Denies dysuria, hematuria.    Hematology/Lymphatics:  Denies swollen lymph glands in neck.    Musculoskeletal:  Denies new muscle pain.    Integumentary:  Denies new rash.    Neurologic:  Denies new focal weakness, numbness, tingling.    Psychiatric: Denies changes in mood          Allergies      Allergies          Voltaren-XR [hives];  diclofenac [hives];  sulfa drugs [lips swell];  ACE Inhibitors [swollen lips, face];  lisinopril [facial swelling]   Assessment and Plan   Diagnosis: Acute diastolic heart failure (ICD10-CM I50.31, Working, Diagnosis), Atrial fibrillation (ICD10-CM I48.91, Working, Diagnosis), Emphysema lung (ICD10-CM J43.9, Working, Diagnosis), GERD [Gastroesophageal reflux disease]. (ICD10-CM K21.9, Working, Problem), HTN (hypertension) (ICD10-CM I10, Working, Problem), Hypertension (ICD10-CM I10, Working, Diagnosis), Hypothyroidism (ICD10-CM E03.9, Working, Diagnosis).      86yF, hx of grade 2 diastolic CHF, atrial fib not on ac, prior cva/tia, hypothyroidism, copd, presents with progressive SOB/DOE/ found to have pulmonary edema likely 2/2 acute chf     # acute hypoxemic respiratory failure  -my impression of her sx's (worsening doe, orthopnea, leg edema, jvd) suggests more acute chf instead of copd  -she was given solumedrol in ED, i think at this time will hold further steroids/azithro as i think it would worsen her chf (can cause fluid retention, edema, rapid hr)  -only got 20mg iv lasix in ED w no response, gave 40mg on arrival and felt improvement  -will treat chf and follow breathing, if develops more wheezing (not impressive on my exam) would treat like acute copd as well     # acute diastolic chf  -pt not on duiretic or bb at home  -received 20mg iv lasix in ED, no response, gave 40mg iv on arrival w good response  -will order 40mg iv lasix for 8am one time dose, will need dosing adjustment base one renal fxn  -recent echo above  -it seems this past month PCP d/c'd her hctz, question if this led to slow fluid overload     # rapid atrial fib  -afib is old, not new  -was NSR on arrival but after being on floor x1-2 hrs developed rapid atrial fib with chest pressure (resolved after 10mg iv cardizem) and new st depressions in lateral seen  -called and discussed w cardio on call, who saw pt (many thanks, much appreciated), felt depressions rate related esp w negative trop  -gave 10mg iv bolus, started drip at 10/hr, now up to 15 with rate 100-110 and solid pressure  -previously not on AC, cardio overnight rec'd apixaban 5mg bid     # emphysema  -at this point will hold further steroids, think this is NOT an acute exacerbation. if mild wheezing does not improve w lasix would revisit acute copd dx again  -c/w home flovent bid  -for now w scheduled q6hr duonebs  -pft's in may not the most impressive, no obstructive pattern and no restrictive pattern; please see EPIC note by Dr Yee on 5/10 who did not feel her lungs accounted for the degree of her SOB     # hypothyroidism  -see PCP note in HPI  -will check TSH, suspect it will be low given PCP's note above and doubt we can get pt to lower her dose  -for now will give 200mcg as ordered     # depression/anxiety  -given PCP's note, suspect that pt's decline is in part due to depression and anxiety. it seems pt attributes her 'depressive' sx's to low thyroid  -for now c/w home ssri     # hld  -stable  -c/w home statin     # htn  -acceptable for now  -recently had amlodipine and Maxzide 37.5/25 mg d/c by pcp  -for monitor for now, wil discuss in AM best options, seems pt may need rate control agent and possible daily diuretic seems her sx's worsened after stopping maxzide     IV Fluids: none  DVT PPX: eliquis 5 bid afib  Diet: cardiac low salt 2l fluid restrict  Access/Lines/Tubes: piv   Mobility: oob  Disposition: admit, final cardio rec's, treat acute chf+atrial fib    Discharge Information   Discharge Summary:          Overnight events: None.         Admit Date: 7/1/2019.         Discharge Date: 7/9/2019.         Attending physician: GLIGORIJEVIC MD, NIKOLA.         Consulting physician: AIYER MD, ARYAN N.         Consult Services: Cardiology .         Reason for admission: Pulmonary edema .         Discharge diagnosis: Atrial fibrillation (ICD10-CM I48.91, Discharge, Diagnosis), Acute diastolic heart failure (ICD10-CM I50.31, Discharge, Diagnosis).         Patient and family discussions: Yes.       Hospital Course      Patient is 86 y/o F with PMH significant for grade II diastolic HF (as per previous TTE in 05/2019), atrial fibrilation (not on AC), CVA/TIA w/o residual weakness, COPD, MD and hypothyroidism who presented on 7/1 with complains of SOB, fatigue, generalized weakness and DOE for several weeks. On initial evaluation in ED, patient was hemodynamically stable with normal HR. Physical exam was remarkable for JVD+ and bibasilar wheezing and crackles. She received DuoNebs, Methylprednisolone as well as Lasix IV. Patient was admitted to medicine service under the impression of acute hypoxemic respiratory failure secondary to acute diastolic HF exacerbation with possible component of mild COPD exacerbation/viral bronchitis. Upon admission, patient developed rapid Afib requiring treatment with Diltiazem IV gtt. Patient was monitored on telemetry and continued on IV diuresis with Lasix. As per cardiology recommendations, since her CHADS2VASC score is 6, patient was started on AC with Apixaban BID. Once the HR was optimized, patient was transitioned to PO Diltiazem that resulted in appropriate HR control. Repeated TTE showed grade III diastolic dysfunction. After optimizing patient's volume status, Lasix was switched from IV to PO. As per cardiology recommendations, her HF regimen was optimized by adding Spironolactone 12.5mg PO daily. Her statin medication was changed from Simvastatin to Pravastatin to avoid potential interactions with Cardizem. Patient also received 5 days course of PO Prednisone for possible mild COPD exacerbation. Her TSH level was checked and showed level of <0.01. Levothyroxine dose was decreased from 200 to 175mcg but patient refused to take the lower dose stating that she has been stable on the current dose for many years. All the risks were explained to patient and she verbalized understanding. Of note, patient has a long history refusing to take lower dose of Levothyroxine which is also documented in her PCP's notes (Dr.Fiorillo) who spoke to patient regarding this issue during this hospital stay as well (7/8/2019). During this hospital stay her depression was managed with home dose of Citalopram and she did not express and active suicidal or homicidal ideations.      Today, patient reports feeling well and she has no active complains. Denies CP, SOB, cough, palpitations or LE edema. Hemodynamically stable and euvolemic on physical exam. Patient is ready to be discharged home today with HHA, visit nursing services, home PT and tele-health services. She will follow up with her PCP next week and cardiology in 4 weeks.       Goals of Care   Goals of Care:     Goals of Care Discussion as of 07/06/2019 15:47  Clinicians Attending: APP  Family Attending: Child  Topics Discussed: Disease Information, Prognosis, Patient values and preferences, Current treatments, Option for future treatments, Patient family understanding of condition and goals of treatment  Conversation Details: I spoke with Risa, Ms Gerbers daughter on the phone at length about current status and possible discharge planning. Daughter had multiple concerns about her mother coming home as she states the pt has difficulty with her ADLs and IADLs. The daughter states the pt typically does not get oob till 2pm and does not eat much or drink much during the day. Daughter states the pt's health has significantly decreased and she fears that she will lose her mother if somethgin does not change. Her mother lives home alone  and daughter feels she can not fully take care of herself and at times she will frequently fall at home. I told the daughter I will discuss everything with the case manager, and also suggested that the daughter call the unit and talk with the case manager. Home health nursing, aide, PT/OT, and social worker ordered for when pt is to be d/ced  .       Results Review           Microbiology: (Resulted in the past 36 hrs.
