ae_narrative: ALTHOUGH THIS PERSON HAS BEEN RANDOMIZED SHE HAS NOT YET STARTED STUDY MEDICATIONS:    At a routine visit on 10/11/2018, her cardiologist recommended that she present to the ER for a work-up.      Per the ER report:  This is a 61 year old African American female with PMHx significant for CHF, hypertension, type 2 diabetes presenting to emergency room with intermittent chest pain, patient describes this chest tightness that radiates to the left arm as well as the back, associated with shortness of breath. Denies any nausea, vomiting. She also reports that her chest pain or shortness of breath is 6 worse with exertion. Denies any worsening lower extremity edema. Patient reports that she's been compliant with her Bumex.  Denies any recent travel, hospitalization, or history of DVT or PE.    HOSPITAL COURSE/MEDICAL DECISION-MAKING:     This is a 61 year old African American female with PMHx significant for CHF, hypertension, type 2 diabetes presenting to emergency room with intermittent chest pain, patient describes this chest tightness that radiates to the left arm as well as the back, associated with shortness of breath. Patient reports chest pain worse with exertion. Patient was sent from heart failure clinic for admission. Her symptoms are concerning for ACS, less likely to be PE given that patient is not tachycardic or hypoxic. Her EKG did not show any signs of acute ischemia. Blood work reviewed, which were overall unremarkable including a negative troponin. Patient received aspirin and nitroglycerin with control of her chest pain. I did obtain a repeat EKG in the setting of persistent pain, which overall unchanged. I spoke to CHF attending, who accepted the patient for admission.
ae_relevant_info: Discharged to home on 10/14/18   She was readmitted 11/1/18 to 11/8/18
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: UP10141 was admitted to UPMC McKeesport on 12/7/18 for shortness of breath and peripheral edema.   She is week 7 in participation in STEP1 switch to Wellbutrin currently taking 300mg daily.   This admission is not related and unexpected, not reportable to Pitt IRB.    Inpatient H&P on 12/07/2018:  61 y/o female with PMH of NICM w/ AICD, stage III CKD, uncontrolled hypothyroidism and uncontrolled diabetes, active smoking, presented to the hospital with 3 days history of worsening shortness of breath and lower extremity swelling.   She was recently discharged from the hospital around 2 weeks ago after management of diarrhea, AKI and her bumex and aldactone were held on discharge. She saw her PCP and was euvolemic and diuretics were still kept on hold. 3 days she starting having shortness of breath, dry cough, mild chest tightness and bilateral lower extremity swelling. She also reports orthopnea and needing more than 4 pillows to sleep at night for the past 3 days. Usually requires only one. Denies any chest pain, sputum production, sore throat, runny nose, sneezing, sick contacts.     On arrival to the ED:  Vitals: afebrile, BP 152/85, HR 126, RR 18, O2 sas 98% on RA  Labs: WBC 12.7, BUN 15, Cr 1.5, BNP 644, trop -ve x 1  CXR: no infiltrates  CTA chest: negative for PE, left lung infiltrate  EKG: sinus tach,. no ST changes     She recieved 2 x doses of bumex 1 mg in ED, 125 solumedrol, breathing treatments and now she is being admitted to the floor for further management. She feels a little bit better since coming to the hospital but overall continues to be short of breath esp when exerting.     Impression:  Left sided HCAP  Copd exacerbation  Acute kidney injury probably due to diuresis  h/o Non Ischemic Cardiomyopathy     Recommendations:  Will start her on antibitics  cefepime and zithroomax  smalldose of steroids  some IV fluids cautiously  hold off Diuresis     Medications  acetaminophen (acetaminophen 500 mg oral tablet) 1,000 mg Every 6 Hours PRN By Mouth   albuterol (albuterol HFA 90 mcg/inh inhalation aerosol) 180 mcg Every 6 Hours PRN Inhalation   aspirin (aspirin 81 mg oral tablet) 81 mg ONCE A DAY  By Mouth   atorvastatin (Lipitor)(atorvastatin 40 mg oral tablet) 40 mg ONCE A DAY  By Mouth   buPROPion (Wellbutrin XL 150 mg/24 hours oral tablet, extended release) 150 mg ONCE A DAY  By Mouth   ergocalciferol (ergocalciferol 50,000 intl units (1.25 mg) oral capsule) 50,000 IntLUnit EVERY WEEK  By Mouth   fluticasone-vilanterol (Breo Ellipta 200 mcg-25 mcg/inh inhalation powder) 1 Puff(s) ONCE A DAY  Inhalation   insulin glargine (Lantus 100 units/ml subcutaneous solution) 53 Unit(s) AT BEDTIME  subQ   insulin lispro (HumaLOG) (HumaLOG 100 units/mL injectable solution) 16 Unit(s) 3 TIMES A DAY (WITH MEALS)  subQ   levothyroxine (levothyroxine 125 mcg (0.125 mg) oral tablet) 250 mcg EVERY MORNING  By Mouth   loperamide (loperamide 2 mg oral tablet) 2 mg Every 4 Hours PRN By Mouth   mirtazapine (Remeron 15 mg oral tablet) 15 mg AT BEDTIME  By Mouth        pregabalin (Lyrica 75 mg oral capsule) 75 mg 2 TIMES A DAY  By Mouth
ae_relevant_info: Discharged to Home on 12/13/18  Discharge diagnosis: AKI (acute kidney injury);  Bronchitis;  Hyperparathyroidism;  SOB (shortness of breath);  Uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus with hyperglycemia;  Vitamin D deficiency   Hospital Course   61 y/o female with PMH of NICM w/ AICD, stage III CKD, uncontrolled hypothyroidism and unocontrolled diabetes, active smoking, presented to the hospital with 3 days histroy of worsening shortness of breath and lower extremity swelling. She was recently discharged from the hospital around 2 weeks ago after management of diarrhea, AKI and her bumex and aldactone were held on discharge. She saw her PCP and was euvolemic and diuretics were still kept on hold. 3 days she starting having shortness of breath, dry cough, mild chest tightness and bilateral lower extremity swelling. She also reports orthopnea and needing more than 4 pillows to sleep at night for the past 3 days. Usually requires only one. Denies any chest pain, sputum production, sore throat, runny nose, sneezing, sick contacts.      Bronchitis/pneumonia/ Shortness of breath  Thought to be multifactorial: HF exacerbation 2/2 bronchitis and CAP. Remained hemodynamically stable, O2 sats good on RA. There was a mild infiltrate on CT chest, ? HCAP given recent hospitalization. Cefipime and zithromax for broad spectrum coverage. Was given a prescription for 1 more day of Zithromax to complete her course.Oral steroids, home dose borchodilators, PRN breathing treatments ordered for COPD. she was given a prescription for prednisone 20 mg daily ×3 days at discharge.Tessalon perles were ordered for cough and a prescription was provided at discharge. Smoking cessation was highly encouraged.     HF exacerbation: mild  Most likley 2/2 bronchitis and pneumonia; current volume status dry/euvolemic. There was no chest x-ray or CT evidence of voluem overload, BNP elevated (644) but could be secondary to AKI (dry BNP 11). Was diuresed with Bumex 2mg IV in ED, no charted UO but creatinine worsened, diuretics were held then restarted. Echocardiogram is done on 12/8/18  Which showed an EF of 35-40%; mild LVH; thickened and calcified aortic valve with mild regurgitation; thickened mitral valve with mild to moderate regurgitation; mild tricuspid regurgitation; mild pulmonary hypertension; diastolic function cannot be assessed. As compared to 7/5/18 it was no significant change.     AKI on CKD stage III  Etiology likely volume depletion. baseline creat around 1.1-1.2. Admission creatinine was 1.5, peaked at 1.9 after diuresis. Was ordered gentle IV hydration, monitor resp status closely. strict I&Os. Renal medicine was consulted, distance appreciated. Creatinine at time of discharge was 1.5. She was restarted on furosemide 20 mg by mouth daily.     Hyperglycemia in setting of uncontrolled diabetes  Has history of uncontrolled diabetes w/ conplications, last HbA1c 14.0 in 10/18. Home regimen: Lantus 53 U HS along with Lispro 16 U TIDAC. currently running >500. Endocrine was consulted for further recommendations. A hemoglobin A1c was 11.5. The creatinine with the orders for insulin and will need further adjustment after the discontinuation of prednisone which was out for the patient at discharge. Patient was ordered Accu-Cheks before meals and at bedtime. Consistent carb diet was ordered. Patient was continued on her home dose of Lyrica for her diabetic neuropathy.     Hypertension/hyperlipidemia  Her lisinopril was placed on hold, blood pressures remained stable. Has follow-up with Dr. Denis Macnamara at UPMC Presbyterian. Was continued on aspirin and atorvastatin.     Postsurgical hypothyroidism   Patient was on Levothyroxine250 µg by mouth daily. Patient was followed by endocrinology. On admission patient's TSH was 0.07, free T4 was 1.7 and a PTH was 190. Patient's levo thyroxine was reduced to 225 µg by mouth daily. Will need to have a follow-up TSH in the outpatient setting in 6-8 weeks.     Vitamin D deficiency  Patient continued on ergocalciferol 50,000 units by mouth weekly     Depression  Continued on Remeron 15 mg by mouth at bedtime. Mood remained stable     Prophylaxis  Heparin 5000 units subcutaneous twice a day was ordered for DVT prophylaxis and pantoprazole 40 mg by mouth daily for GI prophylaxis     Patient was seen and examined by Dr.Qayyum are to discharge and was deemed in improved condition for discharge.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Unfortunately D.MCC (UP10141) is back in the hospital.  She presented on 3/24/2019 by ambulance to UPMC McKeesport for sudden onset of shortness of breath and wheezing, most likely from COPD exacerbation.  She has a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and hyperglycemia.  She is currently in STEP 1 Continuation as a non-remitter.  On 450mg Wellbutrin.  Also taking 30mg Remeron qhs and outpatient IOP started her on 100mg Elavil qhs since she completed the acute phase of STEP 1.    Medical hospital admission for COPD exacerbation is unrelated and expected.  Not reportable to Pitt IRB.      UPDATE 4/29/19:  I do not believe she ever started 450mg Wellbutrin or 30mg Remeron.  Stayed on 300mg Wellbutrin & 15mg Remeron & 100mg Elavil.  In fact, I believe she was receiving 150mg Wellbutrin while in-patient.    During in-patient hospitalization she had a stent placed in her right leg on 3/28/19.   Discharged to home on 4/1/19.    RETURNED TO HOSPITAL FOR SIMILAR PRESENTATION FROM 4/10/19 to 4/16/19.
ae_relevant_info: She has a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and hyperglycemia.

ae_narrative: Since receiving a stent in her right leg on 3/28/19 she has had several falls (dates are unclear).  Most recent fall seemed to happen this past Saturday (4/27/19) where she got dizzy after bending over, fell back and hit her head.  She is unsure whether she had loss of consciousness from these falls.  She feels that coinciding with these falls is a worsening of her memory, word finding ability, concentration, and feeling mentally slowed down.  She does have an appointment with her PCP on 5/1/19 and will mention the right-sided weakness, falls, and cognitive changes (with thoughts to rule out stroke/concussion)    JMK completed home visit on 4/29/19 (no residual issues from the fall).  In subsequent SAE she was admitted on 5/1/19 for stroke (most likely cause of fall).

Unfortunately UP10141 (D.MCC) was admitted to UPMC Mercy on 5/1/19.   This SAE is not related, unexpected, severe (not reportable to the IRB)  Presentation: Patient is a 62 YO female with PMH DMT2, HTN, HLD, COPD, HFrEF s/p AICD, CKD, thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy who presented to Mercy on 5/1/19  as a Level 2 stroke alert.  She had recent admission to UPMC McKeesport from 3/24-4/1 for COPD exacerbation and had R popliteal stent placed on 3/28.  After discharge patient has had increased R sided weakness and dysarthria, which were progressing per family report, unable to get out of bed on her own, and sustaining 3 falls at home.  Family noted word nonsense and took patient to PCP for routine follow-up.  She was directed to Mercy ED from PCP's office on 5/1.  Her course has been complicated by hyperkalemia and a type 2 NSTEMI.  Diagnosis:  Acute ischemic left MCA stroke.  Etiology: Unclear, likely cardioembolic vs small vessel ischemic disease.    She is currently in STEP 1 CONTINUATION.  Completed S1C4M on 4/29/2019.  She did mention recent falls and right sided weakness subsequent to stent placement on 3/28/19.  She also mentioned recent difficulty with word finding.  She reported that she had an appointment with her PCP on 5/1/19 and would follow-up with her on these concerns.  Conversation during the assessment on 4/29/19 was appropriate, she also completed a central MADRS on 4/30/19.
ae_relevant_info: Discharged to home on 5/21/19
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: UP10141 (D.MCC) was due for her S1C12M around 12/27/19 and will be incomplete.  She was admitted to Magee ED on 12/14/19 for diabetic left toe foot infection requiring LLE angiogram, toe amputation and superficial femoral artery to posterior tibialis artery bypass with ipsilateral non-reversed great saphenous vein graft & left lower extremity completion angiogram. Patient has had ongoing hospitalization complicated by acute on chronic post op anemia and fall. She was transferred to Magee TCU on 1/2/20 for continued acute rehab. On 1/21/2020 IP Behavioral Health was consulted for evaluation of depression, decreased appetite, now refusing medications in the context of prolonged hospital stay.  She is on 300mg Wellbutrin qam & 7.5mg Mirtazapine qhs.   I have stopped to visit a few times but unable to complete PHQ-9, most recent visit on 1/14/20.  Provided support.  She did mention to me that she was having vivid dreams affecting sleep, feeling down and worried by her health and whether she would be forced to move due to not be able to attend to bills and that it has stairs, tired of the pain (recently had debridement surgery) and commented that she felt like she was taking too many meds but more in the context that it was hard to swallow and mentioned her throat may be irritate from recent surgery.  She said she keeps going for her granddaughter.  She even made a call to try to address housing concerns and was thinking about how to modify things at home for when she is discharged.  She was adamant that she wanted to be discharged to home this week and the fact that she has not been discharged may have prompted her current mind-set and the consult for IP BH.   Vascular surgery recommended graft exploration/thrombectomy and foot debridement to be done on 1/24/20.      I had been waiting to report when she got discharged and/or when I was able to complete the 12M assessment but neither has occurred so I am reporting at this time.     SAE- medical hospitalization d/t DM-II complications, not-related, unexpected, severe

I received a call from patient's SO today saying that she was admitted to a mental health hospital local to her.  Last night, she and SO attended a funeral home viewing of a deceased friend, and although her interactions with people there were pleasant and appropriate overall, once she left she could not stop perseverating that people were against her.  At the encouragement of family and friends, he arranged an evaluation for her and it was determined that she was unstable enough to be admitted, involuntarily.

At 6:45 this morning she was constipated and having some bleeding.  She had tried a suppository and her go-to which is prune juice with no results.  She called her son, who took her to the ER.  Her BP was 246/100.  They solved her constipation problem with an enema but decided to keep her (at least overnight) for her BP.  They are having a cardiologist see her today and she is scheduled for an echocardiogram.

Early Wednesday morning she experienced severe constipation with some rectal bleeding.  She tried to relieve the symptom with a suppository and prune juice to no avail.  Her son took her to the Jefferson Hospital ER where they were able to relieve the constipation.
Some dizziness some of the time, possibly related to the Wellbutrin; no falls; using the cane more for security.

ae_narrative: Patient called to report several episodes of urge incontinence resulting in public accidents. Significantly impacting her function/ability to go out. Patient continued on the medication through acute, then decided urinary symptoms were caused by the study medication and stopped it in continuation. Later in continuation, her urinary symptoms worsened despite being off the medication, she was convinced the urinary symptoms were not related to the medication and restarted it. She saw a urologist in April 2019 and underwent pelvic floor exercise therapy and the urinary symptoms were eventually brought under control.

ae_narrative: She reports a 3 days of constipation when she first started taking it. She usually has problems with diarrhea so this was somewhat of a relief for her actually, but it did resolve after she ate some licorice a few days later and has not returned.

She reports she's had some daytime drowsiness over the past week which resolved 3 days ago when she started taking the abilify at night again. This lady had a routine of not falling asleep until 5-6 am at baseline, but now with taking abilify at night it's helping her get to sleep around 1 or 2 am and she reports sleeping more soundly and longer.

Patient complains of lip and finger tremor since increasing study medication dose in continuation in response to recurrence of her depression. Study medication was eventually stopped because it was not improving her depression, the tremor almost fully resolved, but mild lip trembling continued long after. The patient did 'internet research' and believed the movements to be tardive dyskinesia. It remained unclear at study end, though the symptoms persisted without change for months after stopping the study medication, then improved after she started a new medication that more effectively controlled her depression and anxiety.

Email to Dr. Karp on 12/10/18- Randomized to switch to Wellbutrin.  Started 150mg Wellbutrin on 12/3/18.  Contacted me on 12/7/18 to state that she did not take Wellbutrin on Friday and wants to stop due to   1) worsening essential tremor progressing throughout the week to the point it was difficult to put in her contacts  2)	very disturbing 'aggressive/agitated' thoughts towards others Friday morning.      I spoke to her on Saturday morning (12/8/18) and she said that she already was starting to feel better not taking Wellbutrin on Friday (12/7/18) and Saturday (12/8/18).  I let her know that I would f/u with her on Monday to see how she felt and consult with you for your thoughts/recommendations about this.    She did stop Imipramine and feels better now off of that med.  She continues 60mg Cymbalta.

ae_narrative: On 5/22/19 she says her sleep is not as restful as she reports over the past week a new symptom of very vivid dreams which interrupt sleep and are so vivid that she thinks about them during the day.  She considers this to be a side-effect to NTP but is at least for now okay with continuing this medication.   She reports vivid dreams since starting NTP which wake her up at night and are disturbing even during the day because she will see something and it will remind her of the dream and makes her question if the dream really happened or not.  Not necessarily nightmares but startling.      In consideration of this we recommend that increasing NTP from 75mg to 100mg for her to do 50mg BID to help with this symptom.    On 6/3/19: She increased to 100mg NTP (50mg BID) on 5/30/19.  Since then she report excessive daytime sleepiness (describes it as uncontrollable and different than just low energy/tiredness).  She continues to have vivid dreams which are not necessarily worse.     S2WK6 phone 6/21/19.  Taking 100mg NTP @ 1hr before bed (increased to 100mg on 5/30/19).  Still a little sleepy during the day but may not be attributed to meds as she is always tired/low energy.  Dreams are still present but not quite as bothersome.  Overall she is doing 'ok' with the medication.      On 7/3/19 for S2WK8:  She also denied side-effects.  Regardless she does not wish to continue with NTP and feels it is just not helpful or agreeing with her.

ae_narrative: 2mg Abilify added on 9/27/19.  At a f/u on 10/17/19 she reported some worsening of her essential tremor.  On 10/31/19 she stopped by today.   She is actually doing really well. UPDATE 11/21/19:  Tremor may have improved slightly since stopping Abilify on 10/30/19.  Most likely progression of essential tremor. Plan is to increase to 40mg BID if no improvement and/or see neurologist for alternative treatment.

ae_narrative: In the morning on 3/6/19 he called to reschedule his appointment later that day because yesterday he had fallen at home and scratched his ankle. He rescheduled for 3/7/19 at which time he was ambulating without the use of his cane and said the bleeding had subsided. ae_narrative: He is on 60mg Cymbalta (moved it to qhs rather than qam) and increased from 2.5mg Abilify to 5mg Abilify on 3/15/19.  Since Saturday he has had vivid nightmares which wake him up and reduce quality of sleep.  He has also had bothersome leg and arm cramps (sound more like stiffness/locking rather than Charlie horse kind of cramp, he described it as having a hard time straightening out his leg).  He did not mention any other symptoms so it did not sound like muscle rigidity related to NMS.  I told him that he could go back to half tab and monitor these over the next few days until we see him on Thursday and reassess plan (appointment is at 1pm).  He does feel that Abilify has been helpful with his mood.  He feels moving Cymbalta to the evening has helped with daytime sleepiness.      On 4/11/19 he reports that even at lower dose of Abilify (2.5mg) he continues to have nightmares- disturbing, people coming after him.  These dreams wake him up.  They are not every night but more often than not.  We told him to stop Abilify and will check in with him next week to see if dreams are indeed related to Abilify.      On 4/26/19 he completed an extra visit to help him transition to outpatient psychiatry (appointment isn't until 5/20/19).  EXTRA SUPPORT.  Since stopping Abilify on 4/12/19, his nightmares have improved.  He also mentioned that his excessive sweating has resolved since stopping Wellbutrin on 3/7/19.

ae_narrative: Pt took first dose of Remeron 7.5mg on 3-6-19  on 3-7-19 she stated 'I just didn't feel right' - she was groggy and then had what sounded like a panic attack. She was very sweaty and husband was worried something more was wrong- they went to Allegheny General Hospital- but before she went she took 0.5mg Ativan.  By the time she got to the hospital she was feeling much better, but husband didn't want to risk it.  So they went in and she had EKG, bloodwork and chest x-ray. They basically found nothing wrong (except WBC was 15- but she is on steroids still for the flu).  She was not admitted. They sent her home.  Dr. told her it was likely a reaction to the Remeron and not to take it again.
ae_relevant_info: SHe is not taking any study medicaiton- this happened as a reaction to Remeron which she was taking as ITT.

ae_narrative: Patient presented to ER on 1/19/19 complaining of chest pain. She was treated and released on 1/21/19. Hospital course suggests chest pain may have been acid reflux and complications of rhinovirus in addition to her significant history of heart disease. We do not believe any reasonable relationship between the study intervention and this SAE exists.
ae_relevant_info: Hospital Course   65-year-old Caucasian female with history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, CAD, and depression who presented with chest pain. EKG in the emergency department was nonischemic and she was hemodynamically stable. Cardiology was consulted, her troponins were trended and remained negative, and Ranexa was added. She was also started on an H2 blocker for possible GERD component. On the second day of admission her RVP returned positive for rhinovirus, she had been complaining of congestion and cough. She was also orthostatic and a bolus of normal saline was given. She was kept overnight and on the day of discharge she did not have any further chest pain, lightheadedness, dizziness. She is discharged home in stable condition with medications and follow-up instructions as above. All questions were answered prior to discharge.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Patient was admitted to hospital with chest pain and shortness of breath. She stopped her chest pain medicine and as soon as they restarted her chest pain resolved and she was discharged.
ae_relevant_info: Addendum by CHAMBERLAIN DO, COLBY L on April 11, 2019 6:46 PM:   Patient seen and examined with Megan Freyer, CRNP.  All laboratory and imaging studies were reviewed.  The assessment and plan were formulated together.     Patient presented with shortness of breath and atypical chest pain. Workup was unremarkable except for mild filling defect in the subsegmental arteries of the left lower lobe. Her EKG she was unremarkable and her troponins were negative. Her exercise oximetry showed no O2 requirement. The patient had recently stopped Ranexa. When this was restarted, the patient had no further chest pain. She was seen by the pulmonary team who did not feel that she needed any anticoagulation or any further pulmonary workup. Because her symptoms had improved, we felt that she was stable for discharge. Patient was in agreement with this plan and will follow up with her PCP in one week.     Gen:  Alert and oriented, NAD  Lungs:  Clear, breathing not labored  Heart:  RRR, no LE edema  Abd:  soft, NT/ND  MSK:  No deformity  Neuro:  Non focal

ae_narrative: Patient tripped going down her steps, fell and broke her shoulder. She presented to the ER, got X-rays, and was discharged without being admitted. As of 12/6/19 patient is still in pain, but recovering well.
ae_relevant_info: X-ray: Right shoulder and humerus x-ray with comminuted fracture with nondisplaced through surgical neck and minimally displaced impacted fracture through base of greater tuberosity.

ae_narrative: Patient presented 2/22/2020 due to chest pain. Got checked out and no heart attack, nothing much to be done. They reduced carvedilol to address some hypotension/bradycardia and the chest pain resolved. She was discharged 2/24/2020. Cardiology consult and discharge summary below.    IMPRESSION:  1.  Atypical chest discomfort that occurred in the right shoulder, then in the left shoulder and then in the right upper quadrant.  I am not 100% convinced this is ischemic.  Her troponins are negative.  2.  Diffuse atherosclerosis based on previous heart catheterization.  3.  Multiple cardiac risk factors including diabetes, hypertension, combined hyperlipidemia, obesity, untreated sleep apnea and a very strong family history and remote smoking.     PLAN:  This is a tough case.  I do not have a lot of options here.  I think the best thing we did was optimize medical therapy without anything objective on an EKG or troponins, I am reluctant to repeat a heart catheterization.  The best thing to do right now is to ambulate this lady put her back on her Ranexa, her nitrates and she is on carvedilol, I see at 25 mg twice a day.  I am looking at her office chart and it appears that all of her medicines have been restarted.  There is a history of noncompliance.  I wonder if she was noncompliant.  The other thing that we can do for this lady is possibly add Plavix instead of aspirin.  I think it is a more effective antiplatelet or we can get both aspirin and Plavix.  I think the best thing right here is to  just ambulate her and if she is stable, discharge her later today or tomorrow morning.  I just do not think testing is going to change anything I do.     Thanks for the consult.        ______________________________  Saul J. Silver, M.D.  Clinical Assistant Professor of Medicine    Hospital Course   66-year-old lady, PMH pertinent for CAD s/p prior PCI, presenting with chest pain x 1 day. Occurred at rest, improved with nitro.       Chest Pain  - Already on chronic antianginal therapy including Imdur and ranolazine.  - Troponin neg x3, EKG no ST/T wave abnormalities  - Cardiology consulted- appreciate assistance; patient has hx of mild-mod CAD and is high risk for cath. Cardiology does not recommend further workup at this time given negative EKG/Trops and in view of patient being high risk for cath. Plan discussed between Dr. Silver and Dr. Kowalski. Patient deemed stable for discharge home with outpatient cardiology follow up.      Hypotension  - per pt was taking coreg 25mg po BID at home- after receiving this dose she became hypotensive and bradycardia. Reviewed EPIC records as well as discussed with her outpt pharmacy. Appears pt is not on a beta blocker  -started on coreg 6.25mg po BID given hx CAD, patient's BP/HR tolerated this dose well. Will continue on discharge, script brought to bedside via rx express prior to discharge. Nitroglycerin SL also given to patient via rx express prior to discharge.      Prior to discharge, patient had no further chest pain or new complaints. Tolerating diet and ambulating without difficulty. Discussed follow up with PCP in 1 week and Cards in 2-5week.      Discussed with Dr. Kowalski  Elisabeth Walls, PA-C  Pickle#623-8370

ae_relevant_info: Family history-year-old female who presented for evaluation of palpitations. These palpitations began early in the morning the morning of presentation. She also had associated lightheadedness and difficulty breathing that was worse when exerting herself. She had a recurrence of the symptoms later today and decided to come to the ED for further evaluation. On admission, she was found to be in A. fib with RVR. She was started on a Cardizem drip and admitted to the hospitalist service for further evaluation and management. She was evaluated by cardiology who recommended TEE/DCCV. She was also started on Eliquis. Patient converted to NSR overnight 10/15-16. She will be able to be discharged on her oral atenolol and Eliquis for continued prophylaxis. She remained otherwise stable for discharge back home.

Pt admitted from 1/21/ to 1/24 to 2/6/20    1/21/20- 78-year-old female was brought to the UPMC East due to acute episode of altered mental status and confusion. the pt usually lives alone at home and takes care of herself. the son calls her usually to check up on her. When he called on day of admission, she was confused and could not recall the events of the previous day. she was brought to the hospital.    she was treated for the following     # UTI: completed a course of Ceftriaxone 3 days. no more abx necessary   # anemia: Ferrlecit 750 given one dose. he has Hx of colon polyps and FHx of colon cancer. used to get coloscopies but stopped few years ago. advised to see a GI doctor soon. started PO iron   # AMS: due to UTI and polypharmacy. on Remeron for insomnia, Abilify/Zoloft for depression. and Gabapentin for back pain. stopped Gabapentin this admission and advised to F/U with psych and PCP to sort out her meds.  advised to stop taking gabapentin meanwhile.    She was discharged and then came back to the hospital on 1/26 with her son who  brought her in because she was again seeming confused.   Liver function tests are abnormal.  Discharged 2/7/20 from hospital- they feel this could be all due to worsening dementia. Dr. Karp's recommendation was to continue on her antidpressants and refer to inhome psychiatric care.  She was in SNF from 2/7/20 till end of February, then discharged home.    update 1/31/2020-The clinician thinking from GI was Rocephin as most likely causative agent for transaminitis.
ae_relevant_info: 1-21 admission lab results:    CT head. abdomen and pelvis were -ve  labs were sig for anemia which was later confirmed to be IDA  UA was positive    1-26 labs      - Hx of alcohol abuse, ETOH levels unremarkable last admission. ae_narrative: On 3/13/19 Does feel dizzy (particularly when changing positions and in fact got dizzy when he and wife got up to leave.  He did not fall down but used wall and us for support).  Denied any falls.      On 3/20/19 he reports on & off moderate dizziness (mostly positional or with anxiety).  No falls.    On 4/10/19 he continues to report frequent dizziness.   Update to PCP:  At his visit, sitting/standing BP and HR were measured (sitting 160/83,51; standing 124/77,60; standing delay 152/84,57).  He does have postural changes and associated dizziness.  Adjustment of his blood pressure medications may help with symptoms of orthostatic hypotension.  He has not had any recent falls.    Dr. Karp's response to his PCP:  Dr. Gongloff -- given his orthostasis, persistent htn, and unsteadiness (and relatively recent fall), do you think that the metoprolol is interfering with compensatory increase in HR to prevent orthostasis?    PCP's staff response:   In regards to the weakness and dizziness, Dr Gongloff makes no mention of it in his 3/15/19 note.
ae_relevant_info: He did see a neurologist and had several tests as he was concerned that there is an underlying medical condition to explain dizziness and muscle weakness:    Note from Neurologist:  April 15, 2019:  Results of the testing (CPK, EMG, MRI brain, MRI cervical spine) essentially unrevealing. The MRI of the brain showed changes consistent with SVID and the cervical spine showed degenerative changes without evidence of myelopathic changes. Instead of ALS, he is now fixated on whether he has MS. He told him I do not seen any evidence of MS in his brain or spinal cord, and that I do not feel any additional testing is necessary. I recommended he come back to see me when his anxiety is under better control, given the absence of clear evidence of neurologic disease on the extensive testing to date, to determine which symptoms are or are not anxiety-related. I also referred him to balance therapy due to his concerns of feeling unsteady on his feet - I did not find any clear neurologic explanation for this.     Increased to 450mg Wellbutrin on 4/11/19- Dizziness increased, no falls  Decreased to 300mg Wellbutrin on 4/17/19- Dizziness better but still present  Decreased to 150mg Wellbutrin on 4/22/19- Dizziness better but still present  Stopped Wellbutrin on 4/26/19- Dizziness resolving  Started 2mg Abilify on 4/26/19

ae_narrative: On 3/13/19 He also reports urinating more during the day.    At WK 8 on 4/10/19 he was no longer reporting this symptom

UP10168 (R.DAV) was due for his S1C8M on 12/22/19 and will be incomplete.  He had been putting off the 8M assessment due to various health complaints.  Finally was re-referred to OPTIMUM after a visit with his PCP on 1/14/2020 and met with myself and Jordan on 1/22/2020 with his wife and son.        Diagnosis is major depression with psychotic features.  Symptoms are low mood, anhedonia, spending about 18 hours/day in bed, excessive worry, and fixed ideas that he has a terminal illness, either cancer or AIDS.  Despite several attempts to reassure him he does not have these diseases, he continued to perseverate that he very well may.  He is becoming deconditioned by this excessive amount of time in bed, per his family.  He is anxious if his wife is not around.  He is not suicidal.   Given the severity of his symptoms and how disabled he is by these symptoms, Jordan recommended inpatient admission on the geriatric unit at WPIC.  To help with this process, we obtained CBC, BMP, TSH, and EKG at our office to avoid an ER admission and do a direct voluntary admission.  After he had labs and EKG, they returned home as there were no acute safety concerns and to await bed availability.  A bed was available and he was admitted on 1/22/2020 for further psychiatric treatment.  Treatment plan is to augment with a low dose of Olanzapine and initiate cross taper of his current antidepressant, 40mg Celexa, to Sertraline.  During participation he had been randomized to switch to Wellbutrin but could not tolerate switch and continued on index med of Celexa.  At STEP 1 End, Wellbutrin was tapered and switched to Abilify for somatic preoccupation.  He could not tolerate Abilify and PCP discontinued and increased Celexa to 40mg.       SAE- psychiatric hospitalization for worsening symptoms, not-related, expected.
ae_relevant_info: He is scheduled for discharge Friday 1/31/2020 with recommendations to continue outpatient psychiatry with Benedum and the BEST Program.      His medication 40mg Celexa was changed to Zoloft (75mg) & Zyprexa (5mg) & Trazodone (100mg)

ae_narrative: The patient was admitted over the weekend after suffering a fall with minor facial injury. We learned of the admission on Monday, 3/11/19, though we were aware on 3/8/19 that the patient intended to go to the ER at some point.     After increasing the aripiprazole from 2 mg to 5 mg on 3/1/19, the patient called 3/4/19 with numerous complaints including that she was falling. She had 4 very minor falls without significant injury. We instructed her to stop the medicine, but she continued to fall throughout the week with increasing severity, falling from her motorized wheel chair on 3/8/19 and injuring her face, and presenting to the ER the following day and being admitted at that time. Note that the patient had been off the study medication for 4 days prior to this event.    I've included her discharge summary below. Please note that although bipolar disorder is listed in her clinical medical chart, both our baseline evaluation and a review of the evaluations of clinical psychiatrists over the past 30 years suggest the patient does NOT have bipolar disorder.
ae_relevant_info: Hospital Course          Ms. Kac***** is a 67yo Caucasian female with a PMHx of tachy-brady syndrome s/p pacemaker placement, HTN, HLD, bipolar disorder, spinal stenosis, who presents to the ED after suffering a fall on 3/7/19, c/o facial and back pain. Patient stable for discharge today. Patient verbally frustrated, agitated, and aggressive on day of discharge. Instructed patient that we will send her new prescriptions to her pharmacy, order home PT/OT, and for her to follow up with her PCP and regular neurosurgeon on discharge. She reports chronic back pain, no other complaints. Detailed hospitalization listed below:          S/P Fall    - appears to have been mechanical fall but notes frequent falls    - Facial CT negative for acute fx or hematoma. CT chest, CT A/P negative for acute findings as well.    - Continue home pain management regimen of Percocet, Celebrex, Lyrica, and MS Contin. Lidoderm ointment.     - Will consult pain management, recommended continuing current regimen    - Consult PT/OT - rec home with home PT/OT, ordered         Spinal Stenosis    - MRI thoracic spine reporting severe T11-T12 stenosis with disk herniation. MRI L-spine reporting disk bulge with right paracentral disk extrusion at L1-L2, with moderate stenosis.    - Pain management as above.     - NSGY consulted in ED, Decadron 4mg Q8hrs. No emergent intervention at this time. Recommending Decadron taper on discharge, sent electronically to patient's pharmacy.     - patient ambulating well in hallway with walker with PT on day of discharge         UTI    - Urine cx with GNR multiple resistance    - D/c'd with Macrobid x 10 days         Hx of Bipolar Disorder    - Patient agitated, frustrated, uncooperative, and unpleasant on exam.    - Psych following while inpatient, continue Zoloft, Remeron.          CAD, HTN, HLD    - S/P pacemaker placement for tachy-brady syndrome.     - Continue Aldactone, Lipitor.          Hypothyroidism    - Continue Synthroid.

ae_narrative: She's a 67 year old Caucasian, non-Hispanic female.  She entered the study on 1/30/019 and was assigned to augment escitalopram 20mg with aripiprazole, which she started 3/20/2019; her ending dose was 15mg.  She was in the continuation phase and her last study assessment was month 8 MADRS on 2/27/2020.  She was due for her 12 month assessment at the time of death.    She had sarcoidosis with ocular involvement, severe COPD on O2, OSA, PE, CAD s/pCABG, HFpEF, DM , hypothyroidism, initially admitted in April for pulse dose steroid treatment for sarcoid uveitis complicated by decompensated heart failure. Since April has been hospitalized a total of 6 times, each returning to SNF after for UTI/pneumonia and CHF exacerbations. Most recent admission was for SOB and peripheral edema with ongoing pneumonia diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia with secondary bacteremia.     Preliminary Cause of Death:   1) Septic Shock, secondary to:  2) Staph pneumonia/empyema     Contributing causes: acute respiratory failure, atrial fib, sarcoidosis on immunosuppression.

The patient states that he fell outside of Eat N' Park hitting his head on the pavement.  Apparently he fell forward facing down and denies any history of LOC.  He states that he just fell because his 'balance is off' and feel like he is unable to lift his legs at times.  He reports having these symptoms for about 2 years, and has tried PT/OT without improvement.  He denied any dizziness/lightheadedness noted prior to his fall .  He denies any headache, vision changes , slurred speech, focal weakness or paresthesias . numbness/tingling to his extremities.  He denied any chest pain, SOB, or lightheadedness.  He denied any fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or urinary symptoms.  He denies any leg swelling or pain.  Patient felt off balance intermittently for the last several months and had fallen several times in fact.  He reports having nasal congestion with productive cough X few months.  He states that he was to see a Cardiologist 6 months ago, but is unsure which testing was performed.  The patient does have small abrasion on the back of his head, but is denying any pain at this time.  He denies any prior history of CVA or seizures.  He denies any back pain or pain radiating to both lower extremities.  Further questioning he admits to having prior history of brief episodes of vertigo in the past. In the ER, vitals were stable.  Labs unremarkable  CT head and CT cervical  spine were negative for any acute process.  EKG showed SR with first degree AV block, seen in previous EKGs, no acute changes.  He was given 500 ml bolus and admitted for further work-up and evaluation for fall and balance problems.  Neurology was consulted regarding further evaluation and management.
ae_relevant_info: Patients is an 85 year old male with a PMH of CAD, HTN, HLD, depression and OSA who presented to the ER after a fall.  The patient states that he fell outside of Eat N' Park hitting his head on the pavement.  He denied any LOC.  He states that he just fell because his 'balance is off' and feel like he is unable to lift his legs at times.  He reports having these symptoms for about 2 years, and has tried PT/OT without improvement.  He denied any dizziness, headache, vision changes , slurred speech, or numbness/tingling to his extremities.  He denied any chest pain, SOB, or lightheadedness.  He denied any fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or urinary symptoms.  He denies any leg swelling or pain.  He reports having nasal congestion with productive cough X few months.  He states that he was to see a Cardiologist 6 months ago, but is unsure which testing was performed.  The patient does have small abrasion on the back of his head, but is denying any pain at this time.     In the ER, vitals were stable.  Labs unremarkable  Ct head and cervical were negative for any acute process.  EKG showed SR with first degree AV block, seen in previous EKGs, no acute changes.  He was given 500 ml bolus.  MRI/MRA head ordered, and consult to Neurologist ordered from the ER.      He was evaluated by neurology for history of frequent falls and ambulatory dysfunction:  MRI brain without acute findings.  Showed chronic small vessel ischemic changes  MRA brain with normal findings  Orthostatic vital signs negative  MRI lumbar spine showed decompressive laminectomy, multilevel DJD and left L5 radiculopathy.  EMG/NCS of both lower extremities as outpatient is recommended     he is also evaluated by cardiology.  Recommended adding aspirin.  No further cardiac work-up at this time is recommended.  Patient is feeling like his normal self.  Evaluated by PT and OT who recommended home care physical therapy.  Stable for discharge home with home care

ae_narrative: S1WK2 by phone on 3/12/19.  Augmenting 20mg Prozac with 300mg Wellbutrin SR (2 tablets of 150mg qam).  Wellbutrin was increased from 200mg to 300mg daily on 2/26/19.  She made note of the following physical symptoms over the past two weeks 1) increased frequency and intensity of existing headaches; 2) increased dream activity which does wake her up but has not reduced sleep; 3) pruritus mainly by the evening which is relieved with Benadryl; 4) nausea which seems to be relieved by taking 150mg Wellbutrin BID rather than both tablets QAM; and 5) increased sweating on exertion.  She reports these symptoms are mild and tolerable.  She is hopeful they will dissipate with time and is comfortable continuing with the medication recommendations.  She denied falls or changes to her health.  She is planning to see her neurologist in April to reassess headaches.
ae_relevant_info: She does have a history of frequent headaches and is prescribed Imitrex    Update at S1WK6 call on 4/9/19.  She did see her neurologist for continuing daily headaches/migraines w/ worsening frequency.  He changed medication regimen:  d/c imitrex, started Migrelief, Mag Oxide; Milk Thistle; Melatonin; Prednisone taper; Aimovig montly injections.   She no longer considers this to be a side effect of study medication.      UPDATE 4/29/19:  We had increased Wellbutrin to 450mg on 4/24/19- headache significantly worsened with nausea.  Impacting function.  Decreased to 300mg on 4/29/19.      Ongoing at Study End (termination at S1C8M) participant withdrew via email 1/28/20 but commented 'Sorry I haven't had a chance to get back to you til today - I really don't want to participate any more with the study....  Have been doing ok - still dealing with headaches and accompanying symptoms and that's what gets more down.  I have weaned off Prozac and am taking Wellbutrin 1 daily. Generally feel good on this regiment; but definitely feel myself get frustrated and a bit down with the headaches.

ae_narrative: pt went to ER because of continued trouble breathing.   Note is below- pt was not admitted    Patient is a pleasant 66-year-old female who presents emergency department for chief complaint of a productive sputum cough that is only minimally better after recent antibiotic treatment for her pneumonia. She does have adventitious breath sounds on lung exam but is currently afebrile hemodynamically stable. CT angiogram of the chest was ordered along with some routine blood work. She was given 2 DuoNeb treatments. She endorses some improvement with the DuoNeb's. Blood work completed today reveals no leukocytosis with a stable hemoglobin of 11.6. Platelets are normal. Lactate is normal. Electrolytes and kidney function normal. Patient is afebrile  hemodynamically stable     CT angiogram reveals concerns for peribronchial vascular pneumonia in the setting of the patient's productive cough. There is no pulmonary embolism appreciated. There were other findings as discussed with the patient about increasing nodularity with her neoplastic in metastatic disease. She was informed of this and advised to promptly follow-up with her oncologist. She'll be treated with Levaquin 750 daily ×5. I did consider the associated medication side effects however in the setting of her immunosuppression and failure of doxycycline I feel that this is the next best approach especially with her allergy to Zithromax. She agrees and understands and has no further questions comments or concerns. She is ready to go home and does not want to stay here any longer.     Patient is advised that they should followup with their primary care physician in the next few days for reevaluation as well. Any/All labs and radiographic findings were discussed with the patient. Patient verbalizes understanding of their diagnosis, treatment plan, need for follow up, and discharge instructions. Patient has no further questions, comments, or concerns. Patient is given quality return precautions and told to return to the ER for any changing symptoms, worsening symptoms, or new symptoms - patient agrees and understands. Patient was also given a paper copy of their discharge instructions. Patient is stable at discharge and departed the ER.
ae_relevant_info: see narrative description above- pt not admitted

ae_narrative: On 3/26/19:  Started 2mg Abilify on 3/19/19, augmenting 100mg Zoloft.  She has seen some positive changes already, son has noticed too.  However, at first she did have some vomiting, this has resolved by moving Abilify to right before she goes to bed.  Not impacting sleep.  This nausea resolved on 3/26/19.    On 4/17/19:  Started 4mg on 4/9/19 & increased to 5mg soon after.  Reports vomiting & nausea returned.  Vomiting was just on the first few days, now mostly nausea.  She is optimistic this will resolve.

I contacted her on 4/2/19 @ 3pm for her week 2 phone call but she said that she was sent to the ER last night from work due to sinus infection & coughing.  She was given a prescription for augmentin but only took it for a few days as it gave her a rash.  She is feeling better and symptoms are resolving.  She did miss work for 2days.

She feels that for at least the past 3 wks she has been eating continuously and not always the healthiest of choices.    Baseline 3/12/19= 175lbs; on 100mg Zoloft & start 2mg Abilify on 3/19/19.    WK 10 5/28/19= 177lbs; on 100mg Zoloft & 7.5mg Abilify  S1C4M 9/27/19= 188lbs; on 150mg Zoloft & 7.5mg Abilify  S1C8M 1/23/20= 180lbs; on 200mg Zoloft & 7.5mg Abilify  S1C12M 5/29/20= 176lbs (back to baseline), on 200mg Zoloft & 10mg Abilify

ae_narrative: Reported at S1WK6 on 6/12/19.  Switched to Wellbutrin.  Taking 300mg daily.  Also taking 15mg Remeron qhs for sleep.  He went to the ER (VA) last Tuesday due to neck pain, dizziness, & mild headache.  They conducted a ECHO stress test and suggested he follow up with a cardiologist.  He does not feel these symptoms are associated with Wellbutrin or Remeron as he said he has had these symptoms on & off for a while now.  He said his dizziness is mostly with positional changes.  I will report as an AE and ask Dr. Smolcic if she can email or fax over ER report and EKG if he had one.        He has reduced physical activity (walking) until he is able to see his cardiologist.  In light of recent ER visit and need to see cardiologist, recommendation is to keep medications at current dose with potential to increase to 450mg Wellbutrin if needed at Week 8 on 6/26/19.     At WK8 he reports 'Sometimes forgets to take his meds despite using weekly pill organizers (2 days).  Sometimes remembers later in the day but doesn't want to take them too close too morning dose.  Reports feeling off-balance and lightheaded/dizzy particularly with positional changes or quick movements.  Denies falls.  Denies side-effects or alcohol use.  He did mention that his blood glucose and his blood pressure have been running high at times.  This greatly worries him and he has been following with his PCP to address but has not yet been provided with answers.'
ae_relevant_info: At WK10 on 7/9/19 he reported 'Denies side-effects, falls, alcohol.  No compliance issues.  Feels health (BP & blood sugar) are better regulated.'

ae_narrative: Good Morning Erica,    Thank you so much for keeping us posted.  I did call to check on him yesterday afternoon and he confirmed what he told you.    We anticipate the time of the blood draw is contributing to his levels but agree with your plan.  We will be meeting with him next week and can consider medication recommendations then.      Thank you,  Joelle    From: Erica.Smolcic@va.gov <Erica.Smolcic@va.gov>   Sent: Thursday, October 17, 2019 8:00 AM  To: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Subject: Secure: RE: MUTUAL PATIENT      Hi Joelle,  Thanks for the update.  I did see J.BOW yesterday.  He was seen in the ED for his back pain prior to our visit and received a steroid dose pack as well as ibuprofen 600 tid for 10 days.  He did say that his mood has been more low especially in the past wk with the back pain.  He also mentioned some reminders of his military service which triggered some negative ruminative thoughts.  He got a lithium level after our visit which was < 0.1 at 3:17 pm.  I'm concerned about increasing the lithium level further though especially since he just got the ibuprofen from the ED.  Dr. Smolcic  ________________________________________  From: scanjm2@UPMC.EDU  Sent: 10/15/2019 2:45:00 PM  To: Erica.Smolcic@va.gov  Subject: MUTUAL PATIENT  Hello Erica,     I just received a call from J.BOW.  He said that things have gotten worse to the point he may try to go to the ER in the morning.      Commenting about severe back pain, feeling overall not well, and cannot sleep.  He denied fever, chest pains, or falls.  He has not checked blood sugar or blood pressure today.  I encouraged that he do so.  I asked if he had someone to take him to ER but wife is asleep and he said he cannot go now because he needs to pick up his granddaughter from school.  I encouraged him to go to the ER if needed and keep up posted.  I suggested he should have them do Lithium level just to check.      He usually does not contact me to complain so this was concerning.     As a reminder he is taking 450mg Wellbutrin qam & 300mg Lithium qhs.   We do not believe his complaints sound medication related.   He has been feeling worse overall for the past several weeks.   We will check in with him later this week as a follow-up.     Thank you,  Joelle

ae_narrative: on 11/21/19:  He has discontinued Lithium.  He reports he has not noticed much of a difference.  His sleep has improved since starting Melatonin 3mg qhs.  Reports @ 7hr/night on average.    He continues taking 450mg Wellbutrin qam and 15mg Mirtazapine qhs.   He continues to deny problems with medication compliance, side-effects, falls, or alcohol use.  He did admit to missing one injection of insulin.  Yesterday his glucose was in the 600s and both his neurologist and PCP sent him to the ER.  He had a follow-up appointment with his endocrinologist scheduled for this morning after meeting with us.  The fitting for his CPAP is scheduled for tonight.    PHQ-9 = 14.  Reports daily anhedonia, depressed mood, poor appetite, and poor concentration.  He does state that some days are better than others.  He occasionally feels tired, worried, and that his speech is slower than his thoughts.        As he continues to have symptoms of depression, we recommend switching Wellbutrin to Cymbalta.  He is aware and willing to make this change.  If you agree please prescribe 30mg Cymbalta titrating to 60mg daily.    We recommend he continue 15mg Mirtazapine and 3mg Melatonin qhs.    We suggest cross-tapering Wellbutrin and Cymbalta with the following schedule:  Reduce to 300mg Wellbutrin qam x 1 week, then 150mg Wellbutrin qam x 1 week, then stop.  Start taking 30mg Cymbalta qam x 1 week, then increase to 60mg Cymbalta qam.      We plan to meet with him again on Thursday, December 5, 2019 @ 11:00am.
ae_relevant_info: He has a history of diabetes and non-compliance with both diabetes mediation and checking his blood sugar.    Medication at the time of the even was Wellbutrin 450mg.

ae_narrative: Patient had a vasovagal episode and was kept overnight for evaluation and observation. No sequelae. Doesn't seem related to her medications. See below ER evaluation and discharge summary.      Basic Information?     Visit Information: ?Patient seen on 1/27/2020. ?    ?     Chief Complaint?      Syncope      ?     History of Present Illness?      72-year-old female with no significant past medical history presented to the emergency department after a syncopal event. The patient is a home health nurse and was seeing a patient. She felt weak while sitting in a chair and passedout. She also had an episode of urinary incontinence. She has no other complaints. She denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, chills, weakness or headache.    In the emergency department she was afebrile, blood pressure 142/67, pulse 52, saturating 97percent on room air.    EKG shows sinus bradycardia    Chest x-ray shows atelectasis at lung bases, no focal consolidation.    She was given 1 L of normal saline in the emergency department.          Assessment and Plan?       Diagnosis: Syncope (ICD10-CM R55, Working, Diagnosis).           72-year-old female with no significant past medical history presented to the emergency department after a syncopal event.         Syncope:   -likely vasovagal vs related to her bradycardia. ae_narrative: After decreasing her bupropion to 150mg in order to d/c it to begin lithium for step 2, she developed nausea and extreme fatigue. When we asked her how she was reducing her dose, she said she was breaking a 300mg sustained release tablet in half, which is not recommended and may explain some of her symptoms. We told her to go back to taking 300mg and see how she felt.
ae_relevant_info: She ended up being hospitalized with a large pulmonary embolism
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: She called to complain about extreme fatigue (accompanying the nausea) on 8/14/2019. She thought it was due to one of her medications, and she had recently decreased her bupropion in preparation to enter step 2, so we recommended she go back to her original 300mg dose to see if she felt better. Her fatigue continued to increase, and she went to the ER 8/25 with extreme fatigue and nausea and she was found to have a pulmonary embolism as well as several blood clots in her legs. She is currently inpatient and waiting to undergo a procedure. Not likely related, unexpected.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: On 8/7/2019 The University of Pittsburgh IRB, after reviewing all of the information, concluded that this Reportable Event did not represent serious or continuing non-compliance in accordance with University of Pittsburgh policies or federal regulations, nor did it meet the definition of an unanticipated problem involving risk to subjects or others. This matter is now considered to be closed.     Per email from Dr. Lenze on 7/3/19 this event has been revised to not likely related.    I was assuming both.   ________________________________________  From: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Sent: Wednesday, July 3, 2019 2:44:08 PM  To: Lenze, Eric; Lenard, Emily; Emanuel, James E; Karp, Jordan; Gebara, Marie Anne  Cc: Chickering, Sunita N; Lawrence, Suzanne; Lightfoot, Michael  Subject: RE: OPTIMUM SAE Report UP10190      For clarification are you saying that the hypokalemia or dysarthria or both are not related to aripiprazole?      From: Lenze, Eric <lenzee@wustl.edu>   Sent: Wednesday, July 3, 2019 3:39 PM  To: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>; Lenard, Emily <lenarde@wustl.edu>; Emanuel, James E <emanuelje@upmc.edu>; Karp, Jordan <karpjf@upmc.edu>; Gebara, Marie Anne <gebarama@upmc.edu>  Cc: Chickering, Sunita N <chickeringsn@upmc.edu>; Lawrence, Suzanne <lawrencesm@upmc.edu>; Lightfoot, Michael <lightfootm@upmc.edu>; Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Subject: Re: OPTIMUM SAE Report UP10190    Great let us know if you have any concerns about this decision. Eric  ________________________________________  From: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Sent: Wednesday, July 3, 2019 12:51:41 PM  To: Lenard, Emily; Emanuel, James E; Karp, Jordan; Gebara, Marie Anne; Lenze, Eric  Cc: Chickering, Sunita N; Lawrence, Suzanne; Lightfoot, Michael; Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon)  Subject: RE: OPTIMUM SAE Report UP10190      We have not received a response from the PITT IRB yet but I can update them with the consensus that this is likely not related based on Eric's rationale below.      From: Lenard, Emily <lenarde@wustl.edu>   Sent: Wednesday, July 3, 2019 1:41 PM  To: Emanuel, James E <emanuelje@upmc.edu>; Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>; Karp, Jordan <karpjf@upmc.edu>; Gebara, Marie Anne <gebarama@upmc.edu>; Lenze, Eric <lenzee@wustl.edu>  Cc: Chickering, Sunita N <chickeringsn@upmc.edu>; Lawrence, Suzanne <lawrencesm@upmc.edu>; Lightfoot, Michael <lightfootm@upmc.edu>  Subject: RE: OPTIMUM SAE Report UP10190    Hi everyone,  Just wanted to follow up on this event. I'm copying Eric's response about it below:    I'd call it unlikely related, since the hypokalemia resolved while the patient was still on aripiprazole (it resolved 24hr after his last dose -- given ari's long half-life, it's still totally in his system 24hr later).      I would agree with unexpected, given the nature of the AE.    I did report it to the WU IRB, but they indicated it did not meet reporting guidelines because we reported it was probably not related to the research. Is there any more information available from the Pitt IRB?  Thanks,  Emily     Patient called on 6/18/19 in after 11 days on aripiprazole 2 mg augmenting duloxetine 90 mg. Her daughter had noticed some slowed/slurred speech and concentration difficulties. The speech changes were pronounced and noticeable by her study clinician, who completed her Week 2 evaluation, then contacted the site PI immediately. The patient was instructed to discontinue the aripiprazole and, considering her history of subdural hematoma/craniotomy evacuation, we suggested an ER evaluation. She presented to the ER at UPMC Passavant on 6/18/19 and was admitted for the night for evaluation. An EEG was performed showing isolated right hemispheric sharps but no suggestion of seizure activity. Patient labs were notable for hypokalemia, which was corrected. The speech changes appeared to have resolved the following day, notably after aripiprazole was stopped. The patient was discharged on 6/19/19. We learned of the hospitalization on 6/20/19.
ae_relevant_info: ER Report 6/18/19:  History of Present Illness   Over the past 4 weeks patient has been having difficulty speaking. Patient is aware of her symptoms and states that sometimes she has a hard time trying to find the words that she once to speak. Family states that there are periods where she looks like she is trying to find words and when she does speak at times she has slurred speech. Patient denies any other symptoms other than feeling somewhat tired over the past several weeks. She denies any headaches, vision changes, dizziness or lightheadedness. She denies any extremity weakness or numbness/tingling. She denies any fevers, cough, nausea/vomiting/diarrhea or dysuria. There is been no recent falls or trauma. Family states in March 2018 patient had a subdural hematoma with surgical evacuation. They state that they are typically aware of any neurologic changes since that incident, states she has been doing well until approximately one month ago. Family also states that patient was enrolled in a study at the Benedum geriatric Center and was recently placed on Abilify. They contacted the Center and they recommended stopping the medication, this was discontinued yesterday. Family still has concerns with her symptoms.     Medical Decision Making   71-year-old female presenting with episodes of dysarthria and word finding. Symptoms have been intermittent over the past 4 weeks. She did have a history of subdural hematoma in 2018 but has been doing well. She has a new medication, Abilify started shortly before the symptoms. This may be a side effect of the medication, also concern for TIA. She is neurologically intact upon arrival with NIH stroke scale 0. She is hemodynamically stable and well-appearing. EKG shows no signs of ischemia or injury. CT head shows no acute intracranial abnormality. Metabolic panel shows a potassium of 2.7, otherwise within acceptable limits. No leukocytosis or anemia. Patient was given oral potassium with IV fluids normal saline +20 mEq of potassium. Patient will be admitted for further management, MRI was ordered with neurology consult. Patient did not appear to have any EKG changes from a potassium of 2.7, rest comfortably remained hemodynamically stable and neurologically intact during the remainder of her ED course.      Impression and Plan   Diagnosis:  1. Episodic dysarthria  2. Generalized weakness  3. Hypokalemia.    Plan:  Admit.      Inpatient Evaluation 6/19/19:  Chief Complaint   slurred speech      History of Present Illness   71y/o F, known to Dr. Gilmour, with h/o HLD, SDH, GERD, s/p gastric bypass, provoked DVT (s/p xarelto completion) depression and anxiety with panic attacks. She presented to NHP 6/18/19 with cc slurred speech.  Sxs ongoing x 4 weeks. Pt noted occasional word finding difficulties but stated she hadn't noticed much with her speech.  She stated her daughter has noticed the speech and insisted on evaluation. Pt noted b/l LE weakness and balance issues on and off since dx of SDH.  She has had visual changes stating vision isn't as clear for the past 6-8 months; no new focal weakness or visual changes. She did start Abilify 1 week ago as part of a study at Benedum geriatric Center.  Pt and family contacted the center with their concerns and recommended the medication be stopped.  No recent illness, chest pain, sob, n/v. She has occasional abdominal pain and GERD. No dysuria.     In the ED, VSS. HCT without acute intracranial abnl. EKG with NSR, no ischemic changes. Labs with hypokalemia with K 2.7, plts 576, U/A with mod LE's, trace protein, 77 WBCs, 4 RBCs and many bacteria. Culture was sent. Brain MRI was without acute abnl.  She was admitted with consult to neurology.     6/19: Pt evaluated this morning. She feels well. No focal numb/ting/weakness. No word finding difficulty this AM.               .         Histories      Past Medical History   HLD  SDH  GERD  constipation  s/p gastric bypass  anxiety w/ panic attacks  depression  h/o provoked DVT, completed xarelto      Past Surgical History      ORIF left hip  2009, breast reduction, bilateral  2004,  hiatal hernia repair  2007, bilat Lasik  ~2007, tonsillectomy  age 16, Roux en Y, Nissen fundoplication  2014, Admit to Mercy- Subdural Hematoma  , worsening  3/21/2018 s/p evacuation     Reaction to anesthesia=Yes     Assessment and Plan   Diagnosis:  .   Dysarthria  -appreciate neuro consultation  -likely related to side effect from Abilify  given onset of symptoms shortly after starting it. Medication has since been discontinued  -HCT and Brain MRI Without acute abnl - no CVA  -EEG ordered by neuro given h/o SDH     Hypo K  -corrected.      Anxiety  MDD   -cymbalta, trazodone     HTN  -Norvasc - BP elevated this morning prior to medication - monitor     Thrombocytosis  -monitor as outpt     Dispo  -home today pending EEG and neuro attending input. She should f/u with her PCP within a week     LABS:  LABS:  Component	Value	Ref Range & Units	Status  Sodium(Na)	140 	136 - 144 mmol/L	Final  Potassium(K)	2.7Low  	3.5 - 4.9 mmol/L	Final  Results called to and read back by   BRITTANY HUNKELE @1719 ON 06/18/2019   Chloride(Cl)	101 	98 - 109 mmol/L	Final  Carbon Dioxide(CO2)	30 	22 - 32 mmol/L	Final  Urea Nitrogen	7 	7 - 24 mg/dL	Final  Glucose	106High  	70 - 99 mg/dL	Final  Creatinine	0.85 	0.50 - 1.17 mg/dL	Final  Calcium(Ca)	8.4Low  	8.5 - 10.1 mg/dL	Final  ANION GAP	12 	7 - 15 mEq/L	Final  BUN/CREATININE RATIO	8 		Final  CALCULATED OSMOLALITY	288 	281 - 307 mOsm/kg	Final  EGFR NON AFRICAN AMERICAN	69 	>59	Final    Component	Value	Ref Range & Units	Status  Neutrophils	60 	%	Final  ABS Neutrophils	2.90 	1.80 - 7.50 X10E+09/L	Final  Lymphocytes	27 	%	Final  ABS Lymphocytes	1.30 	1.00 - 5.00 X10E+09/L	Final  Monocytes	10 	%	Final  ABS Monocytes	0.50 	0.00 - 0.80 X10E+09/L	Final  Eosinophils	2 	%	Final  ABS Eosinophils	0.10 	0.00 - 0.70 X10E+09/L	Final  Basophils	1 	%	Final  BASOPHILS, ABS	0.00 	0.00 - 0.20 X10E+09/L	Final  WBC	4.8 	3.8 - 10.6 X10E+09/L	Final  RBC	4.37 	3.90 - 5.00 X10E+12/L	Final  Hgb	12.7 	12.0 - 14.8 g/dL	Final  Hematocrit(HCT)	39.7 	35.0 - 43.0 %	Final  MCV	90.8 	81.0 - 99.0 fL	Final  MCH	29.0 	27.0 - 33.0 pg	Final  MCHC	31.9 	30.0 - 37.0 g/dL	Final  RDW-CV	16.4 	%	Final  Platelets	576High  	150 - 450 X10E+09/L	Final  Mean Platelet Volume	7.1 	fL	Final    Component	Value	Ref Range & Units	Status  Prothrombin Time	12.7 	11.2 - 14.7 seconds	Final  INR	1.0 	0.8 - 1.2	Final    Neurology Consult 6/19/19:  History of Present Illness   This is a 71-year-old female with a past medical history of subdural hematoma after a ground-level fall on March 11, 2018. Recurrence of subdural hematoma noted on March 22, 2018 with symptoms of lethargy and language changes. S/p surgical intervention. Other medical history includes hyperlipidemia, anxiety, depression. She presents as a new consultation for intermittent slurred speech.      She was started on Abilify two days ago.  Shortly after she noticed cognitive changes in word finding difficulties. Family noticed language changes yesterday which prompted ER evaluation. Her Abilify was discontinued and she noticed improvement to her cognitive complaints. No speech difficulties at this time. She mentions paresthesia to her lower extremities, but no focal complaints. She denies motor weakness. She has gait instability, but no falls. She was on Keppra briefly for seizure precautions, however this was discontinued. No aspirin, Plavix or other blood thinning medications at this time.      Histories      Past Medical History   Right-sided subdural hematoma with recurrence in March 2018, hyperlipidemia, anxiety, depression.     Impression and Recommendations   This is a 71-year-old female seen as a new consultation for language changes noted by family. She was started on Abilify and shortly after noted cognitive side effects. Family noted language changes yesterday which prompted ER evaluation. Abilify was discontinued with improvement to cognitive complaints.  Language appears normal on exam.  CT head completed and negative for acute findings. MRI brain completed and negative for acute findings. Symptoms most likely explained by medication, however seizure should be included in differential (history of SDH).  Plan for EEG.  No ptosis or other findings of myasthenia gravis  on exam.  We'll follow for testing results.  Dr. Massa evaluation to follow.        Diagnosis:  History of SHD, language changes. . Addendum by MASSA MD, ROBYN E on June 19, 2019 2:59 PM:      I have seen and examined the patient and agree with plan of care in the CRNP note. Patient states her daughter told her that her speech has been slurred the last few days. The patient herself has not noticed any speech changes and she feels well. She has no complaints. She had a R SDH evacuated last year and has done well since then. No seizures.     Neurological exam is normal. She is awake, alert, appropriate. No dysarthria or aphasia. Mental status, CNs, motor, sensory, DTRs, cerebellar exam normal.     MRI brain: there are extensive WM changes but no new acute change.  UA positive, she is asymptomatic  EEG: isolated right hemispheric sharps     71 yo F with history R SDH s/p evacuation with reported dysarthria that resolved with stopping abilify. Exam at this time is normal. EEG does show isolated right hemispheric sharps likely due to cortical irritability from prior SDH, however history is not suggestive of seizure.   -Recommend follow-up in neurology clinic. Would obtain 48  hour ambulatory EEG for any recurrent neurologic symptoms that may be concerning for seizure    EEG 6/19/19  UPMCPassavant  Pulmonary  EEG Report    ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:  MARK A WOODBURN  ADMISSION DATE:  06/18/2019  EVALUATION DATE:  06/19/2019     This is a 22-channel digital EEG obtained during alert state.  The tracing  was performed for 25 minutes and 8 seconds in duration.     Low voltage 8 cps alpha activity is seen in the background of the tracing  with left hemispheric accentuation.  Slower 7 cps theta activity with  occasional sharp wave appearance is seen involving right hemisphere with  some accentuation of right frontal and right temporal region.   Hyperventilation was not attempted in this case.  Photic stimulation did  not evoke a photo convulsive response.  The patient remained alert  throughout the tracing.     IMPRESSION:      This EEG obtained during the alert state is abnormal.  There is asymmetric  mild slowing involving right hemisphere compared to left with isolated  sharp forms present involving right temporal and parietal region.  These  areas are suggestive of epileptiform character, but are isolated in  character.  Background eye blink, muscle and movement artifact is present.        ______________________________  Electronically authenticated at end of document.      Dictated by: David M. Lobas, M.D.    EEG 7/11/18  Basic Information       Date of Study: July 11, 2018       Duration: 42 minutes      EEG Number: 070-4818   Diagnosis:  Personal history of traumatic brain injury (ICD10-CM Z87.820, Working, Diagnosis).       Subjective   70 year-old presenting with history of traumatic brain injury, on AED therapy. The question of discontinuation of medication has been raised  EEG was requested to evaluate for potential seizures.   Pertinent Medications: Keppra      Impression and Plan   EEG Diagnosis   Wakefulness-sleep obtained      Objective   EEG description: This is 22-channel digital EEG recording with electrodes placed in accordance to the International 10-20 system. A single EKG channel was used throughout the recording. Video was reviewed if available.       Background:  There is a well-developed, symmetric, rhythmical 8-9 Hz posterior dominant rhythm that attenuates with eye opening. The background is continuous, spontaneously variable and appropriately reactive.  Very subtle asymmetry was seen between the hemispheres with the high amplitude of the discharges over the right parietal head region due to the previously performed craniotomy, representing a breach rhythm  Activation: The patient was alert, oriented and appropriately followed commands and answered questions. Photic stimulation did not elicit any abnormal activation.   Sleep: Patient became drowsy, fell asleep, sleep patterns were seen, sleep was interruptive, vertex waves, spindles were evident     Epileptiform discharges: none  Seizures: none     Additional Channels: The EKG channel was unremarkable.       Test Interpretation   This along EEG monitoring has failed to record the presence of definite epileptiform discharges, seizures or other focal abnormalities   Very subtle asymmetry could response to the location of previously performed craniotomy with a high amplitude of the discharges over the right parietal head region  Otherwise, clinical correlation is needed      Professional Services   Credentials Title and Author     Credentials: MD.     Title: Attending.     Supervising MD: ZARETSKAYA MD, MARINA.       EEG 3/24/18  Basic Information       Date of Study: 3/24/18       Duration: 25 minutes      EEG Number: 0312418   Diagnosis:  Subacute subdural hematoma (ICD10-CM I62.02, Working, Diagnosis), SDH (subdural hematoma) (ICD10-CM I62.00, Working, Problem), Hypertension (ICD10-CM I10, Working, Diagnosis), Anxiety and depression (ICD10-CM F41.8, Working, Problem).       Subjective   70 year-old presenting with ICH, s/p Right crani  EEG was requested to evaluate for potential seizures.   Pertinent Medications: AED      Impression and Plan   EEG Diagnosis   Dysrhythmia grade III, Left frontal- temporal  Dysrhythmia grade III, right frontal-central      Objective   EEG description: This is portable 22-channel digital EEG recording with electrodes placed in accordance to the International 10-20 system. A single EKG channel was used throughout the recording. Video was reviewed if available.    Slow BG activity was seen over the left hemisphere, in the Delta range.   High amplitude Delta was evident over the left frontal-temporal region, with the presence of the high amplitude sharp waves, with frequency of 1 -2/second.  At the same time, suppression was seen over the right hemisphere, with the presence of the slowing in the delta range  Occasionally, sharp waves were seen over the right frontal-central to right temporal regions     HV could not be performed  Photic did not elicit a well developed driving response     Despite the presence of the sharp waves, this EEG has failed to reveal the presence of the electrographic seizure   Additional Channels: The EKG channel was unremarkable.       Test Interpretation   This an abnormal study for the patient of this age due to the presence of the epileptiform discharges, evident over the both cerebral hemispheres, but much more pronounced over the Left frontal- temporal area. It is suggestive of a higher seizure tendency  Clinical correlation is needed  A close follow up is recommended       Professional Services   Credentials Title and Author     Credentials: MD.     Title: Attending.     Supervising MD: ZARETSKAYA MD, MARINA.
