ae_narrative: Patient presented to Renaissance Family Practice Hampton on 9/30/19 complaining of upper right quadrant abdominal pain. The evaluated her and sent her to the emergency department. She was transferred to Magee Women's Hospital for suspected cecal bascule. patient was evaluated for possible surgery, but discharged home as it was determined surgery was not acutely necessary.    Chief Complaint   Abdominal pain      History of Present Illness   71-year-old female with past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, subdural hematoma, gastroparesis, past surgical history of gastric bypass 4 years ago in a Margaret's with Dr. Peluso presenting with abdominal pain.  Patient states she had had right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past 2 to 3 days.  She went to her primary care doctor who then sent her to the emergency room at UPMC Passavant.  Patient describes the pain is sharp constant 4 out of 10 pain.  She denies any fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting.  Patient denies any change in bowel habits, states she had a regular bowel movement yesterday with no blood in her stool.  Patient endorses passing flatus.  Patient denies ever having pain like this previously.  Patient has a record of laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication in the chart in 2007, however does not recall having the surgery.  Patient is not a smoker.     Assessment and Plan   Diagnosis:  Abdominal pain in female (ICD10-CM R10.9, Working, Diagnosis).    71-year-old female past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, subdural hematoma status post evacuation, provoked DVT status post Xarelto, past surgical history of gastric bypass 4 years ago, possible laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication presenting with right upper quadrant abdominal pain possible cecal bascule     -No acute surgical intervention, patient does not have any acute abdomen  -Admit to general surgery  -Pain management  -Home meds  -Encourage out of bed, ambulation 3 times daily or greater  -Incentive spirometry 10 times per hour  -N.p.o. except medications  -Resuscitative IV fluids with lactated Ringer's at 100 mL/h  -IV bariatric vitamins  -Strict I's and O's  -No indication for antibiotics  -Repeat static lactate, if continues to be elevated will treat with IV fluids, trend lactate  -DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox, SCDs      Professional Services   Credentials Title and Author     Credentials: MD.     Title: Fellow.     Supervising MD: HAMAD MD, GISELLE G.
ae_relevant_info: gastric bypass 4 years ago, Nissen fundoplication for her GERD in 2014    Radiology results (current admission 9/30/19)  X-ray: Chest x-ray was performed and read by radiology as the following:  IMPRESSION:   No evidence of acute cardiopulmonary disease., Computed tomography: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed and read by radiology as the following:  IMPRESSION:     There is a significantly different position/location of the cecum   into the high right upper quadrant on today's study than seen on the   2018 previous exam. The cecum was previously very low-lying into the   deep pelvis, now positioned superiorly into the right upper quadrant.     There is slight distention and increased fecal material present   involving the cecum and terminal ileum. There is slight fat stranding   and altered configuration of the terminal ileum. A definite twist is   not identified to suggest a definite cecal volvulus, however, the   possibility of an underlying malposition due to internal hernia with   developing obstruction or cecal bascule process cannot be excluded.     Surgical consultation is recommended.     Sigmoid diverticulosis without active diverticulitis.     Previous gastric bypass procedure.     Moderate caliber hiatal hernia.     Hepatic steatosis.

ae_narrative: Presented to the ER with a nosebleed starting 6/26. It is on the R side of her nose. She and her daughter attempted to hold pressure at home without success; since she has been here with a nose clip the bleeding has slowed. They have soaked through 3 hand towels. She cannot breathe through her nose but otherwise breathing is okay. Denies nausea. Denies lightheadedness. After another 25 minutes the bleeding had slowed to only drops and she no longer had the sensation of blood going down her throat. This was an improvement, but as there continued to be a slow drip.  Observation is warranted. Leaving the packing in and  gave her a dose of Unasyn.  She will be admitted for observation to a regular floor.

pt feels increased anxiety- it hits her suddenly and can be intense. She needed to take lorazepam 2 times past week, when normally she doesnt take it that often.

Pt has lost 8 lbs (baseline was 128, now weighed herself at 120).  She notes she doesnt have much of an appetite.  She is moving in to STEP 2 and switching to Nortrip.    Did not lose anymore weight after this, at STEP 2 week 10, she remains 120
This is occuring as she is tapering wellbutrin 450mg daily to begin a STEP 2 medication- so really occuring between step 1 acute and step 2 acute
ae_relevant_info: BP was checked at rite aid and was 105/92-      Dr Reynolds would like her to slow down taper of wellbutrin

ae_narrative: 8/30/19 -Pt said dry mouth is severe even after cutting to 50mg qhs and two nights ago she went down on dose to 25mg on her own    pt has dry mouth- she will get biotene and hard candy  8-14-19- Pts dry mouth is worse, also her nortrip level was very high, she will cut down to 50mg of nortirp nightly after skipping her dose today (8-14)
feels very bloated, thinks she might be constipated, told her to get and take Senna    9-12- pt continue to have constipation, but when she takes Senna it is helpful
Pt is not on study med, is taking Lexapro after stopping nortriptyline.    pt tried increasing Lexapro from 10 mg to 20mg, but felt too tired after two days and reduced back to 10mg daily
Lightheaded
R eye blurry vision, comes and goes.  Optometrist doesn't think it is medication related, but rather due to changes in medical state
Slight and occasional tremor in both hands; no pattern of occurrence; not impairing.
Pt having more vivid dreams about his late wife and other topics that are a bit bothersome, does not say it is affecting his sleep
pt needs to take a nap during the day, he is also sleeping more at night
pt says he feels nasuseas- denies any vomitting

He slipped and fell on some large lava boulders  (while on vacation).  He  landed on his right side.   He went to urgent care on 11-14-19 upon returning. The doc noted ' No head injury/LOC. Having constant pain without radiation in abdomen, legs or groin.  Gets sharp stabbing spasms, with bending, lifting the legs, coughing,   Dr. prescribed Flexeril and Lodine.  Pt is feeling better
ae_relevant_info: Pt denied any dizziness or lightheadedness before the fall- he tripped over rocks

ae_narrative: From: 'Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon)' <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Date: Tuesday, November 12, 2019 at 6:39 PM  To: 'Karp, Jordan' <karpjf@upmc.edu>, Marie Anne Gebara <gebarama@upmc.edu    S.PAG- Reached out today.  S1C4M not until January.  On 9/13/19 entered Continuation as a remitter on 40mg Celexa & 300mg Wellbutrin.  Wellbutrin increased to 300mg on 8/21/19.  Called today to state that she has been experiencing some bothersome side-effects which she feels are related to after increasing Wellbutrin to 300mg.  Saw her PCP, Dr. Bumbaugh yesterday who agrees.  She would like to reduce to 150mg (insists SE were not present at that dose).  She may have some 150mg tablets at home, enough for a week.  I can check-in after a week to see if symptoms resolved and if mood has not worsened, pend script to PCP for 150mg Wellbutrin to continue at that dose.     Symptoms include   Tremor- bilateral hands- affects writing and dropping things- possibly related, expected, moderate  Ringing in Ears- not related to fluid build-up, PCP checked- possibly related?  Others on Wellbutrin have complained about ringing in ears, tinnitis is listed as a side-effect but is not specifically stated in the consent form.    Feeling Off-Balance- no falls, seems positionally related but she has checked BP and has not noted orthostatic changes- specially dizziness is possibly related.
ae_relevant_info: F/U call on 11/18/19.  Reduced Wellbutrin to 150mg on 11/12/19.  She said shaking has stopped and she is no longer feeling unsteady on her feet.  Ringing in her ears has also improved.  She has not noticed a decline in mood since reducing Wellbutrin from 300mg to 150mg.

ae_relevant_info: ATTENDING IMPRESSION:    This is a 63-year-old male who presents after a ground-level fall. Patient also is in and out of consciousness. He has a superficial forehead hematoma on the left side of his forehead. CT of the head and cervical spine showed no acute traumatic injury. He also has an abrasion over his left knee. X-rays of the left knee and left hip show arthrosis but no fractures. Admission labs are unremarkable. He does not have a low hemoglobin. He is not dehydrated. Potassium is slightly low and was given oral repletion. Patient is not hypotensive. His glucose is within normal range. His vitals are otherwise stable. Tetanus is up to date. Given reassurance. Discharged in stable condition with return precautions.       Note- Pt was not taking any antidepressant when this fall occurred- he had decided to stop the wellbutrin 300mg about one month before this fall.

ae_narrative: Email received 9/24/19:    Hello Joelle,  Wanted to give you an early heads-up.  Last week was very stressful for me and not sure how your study would reflect on that - I had to visit Kashmir for some work and place has been in news you must have heard, dealign with curfews, soldiers everywhere on streets, checkpoints everywhere - whats worse is there was no internet :)    I was feeling lousy last week, I had pain in my back all the time, etc. etc.  To make matters worse after I landed back in New Delhi it went from bad to worse.  I was diagnosed with Malaria / Dengue fever and doctor has ordered complete bed rest.  I go from feeling ok to triple digit fever (104,103...), body aches, stomach cramps, etc....    I continue to take my daily meds but too many variables affecting state of mind.  I can do Friday call if you are still interested but wanted to give you a head-up.
ae_relevant_info: On 9/30/19 fever is starting to drop and body aches have been better over the past 3 days.  Blood platelet levels went from 160 down to 88, then 64.  They are now back up to 120.    As of 10/28/19 he said 'He is finally starting to feel like things are on an upward slope in his recovery from Dengue Fever.'
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: On 10/11/19 I received message 'I was also experiencing severe anxiety, so I cut back from 7.5mg to 5 last 2 days....'  Since reducing dose 'I have less anxiety...I had episodes where I felt I needed to get out of my skin....Better now.  Not sure what's going on.'   Recognizes there could have been other contributing factors but unsure if it was a side-effect.

S1WK10 on 10/28/19 mentioned that since starting Abilify he feels that his sexual interest is significantly decreased almost 'non-existent'.  As such he is unsure whether he would like to increase dose of Abilify further.
ae_relevant_info: On 3/17/2020 he denied any side-effects (please note he stopped Abilify around 2/25/2020)

Patient presented to ER with abdominal pain and vomiting. A retroperitoneal hematoma was identified. Patient denies any falls or trauma since entering the study. Patient reports the doctors think it was related to her motor vehicle accident in July (shortly prior to entering the study). It may have been mild and missed at the time as they focused on her other injuries (e.g., rib fractures) and exacerbated more recently when she was out for a walk. The hematoma was treated by IR embolization and the patient was monitored in the hospital over the weekend. She remained stable and was discharged 10/15/19. Discharge summary below:    Hospital Course   Ms. M presented to Mercy Hospital on 10/12/19 with a chief complaint of abdominal pain as well as shortness of breath.  CT abdomen and pelvis was done and revealed an 11 cm retroperitoneal hematoma at the pelvic inlet.  Interventional radiology was consulted and performed an interval glue embolization of the right inf epigastric artery and gel foam embolization of the small branch from the right internal iliac artery. She was also transfused 2 units of prbcs and placed on her home dose of oxycodone 5 mg TID for pain control following her procedure. Over the next 3 days her hemoglobin and blood pressures were monitored.  These remained stable throughout the rest of her admission and Ms. M was discharged.  She was instructed to finish her previously prescribed regimen of doxycycline which she was prescribed for cellulitis prior to being admitted to the hospital.  A prescription for 5 mg oxycodone TID was sent to her pharmacy.  She was given a work excuse for 3-5 days.        General:  Alert and oriented, No acute distress.    Neck:  Supple.    Respiratory:  Lungs are clear to auscultation, Respirations are non-labored, Breath sounds are equal.    Cardiovascular:  Normal rate, Regular rhythm.    Gastrointestinal:  Soft, Non-distended, Normal bowel sounds, slight tenderness to palpation in right abdomen, likely secondary to hematoma.    Musculoskeletal:  No swelling, No deformity.    Integumentary:  Warm, Dry, Intact, erythema on right lower leg.    Neurologic:  Alert, Oriented, No focal defects.    Psychiatric:  Cooperative, Appropriate mood & affect.       Discharge Plan   Discharge Summary Plan   Discharge medications: oxycodone 5mg TID.     Discharge disposition: discharge to home self care.     Discharge instructions given: to patient.     Patient/Family Response to Instruction: able to recall/perform demonstration.     Discharge Status: improved.     Physical Activities: no restrictions.     Dietary Restrictions: no restrictions.     Prescriptions: sent electronically to pharmacy.     Follow Up Instructions: patient will follow-up with Primary Care Physician, in 2 - 3 weeks.
ae_relevant_info: Study Result     Procedure:  Right internal iliac arteriogram  Right external iliac arteriogram  Angio-Seal closure of left common femoral artery.     Clinical History:  71F w/ hx of MVC trauma in July 2019 (with right rib fxs and RLE   hematoma) recently followed up w/ gen surgery as an outpatient. She   reportedly had 5 days of ABD pain in the right side and some SOB,   presented to Mercy ED. CT revealed right pelvic side wall hematoma   with blush/PSA. Hgb currently 7.0 (baseline 9.0), she is receiving   2nd unit of PRBC. IR was consulted for pelvic angiogram, possible   embolization.     Comparison:  CT of the abdomen and pelvis 10/12/2019     Technique:  A timeout was performed. Moderate sedation was administered by a   dedicated nurse under the attending physician's direct supervision.   The attending physician was present the entire procedure.      The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table. The left   groin was prepped with 2% chlorhexidine and draped in the usual   sterile fashion. Sterile drape, gown and mask were used as personal   protection. 1% lidocaine was in the left groin subcutaneously for   local anesthesia.     A 21-gauge needle was used for access the left common femoral artery   under ultrasound guidance. A 0.018 guidewire was placed coaxially   through the needle. The needle was exchanged for a micropuncture   sheath. A Bentson wire was advanced to the abdominal aorta through   the micropuncture sheath. The micropuncture sheath was exchanged for   a short 5 French vascular sheath over the wire.      A 5 French Omni Flush catheter was advanced over the Bentson wire.   The wire and catheter was brought up and over the aortic bifurcation   and advanced into the right internal iliac artery. A subtraction   angiogram was obtained. A renegade high flow microcatheter and fathom   microwire were advanced coaxially through the base catheter and into   a small branch of the internal iliac artery. Gelfoam embolization was   performed.     The microwire and catheter were then removed.     The 0.035 wire and catheter was then retracted and directed into the   right external iliac artery. A subtraction angiogram was obtained at   this location. The renegade microcatheter and fathom microwire were   then coaxially advanced through the base catheter and into the   inferior epigastric artery. Embolization was performed with 0.2 cc of   Trufill glue. The microcatheter and wire were then removed. A final   subtraction angiogram was obtained through the base catheter.     The wires, catheters, and vascular sheath were then removed.   Hemostasis of the left common femoral artery was obtained with an   Angio-Seal vascular closure device deployed in the usual fashion.     There are no immediate post procedure complications. The patient will   return to the emergency department in stable condition.     Findings:  Small irregular artery originating from the right internal iliac   artery. Gelfoam embolization of the artery demonstrate no evidence of   post embolization filling of contrast.     Active extravasation originating from the right inferior epigastric   artery. Interval glue embolization of the right inferior epigastric   artery. Post embolization angiogram demonstrated absence of contrast   filling the inferior epigastric artery.     IMPRESSION  Impression:  Small irregular vessel originating from the right internal iliac   artery, Gelfoam embolization was performed.  Glue embolization of active extravasation originating from the right   inferior epigastric artery.     Electronically signed by: Jingyu Zhou on 10/12/2019 7:11 PM

ae_narrative: Patient presented to ER with shortness of breath. Discharge diagnosis was hypertensive emergency and flash pulmonary edema. Medications were adjusted and a more strict diet was prescribed. She improved once they got her BP under control and was discharged in stable condition on 3/17/2020. Cardiology evaluation and discharge summary below.      Inpatient consult 3/13/2020       History of Present Illness?     Patient is a 72-year-old white female with past medical history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, CVA, provoked DVT/PE, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, and mood disorder who was initially admitted due to hypertensive emergency. ?Patient statesthat over the past 2 or 3 weeks she has been progressively more short of breath which acutely worsened over the past few days. ?She previously been attributing her shortness of breath to increased stress from the passing of her mother, and thought that shewas having panic attacks. ?She reports that while she never had any chest pain she did have some pain across her shoulders which worsened when attempting to take a deep breath. ?Over the last few days she is also developed a nonproductive cough but no fevers,no personal travel outside of the area, and no sick contacts that she is aware of; she does note that her occupational therapist recently returned from a cruise and she did see her therapist 1 week ago but was already short of breath at that point. ?She hasbeen able to continue walking around her home and had been taking care of her mother up until her mother's passing, but did so with increasing difficulty. ?She recalls at least 3 episodes of PND over the past 3 weeks and at baseline has a 2 pillow orthopneabut more recently has been sleeping in a recliner. ?She does have chronic right lower extremity edema greater than left which she does not note has changed recently. ?She eventually decided to call EMS due to progressively worsening dyspnea. ?On arrival patientwas noted to have a systolic blood pressure of 220 and was given aspirin 325 mg, 3 sublingual nitro times, Nitropaste by EMS. ?She was also hypoxic to 85 percent. ?She continued to be hypertensive and tachycardic on arrival to the ED and she was subsequently placedon BiPAP received 40 mg IV Lasix, 1.25 mg IV enalapril, and placed on a nitro drip. ?Her systolic blood pressure decreased from 1 80-80 therefore the drip was turned off. ?She continued at that time to have decreased mentation therefore she has been pain onBiPAP and then admitted to the ICU. ?She however at this point states that she is feeling much better than she had over the past several weeks, back to her baseline mentation, and has had improved respirations.              Impression and Recommendations?      Diagnosis: ?Hypertensive emergency (ICD10-CM I16.1, Working, Diagnosis), Flash pulmonary edema (ICD10-CM J81.0, Working, Diagnosis). ?          Patient is a 72-year-old white female with past medical history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, CVA, provoked DVT/PE, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, and mood disorder who was initially admitted due to hypertensive emergency,with progressive SOB over the last several weeks. Cardiology is now consulted for HTN emergency and concern for new LBBB.         HTN Emergency     - Patient's home regimen is losartan 50 mg daily and carvedilol 6.25 mg daily; she states that she has been compliant with her medications despite the increased stress from taking care of her mother and her mother's passing, missingat most 1-2 doses of her medications a week; she also reports a relatively high salt diet but states that she has been doing this for some 5 years    - Unclear etiology for what tipped her over into hypertensive emergency on this particular occasion, however her blood pressures were aggressively reduced with multiple medications and she is currently normotensive    - Agree with continuing carvedilol 6.25 at this time, however she can certainly have this increased as tolerated    - Can add back her losartan 50 mg if blood pressures begin to increase again    - Agree with PRN IV labetalol 10 mg every 4 hours; she may eventually need the addition of a diuretic as well to her home regimen in order to maintain good blood pressures at home    - Would give additional dose of 40 mg IV Lasix today given that she still has crackles and decreased lung sounds    - Continue to monitor blood pressures closely         N STEMI, left bundle branch block     -Troponin initially negative with slight increase to 0.15, likely secondary demand ischemia given her hypertension tachycardia    - Left bundle branch block seen on her EKG is not new; she did have a stress test in October 2019 where a left bundle was appreciated at a heart rate of 100, and she is also had a cardiac cath in 2014 that showed mild disease in theLAD and the RCA    - Agree with obtaining repeat echo at this time; her last echo in July 2019 had an EF of 40 percent, grade 1 diastolic dysfunction, moderately dilated LV and, and mild diffuse hypokinesis    - At this time she does not require any further work-up for this left bundle branch block which is likely indicative of underlying conduction abnormalities given her cardiomyopathy and is rate related         Thank you for allowing us to participate in the care of your patient. ?We will follow along with you. ?Please contact the cardiology service with any questions or concerns.         D/w Dr. Fallert         Noor-ul-huda Mehdi, MD    Internal medicine, PGY2    ????Pager number 412-270-0265      Addendum by FALLERT MD, MICHAEL A on March 13, 2020 10:24 AM:      The patient ?was seen, chart and old records reviewed, and the patient examined. I agree with the resident ?evaluation and recommendations. The pt has ahx of HTN and mild CAD by cath in 2014. Stress test 9/2019 with ni ischemia, intermittentLBB and EF47percent.    ?She has been under a lot of stress due to motherdying and has been SOB. She came in in pulmonary edema, very hypertensive ,mild trop elevation.    ?Overnight diuresed, feels better, BP down.    ?On exam rales at base, cor RRR, S1 S2, no murmur, mild edema,    ?ECG intermittent LBBB.    ?Imp ?Malignant HTN, ?with secondary MI, now controlled, does not look like a primary ACS.    ?Resume coreg and losartan, lasix today    echo.    ?No need for cath now.     LBBB is intermitted and rate related at ~ 90-95 BPM    for tx to tele floor.    Discussed with CCM>      Discharge summary 3/17/2020     Discharge Information?       Discharge Summary: ??    ?????Admit Date: 3/13/2020. ?    ?????Discharge Date: 3/17/2020. ?    ?????Attending physician: PATI MD, PRATEETH. ?    ?????Consulting physician: GENERALOVICH MD, THOMAS. ?    ?????Consult Services: Cardiology. ?    ?????Reason for admission: Dyspnea. ?    ?????Discharge diagnosis: Hypertensive emergency (ICD10-CM I16.1, Discharge, Diagnosis), Flash pulmonary edema (ICD10-CM J81.0, Discharge, Diagnosis). ?    ?????PCP Discussions: Case was discussed with PCP on discharge ( No ). ?     Hospital Course?          72 Y/O F admitted for dyspnea due to flash pulmonary edema in the setting of hypertensive emergency. His blood pressures were initially in the 200s systolic - she had been adherent to medication at home but had persisted in maintaining a high salt diet.She did have mild troponin elevation to 0.15 and a TTE that showed a decreased EF to 30 - 35percent. She had a cath done in 2019 that showed 40percent RCA stenosis and clean left sided vessels. She was continued on her home carvedilol and losartan. She was diuresed withIV furosemide over a three day period and was transitioned to PO furosemide on discharge. Cardiology assisted with management as well. She did have an AKI as well on admission from the uncontrolled hypertension and this improved rapidly once the blood pressurewas better controlled. Discharged in stable condition.        Discharge Plan?     Discharge Summary Plan?    Discharge disposition: discharge to home self care. ??    Discharge instructions given: to patient. ??    Patient/Family Response to Instruction: able to recall/perform demonstration. ??    Discharge Status: improved. ??    Physical Activities: no restrictions. ??    Dietary Restrictions: low-salt diet. ??    Prescriptions: sent electronically to pharmacy. ??    Follow Up Instructions: patient will follow-up with (Primary Care Physician, GENERALOVICH MD, THOMAS), in 1 - 2 weeks. ??    Time Spent Discharging Patient: Total time spent discharging patient was 28 minutes. ??
ae_relevant_info: Patient has premorbid history of HTN - this is expected SE of bupropion, but her BP increase was independent of bupropion dose/despite bupropion dose decrease.  Pt not reporting it as a SE. The pulmonary edema is not expected but not likely related. The hospitalization and the BP seem both to ultimately have been caused by the shortness of breath/edema.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

We do not think it was related to bupropion but to her worsening pulmonary edema/BP (See SAE).

ae_narrative: At S1WK2 on 10/14/19 she reported that for @ the first week after starting Wellbutrin she had a slight headache and dizziness but did not have any falls and it did not impact functioning.  This has since resolved.

At WK 6 on 11/11/19 she reported that since increasing Wellbutrin to 300mg @ 2 wks ago she has noticed she feels more dizzy and off balance.  Example on Saturday she caught her foot on the curb, normally she would be able to catch herself but couldn't catch her balance and fell.  She scrapped her knee but not other injuries and did not seek medical attention.  Upon asking she does not notice dizziness only upon positional changes.  Mainly in the morning.
ae_relevant_info: Dizziness was worse when dose of Wellbutrin was increased to 450mg 1/10/20 to 1/28/20.  Reported 'scary dizziness' but denied falls.  Recommended to go back to 300mg Wellbutrin as of 1/29/2020.   Symptom resolved by the 4month call on 4/8/2020

ae_narrative: At S1WK6 on 11/11/19 she reports that since increasing Wellbutrin to 300mg @ 2 wks ago, she has noticed that dry mouth is exacerbated to the point that it is 'really annoying' and impacts speech.  It was noticeable on the phone.  She will consider trying biotene.  Wellbutrin 450mg made symptoms worse.  So went back down on 1/28/2020 to 300mg.
ae_relevant_info: Symptom resolved by the 4month call on 4/8/2020

ae_narrative: S1C4M by phone 4/8/2020.  She has been having a lot of back pain which has made mobility difficult as was only able to get around with assistance or a walker.  As such she had a fall on 2/18/2020, presented to ER on 2/19/2020 and CT showed fractured coccyx.  She said that her sister & brother-in-law were assisting with ambulation (she hadn't gotten her walker yet), she lost her balance and fell.   Subsequent MRI on 3/11/2020 for general worsening back pain with left foot drop indicated arthritis and stenosis.  She is currently doing PT to help with this and is able to ambulate with a cane.      She said she does tend to loose her balance easily and has probably fallen @ 8x in the past 4 months.

Contacted UP10225 on 8/6 to scheduled her S1C8M decision support phone call for 8/12/2020.    Unable to reach her on 8/12/2020.  She emailed me to let me know that she is currently admitted at a UPMC hospital after a fall down the stairs with a right hip fracture.       On 8/9/2020 she was taking garbage down the stairs and missed a step landing on her right hip.  Immediately went to the ER and was admitted for right hip fracture.  She had open reduction and internal fixation on 8/10/2020, currently still admitted.  Past history includes outpatient surgery on 6/24/2020 for left equinus contracture for which she was receiving physical therapy.     The event is unexpected but not related and is not reportable to our IRB.       Decision support PHQ-9 = 8, reports she was doing rather well until the fall.  Augmenting 40mg Celexa with 300mg Wellbutrin daily.  S1C8M on 8/13/2020.  She had a fall with hip fracture & hospitalization, admitted 8/9/2020.  She has not been working (combination of COVID and surgery on her leg in June).  She was walking in the park, cleaning her house, still meeting friends once in a while, and getting a lot accomplished.  Feels medications were helping.   She did have another fall prior to the one that landed her in the hospital (slipped in  bathtub, did not need medical attention, no injuries).      Fall was not related to opioid, benzo, or alcohol use.  She was given oxy after her surgery in June but not using at greater frequency (and I believe not at all) at the time of her fall.  She had a script for gabapentin but had discontinued that as she felt she no longer needed it.  No alcohol.      At the S1C12M time point on 12/7/2020 she reports she is recovering well.  She continues PT and will ambulate with a cane when going out for safety.

ae_narrative: UPDATE 12/11/2020:  On December 11, 2020 all five PIs further discussed this SAE and its possible relationship with study participation.   On December 8, we circulated a document to the DSMB with our initial attribution of the SAE to study participation as 'not related.'  Upon further deliberation, we think it is more precise to change the attribution of this SAE as 'possibly related.'   Our rationale for changing the possible attribution is in response to the FDA 2011 MedWatch Advisory Safety Communication describing abnormal heart rhythms associated with higher doses of Celexa (citalopram hydrobromide).  This participant had been taking citalopram 40 mg since 2010, but he had not had a repeat EKG (as far as we know) for the past 5 years.  While he had a number of other medical comorbidities, social determinants of poor health (including poverty interfering with ability to pay for antihypertensive medications at times), given his exposure to citalopram 40 mg, we cannot definitively conclude that his death was not a cardiac event that was possibly related to exposure to this medication.  This change in SAE attribution does not change the risk/benefit analysis of participation in the study.   We will, however, continue to be vigilant during the continuation phase for participants who may be prescribed citalopram at doses higher than 20 mg/day, and recommend they discuss with their PCP if they should have a repeat EKG, lower the dose, or switch medications, to promote ongoing participant safety.  Sincerely,  Jordan F. Karp, MD  Pittsburgh Site PI    SAE Reported to the PITT IRB on 12/14/2020 as possibly related.    12/7/2020:  Participant J.FOR is deceased.  I was trying to reach him for his S1C12M assessment and his phone number was not in service.  I looked in the medical records and found this dated 8/14/2020.  Not related, unexpected.      61yo, white male, non-hispanic  past medical history of depression, hypertension, TIA  Consented 9/11/19 at age 60  Randomized 9/17/19 to augment with Wellbutrin  Started Wellbutrin 9/21/19.  Was taking 40mg Celexa & 150mg Wellbutrin as of S1C8month call on 8/3/2020.  Our recommendation was to increase to 300mg Wellbutrin was sent to PCP on 8/10/2020 & approved by PCP on 8/10/2020.    Was also participating in Optimum Neuro and ONSS.      Only other medication was lisinopriL-hydrochlorothiazide (PRINZIDE) 20-25 mg oral tablet    Medical Comorbidities   Valgus deformity of foot  Obesity, unspecified  Essential hypertension  Tobacco use disorder  Generalized anxiety disorder  Irritable bowel syndrome  Unspecified transient cerebral ischemia    Per medical records on 8/14/2020:  The patient had not been to work for a few days, so they were called to go check on him. When they arrived at his house, they unfortunately found him deceased. He was resting in his bed and appeared to have passed away in his sleep. The police stated they to not think this was foul play, and do not suspect anything other than natural causes.    Last contact with OPTIMUM was S1C8M on 8/3/2020.      This was the update from that time point     He is compliant with augmenting 40mg Celexa (2 tablets of 20mg daily) with 150mg Wellbutrin XL qam.  He denies side-effects, health complaints, or falls.  He reports social alcohol use mainly on weekends.  Previously he had some difficulties with obtaining his medications but changing insurance and pharmacy has made his medications more affordable and compliance is no longer an issue.     His depression score on the PHQ-9 = 8.  Daily low interest, frequent trouble falling asleep, occasional low mood, hopelessness, feeling tired, poor appetite.  The current uncertainty of the health crisis makes him contemplate how much longer he will be here, but he wants to value the time he has.  Sometimes feels weary of life and despair from being alone & struggling but denies wishes, thoughts or plans of accelerating death.  Attributes anxiety and difficulty falling asleep from stress/worrying about what's going on and having trouble shutting off his mind.  Still having some interpersonal conflict at work but it doesn't get to him like it used to.  Lately his spirits were lifted by being able to watch baseball again and speak to his kids.        To help with continued anhedonia and anxiety, Dr. Karp recommends increasing Wellbutrin to 300mg daily and continuing 40mg Celexa daily.   James is aware of this recommendation and is willing to increase dose of Wellbutrin, his only hesitation was he would like to make sure this does not change the costs of his medications.  For your convenience, an order for 300mg Wellbutrin XL qam has been pended for your review and approval if you agree with this recommendation.

ae_narrative: Patient presented to ER after having chest pain in bed/exerting self to get out of bed. The pain was substernal, non-radiating, and had resolved prior to presentation to the ER. He was admitted overnight for evaluation. The pain did not recur and tests were negative for a cardiac event so he was discharged the following day.
ae_relevant_info: From discharge summary: '69-year-old male with history of CAD status post CABG, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, Parkinsonism, and CKD presented to the ED for evaluation of chest pain. He reported left-sided chest pain that started morning of admission.  It occurred when he was laying in bed.  It resolved spontaneously and did not return.  He did not have any other associated symptoms.  He presented to the ED for further evaluation. In the ED, CXR unremarkable.  EKG showed sinus rhythm with 1st degree AV block, old septal/inferior infarcts, no acute ST-T changes.  He was admitted for further care.  Troponin remained negative.  Stress test was a low risk study.  He had no further chest pain during admission.  He was discharged to home in stable condition.'

His recent echocardiogram showing some moderate aortic valve stenosis and his creatinine baseline is  1.0 and recently was 1.98 three days ago  And in January the creatinine was normal. His blood pressure  102/68. The patient states that he started with lasix before his last blood work.  He reported that he has had edema in his left leg.  He is being followed by cardiology for congestive heart failure.   The patient reports that he is on 3 different medications for his blood pressures.  Per doctor 'The bottom line is that you are on too much medicine and to balance out your kidneys I want to try these medication changes.  The blood work will show us if this is working.  I also want to schedule an renal bladder ultrasound'

ae_relevant_info: S1WK12 Extra phone support 1/27/2020.  At week 10 she had had a few high anxiety/panicky days but was otherwise feeling good (PHQ-9 = 6) and wanted to put off decision for STEP 2.  Today, she is augmenting 40mg Prozac with 450mg Wellbutrin.  Continues to have dry mouth.  Also reporting some blurry vision (particularly with reading) that started @ a week ago (prescription bifocals are only about 6 month old).  She was wondering if blurry vision could be related to either Prozac or Wellbutrin.  In case it is related to dry eyes she will try some moistening drops.  One partial fall, tripped up the stairs, caught herself with her arm (sustained a bruise), did not seek medical attention.  No alcohol.  Did need to resort to using her medical marijuana a couple times over the past two weeks to help with anxiety.    PHQ-9 = 7.  Feels her mood is steady but still has some trouble with anxiety leaving the house.  Mainly only goes out to pick up her groceries which she orders online and to see her therapist.  She has bloodwork that she has been putting off and intends to complete it tomorrow.  Discussed barriers & plans.  Main complaint is anxiety which then makes her feel bad about herself.  Her anxiety drains her and then she feels down & fatigued.  She reports this has happened a couple times over the past two weeks.  We discussed STEP 2 and options.  She would like to speak with her therapist (appointment is on the 29th) and PCP @ STEP 2 and asked if we could speak again in 2 weeks before deciding to move forward.  Any other recommendations if she does not wish to enter STEP 2?   Dr. Gebara responded:  she could try artificial tears and see if it helps with her eyes. She could try increasing her Prozac to 60 mg if she does not wish to go to step 2. With a PHQ of 7, that may be a good idea for her. It's good she has a therapist to help with her anxiety as well.     Although she did not mention this specific symptom at S1C4M, there is no indication it had resolved.  She was lost to follow-up for S1C8M & S1C12M so there has been no additional contact with her.  However, in a note from her PCP on 11/5/2020 the patient wishes to wean-off Wellbutrin.

ae_narrative: At Extra Wk 12 on 1/27/20 she was reporting some blurry vision and since she mentioned dry mouth, it was suggested that blurry vision may be related to dry eyes and to use drops like artificial tears to help.    On 2/13/2020 she contacted OPTIMUM staff:    From: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>   Sent: Thursday, February 13, 2020 2:11 PM  To: Karp, Jordan <karpjf@upmc.edu>; Gebara, Marie Anne <gebarama@upmc.edu>  Cc: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Subject: Patient Concern    I received voicemessage from K.ALB.  She is experiencing blurry vision and now it hurts.  She has been using drops and does not consider this to be dry eyes.  She thinks it is associated with increasing Wellbutrin to 450mg.  Before I call her back (most likely plan would be to go back to 300mg and see if that helps), I wanted to see if to your knowledge blurry or painful vision could be related to Wellbutrin (not to my knowledge or to our list of side-effects).  She is augmenting 40mg Prozac.  Been on 450mg Wellbutrin since 12/20/19.      From: Karp, Jordan <karpjf@upmc.edu>   Sent: Thursday, February 13, 2020 3:01 PM  To: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>; Gebara, Marie Anne <gebarama@upmc.edu>  Subject: RE: Patient Concern    Hi Joelle,  I don't think this is related, but I am concerned.  Blurry and painful vision makes me concerned about glaucoma.  However, I reviewed her chart, and I don't see anything about glaucoma.  She does not use eye drops.  I suggest she stop the Wellbutrin, none tomorrow, and restart 300 mg on Saturday.  She should also call her PCP and inform them about the blurriness and pain.  Her PCP may have ideas about this.  Thanks,  Jordan    From  JMK:  Okay.  Thank you.  She still feels that it could be related ('I am the type of person that if you are going to get a weird reaction to a med, it is me').    She is on board with the plan to not take any Wellbutrin tomorrow and then go back to 300mg Wellbutrin on Saturday.    She is going to see her eye doctor next week.   Vision has changed that it is hard to see out of her new glasses (@ 6M old)  The drops she has been using are called Sustain (OTC).  She also mentioned increased constipation for which she is using Miralax.    I will check in with her next week to see how she is feeling.    I will update her PCP to let her know we are suggesting to go back to 300mg.

ae_narrative: I called UP10243 to complete her S2C4, and she reported that she had been hospitalized in late July for 4 days with epigastric pain and worsening neuropathy. She was diagnosed with Duodenitis. Unexpected, not related.    73-year-old female who presented for evaluation of bilateral leg pain and abdominal pain. Patient endorsed worsening crampy constant abdominal pain over the past several days to presentation in addition to similar pain beneath her left breast. She said that eating seemed to upset her stomach more and worsen the pain. She had a lot of nausea, but did not vomit. She tried taking laxatives for that maybe she was constipated, but this did not help. She has ongoing neuropathy in her legs, which she follows with a pain doctor for and has had her dose of Neurontin adjusted as is an outpatient. Admission, VSS. Labs relatively unremarkable. Troponin negative ×3. D-dimer elevated. CTA chest without PE, no acute findings. CTAP showed duodenitis. Patient was admitted to the hospitalist service for further evaluation and management.         Duodenitis: Patient was maintained with supportive care including IVF hydration and pain control as necessary. Her PPI was increased to twice daily. She did have improvement of her pain. Recommend that she continue to use the PPI twice daily on discharge and follow-up with her GI as an outpatient if needed.         Neuropathy: Patient was continued on her home dose of gabapentin. We did add in a low dose of Flexeril to try to help with her pain and discomfort while here, but unfortunately the medication's sedative effects made it unsafe for discharge as the patient lives alone. Chronic pain was consulted and recommended titrating her gabapentin back to 300mg TID and continuing the oxycodone 15mg q8 prn. She should continue to follow with them as an o/p. Discussed with the daughter the incidental finding on CTAP of possibly loose pedicle screws at S1. She said that she vaguely remembers hearing about it in the past. She said that although the patient doesn't want surgery she would like maybe getting a second opinion or further workup as an outpatient. Gave her information for NSG.          Chest discomfort: Patient described the chest discomfort beneath her left breast without associated symptoms. Suspect that this was referred/associated with the pain in her abdomen. EKG was without acute ischemic changes. Troponin negative ×3. She had no recurrence of this discomfort.         Hypoxia: She likely has underlying OSA as she is primarily desaturating at night. O/p sleep study recommended. Follow up with PCP.          She was recommended discharge to SNF but declined placement at this time. She will go home with HHC. She was otherwise stable for discharge back home. Discussed plan with daughter on the phone prior to discharge.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: MEDICAL HOSPITALIZATION- NOT RELATED, EXPECTED  At the S2C12M decision support on 4/15/21, UP10243 a 74yo WF, informed staff that she was recently hospitalized for 'intractable back pain and ambulatory dysfunction' on 2/16/21.  She had previously delayed surgery for her back until the end of March due to concerns about COVID.  They rescheduled surgery for 2/26/21 and she was discharged to home 2/19/21.  She was also treated for UTI which was noted during her hospitalization.  Readmitted on 2/24/21 for delirium d/t accidental opiate overdose.  Surgery for fusion & decompression on 2/26/21 complicated by infection.   Discharged to home 3/24/2021.  While inpatient she was seen by BH and Wellbutrin 450mg was decreased to 150mg on 3/26/21 and stopped 4/7/21.  Sertraline 125mg was started on 3/22/21 and increased to 150mg on 4/7/21.  Reported 2 falls (one prior to hx no injuries and one since returning home, falling out of bed due to mobility issues, no injuries).  She denies any side-effects, compliance issues, or alcohol use.   She is compliant with medical appointments and physical therapy.  PHQ-9 on 4/15/21 = 12; MADRS on 4/21/21 = 23.

ae_narrative: 10/21 (ER presentation): '61 year old with a history of IPF s/p left single lung transplant 09/22/16 (CMV R+, alemtuzumab induction) on 4-6 home O2, chronic tremors, anxiety, hypertension, DM2 who presents for weakness and dyspnea.      Patient notes progressive weakness and tremors over the past 3-4 weeks.  He notes difficulty with standing from a seated or squatted position.  No falls at home but has felt close to falling secondary to weakness.  Notes some dizziness that is irrespective of position. He notes muscle and bone pain.  Associated dyspnea on exertion without cough. Denies fevers, chills, weight loss, sweats.      In the ED, patient was noted to be afebrile and hemodynamically stable on 6L.  Labs notable for NA 134, Cr 1.5, Hgb 12.3. CXR with bibasilar opacities COVID negative.  Nursing attempted to get patient out of bed but he was notable weak and unable to stand; therefore, admitted for further management. '    10/26: '61 year old man with a history of left single lung transplantation for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on  9/22/2016  complicated by chronic hypoxic respiratory failure and progressive dyspnea on exertion on 4-6L home oxygen, chronic tremors, anxiety, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, who was admitted after presenting to the ED with progressive weakness, tremors, dizziness, and dyspnea on exertion over the last 3-4 weeks.  In the ED he was afebrile and hemodynamically stable but noted to be orthostatic once on the medical stepdown unit.  Lab work was essentially unremarkbale. Chest xray was suggestive of pulmonary edema and bibasilar opacities possibly related to atelectasis vs pneumonia. Nasopharyngeal swab came back negative for SARS-CoV2.  For his orthostasis, his Metoprolol dose was reduced, his Prednisone was switched to Hydrocortisone, and he was placed on support stockings. His symptoms diminished but did not completely resolved. He was referred to Neurology for possible myopathy given his weakness and underwent EMG-MCV on 10/26. This came back within normal limits.  He was discharged with home PT.  Also seen by Psychiatry because of uncontrolled anxiety and depression. Venlafaxine and Aripiprazole were continued at the same doses and he was instructed to follow-up with his primary psychiatrist.  Immunosuppression on discharge: Tacrolimus (goal: 8-10), Mycophenolate (Myfortic), Hydrocortisone.  Infection prophylaxis on discharge: SMZ-TMP for PJP, Valganciclovir for CMV.

ae_narrative: In trying to reach UP10246 (P.STE) for his S1C8M time point it came to our attention that he is currently hospitalized at the local medical center.  SAE Non-psych hospitalization 12/16-12/23 with readmission 12/31/2020.  Unexpected, Unrelated, Not reportable    FYI from the Medical Records the follow information is available (tx to Presby from MK today)  61-year old Caucasian male with PMH of IPF s/p SLLTx in 9/2016 c/b multiple episodes of acute rejection, PE on apixaban who was admitted to UPMCMK on 12/31 due to hypoxic respiratory failure. Of note, patient had another recent admission there from 12/16 through 12/23/2020 for bilateral pneumonia and treated with a course of IV cefepime and levofloxacin after discharge (14 days total). His symptoms on presentation this time were shortness of breath, cough and weakness. He is usually on 6 L of oxygen at baseline and increases to 8 L and his oxygen saturations were in the 60s.  Patient denied fever, chills, sweats, headache, dizziness, nausea or vomiting or diarrhea. W/u there was notable for a viral swab negative for COVID 19, flu, and RSV. CT scan showed worsening (compared to earlier admission) ground glass opacities on L lung. He was given one dose of vanc and cefepime for 7 days. His O2 requirement there fluctuated from 13 L -> 8 -> 10 L. Given the lack of improvement in his condition he was t/f to Presby for further management.   On arrival here he appears well. VS are normal, with him satting 98% on home O2 requirement of 6L (from 10 at OSH). He said that lower O2 makes him feel SOB but this was not a/b desaturation. He is tachypneic to the 30s. He states that his breathing has been getting worse over the past 3 months. This is a/b rhinorrhea. Denies sputum production. Has an occasional cough. SOB is mostly exertional. The cefepime and levofloxacin did not improve his breathing. He takes his antirejection medications daily. Denies missing any doses.      Histories   Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis s/p left single lung transplantation on 9/22/2016 as above. Induction: Alemtuzumab, CMV R+, EBV R+   EBV status: +R.   Rejection History:    2/2017 A2 treated with pulse Methylprednisolone    3/2017 A1, not treated as PFTs were best    5/2017 A3 treated with pulse Methylprednisolone    6/2017 A3     4/2018 A2    7/2018 A1.5  Pulmonary embolism  Parainfluenza 6/2019  Tremors with Tacrolimus  H/o C. difficile infection 2016  Obstructive Sleep Apnea  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  Depression and anxiety  Esophageal dysmotility with proximal escape, moderate to severe  Chronic kidney disease stage 3 (b/l Cr. ~ 1.3)  Benign prostatic hypertrophy        Past Surgical History   Left lung transplant  Left knee scope  Multiple bronchoscopies  TURP  Left wrist surgery    Assessment and Plan   Diagnosis: Pneumonia NOS (ICD10-CM J18.9, Discharge, Past Medical Hx), PE (pulmonary thromboembolism) (ICD10-CM I26.99, Working, Problem), History of lung transplant (ICD10-CM Z94.2, Discharge, Problem).   61 yo M w/ PMH IPF s/p SLLTx i 2016 c/b multiple episodes of ACR, PE on AC was admitted due to recurrent acute on chronic hypoxic RF w/ persistent O2 requirement despite 7 days of Abx.     # Hypoxic RF. Acute on chronic. DDx is broad, includes infection vs rejection (given CTC) vs less likely PH (given borderline dilated RV on TTE from 6/2020) vs worsening function of R lung and inability to compensate w/ transplanted lung. In terms of infection this is unlikely bacterial since he did not improve with cefepime and levofloxacin x ~ 3 weeks. Was on treatment dose azithro from 12/16-12/21 therefore unlikely mycoplasma or Chlamydophila. RVP swab negative for COVID, influenza, RSV. CMV PCR negative  - repeat SPCx if patient produces any, urine legionella, urine strep, MRSA swab  - repeat covid swab and extended RVP to include metapneumovirus, adeno, enterovirus, rhinovirus, parainfluenza  - will hold apixaban and keep NPO MN in case he undergoes bronch w/ TBBx tomorrow to r/o rejection  - h/o Abx, given lack of improvement w/ 3 weeks broad coverage and MRSA swab prior negative  - can consider TTE if other w/u unrevealing to assess PA pressures  - will get abg as patient tachypneic to look at CO2, has severe restrictive physiology on previous PFTs     # S/p SLLTx.  - IS: c/w tacro 2 q12 (goal 10-12) levels to be drawn at 7:30 as he last took the med 1/6 8 pm, MFA 360 BID, hydrocort 20-10-10 (was switched for higher mineralocorticoid effect due to orthostatic hypotension)  - c/w acyclovir, bactrim ppx  - c/w azithro/montelukast for immunomodulatory effects     # Hx of PE.  - holding apixaban (got last dose on 1/6 pm) due to potential bronch w/ TBBx tomorrow, if not done will need heparin gtt as bridge     # DM2.  - holding home linagliptin  - LDISS q6hrs     # HTN.   - home metop 12.5 BID, will hold in the s/o orthostatic hypotension, consider d/c'eing     # HLD. c/w zetia, vasscepa     # BPH.  - c/w home flomax for now, can consider decreasing if orthostatic hypotension is not improved after d/c'eing metop after d/w urology     # CKD3. b/l ~ 1.3  - will repeat labs     # Anxiety/depression. c/w abilify and venlafaxine and PRN xanax     # Esophageal dismotility.  - aspiration precautions, home zofran, home protonix     Diet: NPO for bronch tomorrow    Home Medications (from 'Document Medication by Hx')      acetaminophen (acetaminophen 325 mg oral tablet) 650 mg Every 6 Hours PRN By Mouth   acyclovir (acyclovir 400 mg oral Randomized augment with abilify  Study meds at time of death 300mg Effexor (index med) and 5mg Abilify  Enrolled on 1/7/2020 (start of Abilify)  Last Assessment S1C4M on 8/13/2020 by Michael Lightfoot      Email from Eric Lenze 1/21/21:  Agree with Jordan in terms of cause, and that it's unrelated to the study.  ________________________________________  From: Karp, Jordan - (karpjf) <karpjf@arizona.edu>  Sent: Thursday, January 21, 2021 11:04 AM  To: Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon) <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>; Gebara, Marie Anne <gebarama@upmc.edu>; Lenze, Eric <lenzee@wustl.edu>; Lenard, Emily <lenarde@wustl.edu>; Chickering, Sunita N <chickeringsn@upmc.edu>; Lightfoot, Michael L <lightfootm@upmc.edu>  Subject: Re: [EXT]RE: Pittsburgh SAE UP10246 (Now deceased)      * External Email - Caution *  Cause of death is likely pulmonary failure. I was planning on calling him today to check on him and saw in the medical record the patient is deceased.  I have not been able to find in the medical records cause of death, however I had not previously seen that he was discharged to home on hospice.  He is a 61yo M.  Study meds are 300mg Effexor & 10mg Abilify.  Last completed assessment was by Michael Lightfoot at S1C4M in August 2020.  He was due for his S1C8M around the time of his hospital admission in December.        1/21/2021 7:04 AM   Post Mortem Documentation    Post Mortem Information   Patient status: Deceased	      Below is the discharge summary from 1/15/2021  Discharge Summary:          Overnight events: None.         Admit Date: 1/6/2021.         Discharge Date: 1/14/2021.         Attending physician: DE LUNA MD, JOY LIN C.         Consult Services: Pulm-Transplant, Palliative/Supportive Care, Rheumatology.         Reason for admission:   See below  .         Discharge diagnosis: Steroid-induced diabetes (ICD10-CM E09.9, Working, Diagnosis), Pneumonia NOS (ICD10-CM J18.9, Working, Diagnosis), Other specified anemias (ICD10-CM D64.89, Discharge, Diagnosis), Other complications of lung transplant (ICD10-CM T86.818, Discharge, Diagnosis), Neuropathic pain (ICD10-CM M79.2, Discharge, Diagnosis), Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (ICD10-CM J84.112, Discharge, Diagnosis), GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease) (ICD10-CM K21.9, Discharge, Diagnosis), DM (diabetes mellitus), type 2 (ICD10-CM E11.9, Discharge, Diagnosis), Chronic kidney disease (CKD), stage II (mild) (ICD10-CM N18.2, Discharge, Diagnosis), Benign essential hypertension (ICD10-CM I10, Discharge, Diagnosis), Acute on chronic respiratory failure with hypoxemia (ICD10-CM J96.21, Discharge, Diagnosis).       Hospital Course   P.STE is a 61 year old man with a history of left single lung transplantation for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on  9/22/2016 complicated by chronic lung allograft dysfunction with chronic hypoxic respiratory failure (baseline O2 requirement: 6LPM) and hospitalization at UPMC-McKeesport 12/16-12/23/2020 for pneumonia treated with Cefepime + Azithromycin then Levofloxacin, who was admitted because of worsening dyspnea with increase in O2 requirement to 10L since discharge to home. He presented initially at UPMC-McKeesport ED then transferred to PUH for further evaluation and management. CT Chest showed worsening groundglass opacities in the allograft lung prompting empiric Cefepime. Nasopharyngeal swab was negative for SARS-CoV2 and respiratory viruses. However, respiratory status continued to decline necessitating HFNC by 1/11. Pulm-Transplant impression was likely acute rejection in the setting of subtherapeutic levels and occurring in a chronically poor lung function from presumed bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome. Prognosis was felt poor. Nevertheless, he was given empiric 3G  pulse Methylprednisolone with no improvement in his respiratory status. He was then discharged to home per his expressed wish on hospice with an O2 requirement of 40L. ae_narrative: At WK 8 on 3/4 & 3/5/2020 she reported that she has had a cold for the past week.  She was scheduled for OPT-NEURO on 2/28/2020 but cancelled because she has an endoscopy scheduled for 2/28/2020 but then had to cancel that because she had cold-like symptoms (possibly allergies) runny nose, sneezing etc.  Her endoscopy is rescheduled for March 11th.
ae_relevant_info: Cold symptoms resolved at time of medical hospitalization on 3/11/2020.

ae_narrative: Saw gastroenterologist on 2/24/2020.  Iron-deficient anemia.  Per office visit:  iron deficiency anemia is related to poor absorption as a consequence of her atrophic gastritis.  However, she does develop large hyperplastic polyps and thus I think it is reasonable to repeat an upper endoscopy since occult blood loss could be occurring as a consequence of these polyps.     Start Ferrous sulfate 325 mg twice a day on 2/24/2020  Endoscopy scheduled for 3/11/2020.
ae_relevant_info: Medical hospitalization for anemia, a-fib, & gastric mass.  Discharged to home 3/19/2020
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: On 3/5/2020 she reports Daily 'restless leg' which she feels has gotten worse, hard to sit still and she will need to get up and walk (not pace) to move the muscles in her legs.  Although she denies side-effects her reporting of restlessness is more frequent.  In addition, her PHQ-9 scores have been creeping up as we have increased dose of Abilify.      Update on 3/23/2020 at S1WK10 phone call:  Augmenting 40mg Prozac with 10mg Abilify.  We had suggested to go down to 5mg but she only did that a few days before Hx Admission.  Received 10mg Abilify in hospital as that was what was officially in her medical records.  Regardless symptoms of restless leg have resolved.  She said her doctors suggested it was related to anemia.  Denies current side-effects

UP10248 was admitted to UPMC East for medical care on 3/11/2020.  She is currently scheduled for S1WK10 on 3/18/2020 and is augmenting 40mg Prozac with 10mg Abilify.    On 3/5/2020 PHQ-9= 5 and she was reporting possible restlessness so we had suggested to try 5mg Abilify and I would check on her on 3/13/2020.  When I was unable to reach her I checked the medical records and noted she was inpatient.  She had been scheduled for an endoscopy on 3/11/2020 as follow-up for recurrence of iron deficiency anemia related to poor absorption as a consequence of atrophic gastritis.    ER Admission note on 3/11/2020:   73-year-old female with history below including atrial fibrillation on Xarelto presenting for evaluation of anemia.  She was transferred from her outpatient provider after her hemoglobin was found to be 5.3.  She reports significant shortness of breath and generalized weakness.  Denies any chest pain.  No new leg swelling.  She stopped taking her Xarelto 2 days ago as she was preparing for endoscopy tomorrow.  She states that she has had dark-colored diarrhea for the past week or so.  No history of anemia or GI bleed.    This SAE is not-related and unexpected and is not reportable to our IRB.
ae_relevant_info: UPDATE 3/18/2020:  She sent me a text on 3/15 to say that she is in the hospital and 'had to get 3 liters of blood.  I also had a heart attack. I am having a procedure tomorrow'.  UPDATE from medical records on 3/18/2020, still inpatient but transferred from UPMC East to Shadyside:    Patient is a 73-year-old female with history of neuroendocrine tumor (resected 2012), NIDDM/hypertension/hyperlipidemia, CKD who presents with nonmalignant gastric mass complicated by anemia and demand ischemia.      #Gastric mass c/b GIB:  -Pathology demonstrates hyperplastic fold or epithelium with erosion/ulceration. No evidence of dysplasia/carcinoma.  -Received 3 units at East, Hgb ~8 for days, no melena  -Protonix BID for now  -GI Consulted, pt NPO  -Holding Xarelto for now     #Demand ischemia/CAD:  -NSTEMI in the setting of anemia (Hgb 5.5)  -3/11: ST segment depression in anterior lateral leads, T-wave inversions in lateral leads, Troponin peak ~6  -EKG normalized, patient evaluated by cardiology at UPMC East, okay for EGD from their standpoint.  -Recommend elective outpatient heart cath after D/C  -Hold aspirin, continue statin     #Paroxysmal A. fib:  -Rate controlled  -Continue Coreg  -Holding Xarelto for now     #Hypertension:  -Coreg, amlodipine     #Anxiety/depression:  -Xanax when necessary, Abilify, fluoxetine     #History of cecal neuroendocrine tumor s/p right hemicolectomy in 2012:  -Chromogranin A level has doubled since 2018  -Gastric mass pathology negative for neuroendocrine tumor     #Type II DM:  -Hold home metformin  -Q6 AccuCheck w/LDSSI while NPO     #diet: NPO then carb  #ppx: SCDs then resume xarelto   Diagnosis: Anemia (ICD10-CM D64.9, Working, Diagnosis), Atrial fibrillation (ICD10-CM I48.91, Working, Problem), Gastric mass (ICD10-CM K31.89, Working, Diagnosis).     UPDATE:  DIscharged to Home 3/19/2020:    Discharge Diagnosis     Anemia    Additional Diagnoses     Atrial fibrillation;  Gastric mass    Surgeries this Visit:      03/18/20 16:06   Surgeon:  SCHWARTZ MD, MARC B                              Surgery:  GI EGD W/REMOVAL OF POLYP/TUMOR/OTHER LESIONS W/SNARE
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: She is reporting some moderate to severe skin dryness/rash on her hands and feet that started after starting the bupropion and has slowly worsened. Not reported until 1/6/20. It is bothersome to her - has been somewhat painful as the skin cracks and peels and her skin is so changed her phone doesn't recognize her fingerprint.

ae_narrative: Pt states that she has been short tempered and less inhibited. She yelled at a waitress at Eat N Park when they said they did not have an baked potatoes. She also called out a friend who was giving her advice.  Dr. Karp talked with her and does not think this is related to Wellbutrin, but it could be possibly related to getting off the lexapro. For now DS is for her to continue wellbutrin 150mg and we will check on her in one week.
5-7-20 pt went to her doctor complaining of headache  and her doctor cut back her wellbutrin from 450 to 300mg qd  5-11-20-  study clinician checked on her and she reported her headache has resolved
bilateral blepharoplasty on 3/10 by Dr. Stefko
feels a little less of an appetite, but is eating the same amount- no weight loss  2-4-20- feels appetite is normal and increased appetite on a few days

ae_narrative: On 2/10/2020- Since increasing to 4mg she is now reporting urinary leaking/frequency (bothersome), increased irritability/snapping which her BF confirms, and weight gain (@ 8lbs) without change in appetite.  She also describes what sounds like restless leg at night (prior to participation) but this has increased recently.  All of these concern her, she relates them to increasing dose of Abilify, and she is unwilling to continue at this dose.  She however is willing to go back to 2mg.

ae_relevant_info: At S1WK8 on 3/5/2020:    Had increased to 4mg but reported urinary leaking, wt gain, irritability, akathisia.  Most have improved).  However, she started the conversation with 'I really don't like Abilify'.  She feels 'flat', just sitting and staring sometimes and generally 'ookey'.  She would like to stop 2mg Abilify.  Main concern to her is daily DFA & SCD.  It has been 'horrible', very restless & broken, not restful.  Also reported daily trouble concentrating and frequent restlessness in her arms and legs (like she is twitching).    Recommendation:  Stop 2mg Abilify.      Emailed Karp & Gebara on 3/12/2020:  spoke with her briefly 3/12/20 for an update.  She stopped 2mg Abilify last week.  Feeling better since stopping.  Continues 150mg Effexor.    By 3/25/2020 Irritability & restlessness had resolved.

ae_narrative: At the S1C12M call on 3/23/21 she said in February she had COVID.  She did not have to go to the hospital.  She was sick for about 2 weeks.  She said the vaccine worries her but regardless she has to wait 60 more days before she can get it.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Reports at the S1C12M call on 3/23/21 that for a few months she has had worsening dry mouth.  It is very bothersome and makes her mouth feel like it is burning.  Biotene only provides temporary relief.    She is still on her index medication of Effexor 225mg daily (increased to 225 from 150 on 3/27/2020)  Other medications include:  Imitrex 100mg which she needs to take a couple times/week  Omeprazole 20mg daily  Vitamin D once weekly  Ocuvite oral daily
ae_relevant_info: I spoke with G.PAR on 4/9/21.  She did reduce Effexor from 225 to 150 on 3/25/2021 due to worsening dry mouth.  She reports that this has helped improve symptoms and she has not noticed worsening of mood.  She would like to continue at 150mg Effexor.  She has completed participation.

ae_narrative: itching begins about 1 hour after taking bupropion, and began when he started taking it. He's taking benadryl to control it. He stopped taking it a week ago, and the itching has resolved.
Reports becoming irritable one day, but after she described it, this sounded very situational (had trouble following her husband's car in the fog the other night)

ae_narrative: JMK response:  Yes she is taking Abilify in the AM.  I essentially went over all of your excellent suggestions on the phone with her over the weekend and suggested taking it with food, routine wake up time, increase activity.    I will report Wt Gain and Insomnia as AE, possibly related, expected.  Heartburn is not listed as possible side-effect to Abilify, so this will get reported as not related, unexpected?  She also is bothered by emotional blunting (mood is flat), is there relatedness?      Dr. Gebara:  Is she taking abilify in am? Weight gain could be due to her inactivity associated the surgery, also going back to sleep in the am when she usually gets up at 4:30 could be contributing to a decreased 'sleep drive' hence more difficulty sleeping at night. She can stay at 5 mg but try to stick to her usual routine for wake up time or delay her bedtime. Also, can she make sure to take abilify with food?   S1WK6 by phone on 2/8/2020.  Augmenting 10mg Lexapro with 4mg Abilify (increased to 4 on 1/25/20).  She ran out of her script early since she was doing 2 tabs of 2mg and sounds like pharmacy gave her a bit of a hassle refilling it.  She contacted her PCP, Dr. Chaney who put in a script for 5mg which she started on 2/7/2020.  She is reporting daily heartburn to the point that she felt like vomiting the other day.  She is gaining weight and reports daily overeating (mainly in the morning).  She also continues to have daily trouble staying asleep.  She also had daily trouble concentrating.  Otherwise, she has not noticed much of a difference on 4mg Abilify.   No falls, reports minimal alcohol use.   She feels heartburn, weight gain, and trouble staying asleep are related to Abilify.  She is willing to continue but unsure about any dose increase.  Thoughts or suggestion to address these symptoms?     PHQ-9 =  11 (previously = 6 before increasing to 4mg).  She reports that she has been waking up around 2:30am and it is hard to fall back asleep.  When she was working she would typically need to be up around 4:30am.  She is currently on medical leave from work for another week & ½ for a sacral hair line fracture.  While she is off work she will wake up and go get breakfast then go back to bed for another couple hours (occasionally sleeping til the afternoon).  Due to her back injury, her ability to do things has been limited which impacts her interest which is still low on occasion.  She can take short walks and has been helping with some painting projects around the house.  She forced herself to go out with friends and it was difficult to concentrate/follow the conversation.  She did not report low mood but says that her mood is almost flat, difficult experiencing any emotion positive or negative.    Decision Support technically is to increase dose further but since she is unsure about doing that and she just started on 5mg, it may be best to hold off on that.
ae_relevant_info: Stopped abilify 5mg on 3/6/20.    As of 4M on 7/8/2020 she was no longer reporting this issue.

ae_narrative: Reported that after switching Lexapro to Effexor she felt 'sick & dizzy'.   She reports discontinuing Effexor mid-January and as of today, 2/25/21 (S1C12M phone call) this symptom has resolved and she denied any current symptoms.      Note per medical record from PCP on 1/19/21:  62 year old female with MVP, post surgical hypothyroid, Vit D deficiency, Vit B12 deficiency, depression here today for dizziness.   She has had intermittent dizziness since starting effexor. She said she noticed the dizziness, headache, nausea while on the medication and so she decided to taper off of it. Now that she is completely off the medication, she still has the symptoms. She said that she felt off balance like she was walking into walls at one point, but this is better.  She went to the urgent care over the weekend and had an evaluation that was normal and was given meclizine to use as needed.  She said she did use this, and it helped with the dizziness, she now has nausea intermittently. She denies chest pain, vision changes, weakness, fever, chills, shortness of breath, vomiting, unilateral weakness.  She did research and really thinks it is from the effexor. She prefers not to be on any medication for her mood as she just got a new job.  She has hypothyroid and her TSH was low on last testing. Her dose was decreased and she is due for repeat blood work  Her brother passed away last week - he had been ill for awhile

ae_narrative: She reports that for about the past year (certainly she feels it was related to when Wellbutrin dose was increased) she has been experiencing intense sweating, constant even at night she feels very hot.  She feels this has been happening for at least the past year, however she did not start Wellbutrin until 8/2/2020 and did not increase to 300mg until 8/26/2020.  All day off & on, everyday she is clammy & sweating.  People have commented.  Sometimes at rest, mainly with activity.  Sometimes needs to change clothes.  She would consider it moderate.  On going at time of study completion.  Although she feels it could be related to the medications, they are working so well for her that she is comfortable continuing on these doses (in fact she is even comfortable increasing dose if necessary).
ae_relevant_info: She does have hypothyroidism for which she takes levothyroxine 88mcg.

From: 'Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon)' <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Date: Friday, February 28, 2020 at 10:30 AM  Subject: RE: JMK PT UPDATES    How do you feel about M.STR taking Abilify later in the day due to the tiredness/fogginess he is reporting?       From: Karp, Jordan <karpjf@upmc.edu>   Sent: Thursday, February 27, 2020 3:55 PM  Subject: Re: JMK PT UPDATES   Continue 2 mg.  assess for substance use.  Thanks!     From: 'Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon)' <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Date: Thursday, February 27, 2020 at 3:33 PM  To: Jordan Karp <karpjf@upmc.edu>, Marie Gebara <gebarama@upmc.edu>, 'Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon)'   Subject: JMK PT UPDATES     M.STR- He sent text on 2/25 saying 4mg Abilify making him very tired/dizzy.  Instructed to go back to 2mg.  Briefly spoke to him today.  Still very tired, slightly confused (that does not seem new).  He is augmenting 300mg Wellbutrin.  Baseline OP-Neuro appt is tomorrow and I will meet with him to get ONSS consent.  Of note, at week 4 he had resumed alcohol use but was no longer smoking marijuana.  Shall I convey anything to him tomorrow (i.e. should he stop Abilify, try ½ tab, etc)?   Week 6 is scheduled for 3/5/20.        JFK response 2/25/2020:  Reduce to 2 mg, please.  May need slower increase.  Thank you.    From: 'Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon)' <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Date: Tuesday, February 25, 2020 at 1:51 PM  To: Jordan Karp <karpjf@upmc.edu>, Marie Gebara <gebarama@upmc.edu>  Cc: 'Kincman, Joelle (Scanlon)' <scanjm2@UPMC.EDU>  Subject: RE: JMK PT UPDATES    Another update  M.STR- Increased Abilify to 4mg on 2/21/2020 (2 tablets of 2mg).  Received a text today 'since taking 2 Abilify a day I feel consistently tired, dizzy, don't want to drive my car for fear of having an accident....'  To my knowledge taking in the morning and has kept Wellbutrin to 1 tablet of 300mg.  Would it help to suggest to take them at night?  Or should he go back to 2mg?

At S1C12M on 3/29/2021 he is concerned about progressively worsening short term memory.   There was some evidence in the assessment but he would also tend to loose track of conversation.   Hard to say when it started but some difficulties noted at S1C4M in which he could not remember if he was taking medication in the pill packs as well as from a prescription bottle.  We did not change medication dose at that time to avoid confusion.  He was also taking a medication for Hep C around that time.
ae_relevant_info: Ongoing at time of study completion.  OPTIMUM NEURO did 6M visit on 4/14/2021.  Adjudicated Dx of Dementia 6/3/2021.  JMK sent PCP a fax on 4/2/21 suggesting his concerns about worsening memory and that we encouraged him to speak with his PCP about it.

ae_narrative: On 2/27/2020- at least for the past 2 wks she has been feeling 'queasy' a couple hours after taking her meds in the morning.  It lasts for @ 1-1 1/2 hrs.  Mild.  It doesn't stop me.  No vomiting.  She does take her meds after she eats breakfast.      At WK 12 on 4/24/20:  She was having nausea so she decided to space out Wellbutrin.  Takes one at 7am and one around 9am and found that this helped alleviate nausea.

She reported at the S1C12M visit on 4/13/2021 that she has been having continued dizziness/vertigo since falling (reported at S1C8M) by tripping over her dogs leash and falling on her face (reporting minor scrapes/bruising).  She went to urgent care at that time but left due to concerns about covid and did not seek further medical attention at that time as she was feeling better.     She is not sure if the dizziness/vertigo is related to that fall or just coincidental.    She did recently see her PCP and mentioned this issue for which a CT scan head/nasal cavities was completed with negative findings.  She will f/u with ENT.  She has not had a subsequent fall.

ae_relevant_info: Phone check-in today, 1/31/20.  Randomized to switch to Wellbutrin.  Was on 20mg Lexapro (which we tapered pretty slowly 10mg x4d, 5mg x 4d, then stop as of 1/22/20).  Started 150mg Wellbutrin on Sunday 1/26.  Continues 50mg NTP qhs.  Took 150mg Wellbutrin x 3 days and stopped.   Felt 'horrible'. Like what she would imagine it feels like to be on speed.  It was scary.  Today these symptoms have resolved and she feels back to 'normal'.  I did confirm with her that she does not wish to try Wellbutrin again or try to 'ride it out'.  She will be INTENT TO TREAT

ae_narrative: I called pt to check in on her since we recently prescribed Remeron (adding to her Cymbalta).  She stated that she was currently in the hospital- apparently her blood tests from her PCP came back and her hemoglobin was dangerously low- she was admitted to UPMC east where she will be kept overnight. She thinks she will need to receive blood.     She had a GI blood.     1-16-21- Discharge diagnosis: Anemia (ICD10-CM D64.9, Discharge, Medical), Cameron ulcer (ICD10-CM K25.9, Discharge, Diagnosis), Dyspnea on exertion (ICD10-CM R06.00, Discharge, Medical).
ae_relevant_info: HGB 5.8 CRITICAL    Underwent EGD yesterday morning, found to have 8 cm large hiatal hernia with multiple Cameron ulcers at the distal end of the hernia in addition to patchy mildly erythematous mucosa without bleeding in the gastric antrum  -Patient initially started on IV Protonix, switched to oral Protonix daily and started on Carafate as per the recommendations of GI status post EGD  -Vitamin B12, folic acid levels within normal limits but Iron studies c/w severe iron def secondary to GI losses  -Started patient on IV Venofer in house- received 2 doses and discharged to PO Iron supplementation  -Recent colonoscopy from October 2020 revealed diverticulosis and hemorrhoids    Dr. Lenze/Karp believe its possibly related since Duloxetine (the med she came in on) reduces platelet function and increases risk of bleeding events, a risk that is increased by concomitant NSAID use as in this case

ae_narrative: 80 year old male participant signed consent for the OPTIMUM A study under the CAMH REB on December 5th and was reconsented using the CTO ICF on February 6th, 2018. He was randomized to switch to bupropion on December 8th, 2017 and began taking the study medication on December 18th, 2017. He is currently in the continuation phase of the study.   The participant's depressive symptoms worsened since enterting the continuation phase of the study therefore, the participants treating psychiatrist recommended he be hospitalized for ECT as this has helped to improve his depressive symptoms in the past. On March 6th the participant was voluntarily admitted to the Geriatric Admission Unit at CAMH. Study staff were made aware of his admission on March 7th, 2018. The SAE is expected and of moderate severity; it is related to the study intervention.
