67 year old male participant signed consent for the OPTIMUM B study on January 3rd, 2018 and re-consented using the CTO ICF on August 23rd, 2018. He was randomized to switch to Nortriptyline on January 11th, 2018 and began taking the study medication on February 1st, 2018. He is currently on Nortriptyline 60 mg once daily and Lithium 300 mg once a day. He is in the continuation phase of the study.   He started experiencing worsening symptoms on June 30, 2018. On July 1, 2018, participant presented to the emergency department at Muskoka Algonquin Healthcare with his son. He was diagnosed with sepsis caused by an underlying bladder infection. He was admitted in hospital for three days. While in hospital, he was treated with Ciprofloxacin and IV antibiotics. He was discharged from hospital on July 4, 2018 and reports the problem as completely resolved. The SAE is unrelated to the study intervention and an unexpected moderate adverse event.  We do not believe the SAE changes the cost-benefit of the study interventions.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

76 year old male participant signed consent for the OPTIMUM A study on February 8th, 2018, and re-consented to CTO version 3 of the ICF on September 4th, 2018.  He was randomized to augmentation with Bupropion on February 14th, 2018 and began taking the study medication on February 26th 2018. He is in the continuation phase of the study.     On February 4th 2019, the participant fell in his apartment and broke his hip. He was admitted to Mount Sinai and underwent a partial hip replacement. He was then transferred to Bridgepoint Hospital where he entered rehabilitation on February 27th, 2019. After the fall, he went into a delirium. The doctors believe this may have been related to an underlying memory impairment. This delerium lifted at the beginning of May 2019.  As such his planned discharge date is now Saturday May 18th, 2019. At the time, the participant was taking Bupropion 150mg and Duloxetine 60mg. A Baycrest RA was notified of his hospitalization by his wife on May 14th, 2019 when they reached out to complete the 12 month continuation call. The SAE is unrelated to the study intervention and of moderate severity. We do not believe the SAE changes the cost-benefit of the study interventions.

ae_narrative: Patient reported not being able to put weight on leg during week 4 decision support call. Patient visited the hospital April 30/18 & had scans done. Patient reported that doctors noted that leg was white as opposed to red, which would be expected for the swelling. As of the time of the call, patient had not received scan results - patient arrived at 2am, & by 11:30am took a taxi home, as doctor who was to read scans was still unavailable (patient wanted to take care of his dog, a task of great personal importance). Patient will follow-up for results by phone. RA will call back to hear results.    RA spoke with patient May 4/18, see box below for results.      On June 1/18 decision support call patient reported his leg began feeling much worse overnight about a week ago. Patient reported noticing pain in different areas of the foot (e.g., mild swelling on upper surface of foot, extreme soreness under arch, numbness). He cancelled his May 31st (4:30pm) clinical appointment with Dr. Flint (where he was also scheduled to do a nortriptyline blood level) because of this. He went to see his doctor/pain specialist that day, who essentially just confirmed it was not gout according to patient. Patient made the decision to use his boot more often.    On June 18/18 decision support call patient reported foot being considerably better, although still not good. Patient reported foot is good enough to come in for clinical appointment with Dr. Flint on July 3/18. RA will follow up to schedule medication blood level for the same day.    On June 29/18 decision support call (extra call #2) patient reported leg not being perfect, but having improved to the point of being 'good'.     Dr. Flint reviewed medical history/updates regarding leg with patient (during July 3/18 clinical appointment) and told patient main concern is severe osteoarthritis/arthritis of the joints.
ae_relevant_info: Patient reported problems/injury with leg two & a half years ago. Went to the hospital & they suspected gout, although could not fit a needle in affected area. Had on & off problems with the leg.     A couple days after experiencing significant swelling, patient when to the hospital & had scans done. Patient reported that CT scan revealed broken bones in foot (he believes from previous injury that went undetected). Patient was prescribed pain killers & advised to use crutches. Due to physical weakness/pain from 2007 injury (see medical conditions form), patient found it difficult to use crutches & is instead wearing a a boot on his foot.    On May 18/18 decision support call patient reported he had visited doctor for check up on leg & was told to watch it & come back in six weeks.    Dr. Flint reviewed medical history/updates regarding leg with patient (during July 3/18 clinical appointment) and told patient main concern is severe osteoarthritis/arthritis of the joints.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

Patient called RA July 20/18 and reported she had felt sick to her stomach the night of July 19/18 (suddenly) and 'projectile vomited'. Patient reported eating nothing out of the ordinary (i.e., had pasta & salad) & although she did not vomit again, still felt sick to her stomach July 20/18. This AE is in relation to pre-study medication (i.e., Venlaxfaxine) patient has been titrating off of as advised by study doctor.
Patient described having 'near liquid' stools a couple days after starting study medication. Patient noted it does not disturb her functioning, but is noticeable.

Patient mentioned experiencing tingling sensations in her legs at her Aug 21/18 clinic appointment & wanted to temporarily discontinue the study medication. Patient mentioned the sensations were keeping her up at night.    RA followed up (Sept 11/18), patient described the sensations as tingling/mini-shocks in both legs. Patient reported that while moving around during the day, she wouldn't notice these sensations (although they may have still been present). Patient mentioned she would usually experience these sensations while in bed, and they worried her.     Patient was to have an extra visit (as she started study medication late), however, she indicated she wanted to stop the study medication permanently (due to the tolerability issues mentioned above). Sensations reportedly began when the patient started the study medication, and had stopped since discontinuing it. Acute phase end was scheduled for Sept 19/18.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: On November 19th, 2019 at 1:20 PM, study staff became aware that the participant was admitted to Sunnybrook Hospital since November 14th, 2019 due to chest pain. The participant described that he had ongoing chest pain for the past month and his family doctor was aware of this. This was exacerbated on November 14th, 2019 at which point he had called 911 for help. He was admitted to Sunnybrook Hospital on November 14th, 2019 and is expected to be discharged on November 20th, 2019. The participant describes that his care included only monitoring and diagnostics and that no medical procedures were conducted for this exacerbation. The documentation for his admittance indicates that he was admitted with stable COPD, non-ischemic chest pain with chronic LBBB, and stable tachycardia (now resolved), and that he was admitted largely for assessment/potential improvement of community supports.

ae_narrative: Patient reported experiencing shaking in his hands, legs, and stomach which he had to fight, but was able to function. Patient attempted to get more on Dec 24/18, but was unable to see a doctor. Patient went to the emergency room on Jan 2/19 (midnight) and returned home at 8:00am that morning. Patient was told to half the dose of study medication (300 mg bupropion to 150 mg on Jan 2/19) and follow-up with his doctor.

She was experiencing a lot of stress around the end of October, which exacerbated the symptoms. She is feeling much better now, however still experiences some mild discomfort.
December 6 2019: The participant reported experiencing constipation every day, which she believes is due to her IBS.

6 December 2019: the participant reported that since she began to take Wellbutrin, she has experienced a significant reduction in saliva production. This was resulted in the inside of her mouth and the sides of her tongue to become very dry, sore, and painful. This is especially true when she tries to eat. She has described the pain as severe and unbearable, and may decide to discontinue the Wellbutrin if she becomes unable to cope with it anymore. She rubs oregano oil in her gum and lips to help reduce the sensitivity and pain.

Since Monday Feb 11, participant has been suffering from insomnia. She can not fall asleep at all during the night. This has presisted in the nights since then (reported on Feb 15th). At th time of the call, at 11am on Friday, she had been awake since 4pm the previous day. She has been able to fall asleep for about 6 hours during the days, but feels extremely tired.     12-Apr-19: Continues to report ongoing insomnia, but reports slight improvement.    26-Apr-19: Participant reached out to ask about scheduling an appointment. Said insomnia had resolved.

ae_narrative: 2 December 2019: The participant's husband called me to inform me that Florence has been experiencing severe pain in her temples, and across her eyes. She described the pain as the worst pain she's ever experienced. Taking tylenol wasn't helping, and applying cold and hot compresses did not relieve her pain either. Her husband contacted Dr. Stoller (family doctor) and Dr. Alsanad, and they recommended she visit the ER if her pain continues. At the ER, they ran routine blood work and CT scan which revealed nothing out of the ordinary. The doctors recommended she discontinue the Parnate, which is the likely cause of her headaches. After following up with her family the next day, they reported Florence's headache pain has already reduced since stopping the Parnate, although she is still experiencing slight headaches.
9 December 2019: the participant has started experiencing very interrupted sleep after beginning to take Parnate. she reports waking up at least 2 or 3 times every night.

Participant reported being hospitalized due to severe diarrhea from food poisoning. She initially went to St. Joseph's Hospital for about 1 week and later a recovery centre for about 4 weeks. She says she was discharged from the recovery centre about a week ago, around May 19th. She has since then been receiving care at a senior's home.
ae_relevant_info: The following report was provided for the investigators. This was sent to Dr. Eric Lenze and Emily at WUSTL with the approval of Dr. Benoit Mulsant.    SAE Detailed Report (Participant: UT10111, Step 2, Continuation Phase):  A 79 year old female provided consent for the OPTIMUM Study (Step 1) on June 20th, 2019. She was randomized to Step 1 on June 25th, 2019. She was randomized to Step 2 (augmentation with Lithium) on November 6th, 2019. She was previously followed by Research Analyst (RA) Jessica Liu until Step 2 Phase End. Currently, she is in the Step 2 Continuation Phase, followed by RA Kathy Zhang.  During the participant's month-4 decision-support call on May 25th, 2020 at 3:22 PM (EST), the participant described being hospitalized around mid-April 2020. She reported having severe diarrhea due to food poisoning. She was admitted to St. Joseph's Hospital for about 1 week and later stayed at a recovery center for about 4 weeks. She reported being discharged from the recovery center to go home on May 19th, 2020. She is currently a resident of a senior's home.   During the SAE, the participant was taking 450mg of Lithium per day and 120mg of Duloxetine per day. She reported that she did not stop her medications during and following the hospitalization event.  The study RA informed the study investigator Dr. Benoit Mulsant at 4:02 PM (EST) about the event and plans for SAE reporting. Upon further discussion, the SAE was appraised as unrelated to the study intervention, unexpected and of severe severity. We do not believe the SAE changes the cost-benefit of the study interventions.      (This detailed report was sent to and acknowledged by Dr. Lenze on May 26th 2020  at 10:42AM)
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: 25 May 2020: Participant reported losing about 10 pounds in the past month, says possibly due to the diarrhea adverse event and being hospitalized.

SAE Report for participant UT10124     I was notified by Dr. Flint that participant UT10124 was admitted to Internal Medicine at Toronto General Hospital, via the emergency department, for investigation of weakness and functional decline at home. Her admission date was October 1, 2019. Discharge diagnosis was hypoactive delirium, cause unknown despite extensive medical work-up. She remains in hospital at Toronto Rehab Institute for physical rehabilitation because she became weak whilst lying in bed whilst delirious. The bupropion was discontinued during hospitalization, in case it was contributing to the delirium.     At the time of admission she was taking Bupropion 150mg/day. Other medications were Senokot 16.2 mg/day, Colace 100 mg twice per day, Clonazepam 0.5 mg twice per day, Eliquis 2.5 mg twice per day, Amlodipine 5 mg/day, and Diltiazem 300 mg/day.      Medical history is atrial fibrillation, pacemaker, high blood pressure, diverticular disease, and constipation.      Severity: severe  Relationship to study treatment: possibly related (SAE started within a few days of Bupropion being started)  Expectedness: Unexpected   AE ongoing: yes
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: On May 12th, 2020 at 2:00 PM, during the participant's Step 1 Month 4 Continuation Call, the study staff became aware that the participant recently completely lost her vision in the past 20 days. For some context:    April 16th: Participant woke up with black spots in her right eye.   April 17th: The black spots persisted, and her daughter called the participant's ophthalmologist and left a voicemail.   April 21st: The black spots had expanded in her right eye and came a little net of dots. The ophthalmologist returned her call and scheduled to see the participant.   April 23rd: The participant's daughter called the ophthalmologist again to mention that the blackness had expanded to a quarter of the eye. The ophthalmologist said to come into the clinic, immediately.  April 24th: At the appointment, the ophthalmologist diagnosed that there is macular hole in the retina of both of her eyes, and the left eye appears worse in comparison to the right eye (which did not make sense to the participant). She was then referred to a different surgeon for a surgery for a later date.   April 28th: Participant woke up and the black spots expanded to half of her right eye. Her daughter took her straight to Sunnybrook Hospital, immediately. She was admitted in the ER and they did some scans and blood work.   April 29th: CT scans revealed that she had inflammation in her right eye (something that her ophthalmologist had missed). An urgent referral was made to a neuro-ophthalmologist, but they were not on-call (given COVID-19). The doctor managing her case in the ER suggested that the inflammation was high, but not something to worry about and the participant was discharged from the hospital  April 30th: Participant returned to Sunnybrook to see the neuro-ophthalmologist and he was shocked that she was discharged the day before and that her condition was much worse than what she was told. She was re-admitted on the 30th but at this point it was too late. She did not respond to the medications that she was given at the time (injections of Prednisone I believe)  May 1st: She lost full sight in her right eye. She began taking several medications including: Prednisone 80mg/day. Sulfatrim, Insulin, and Calcium Carbonate (she was also taking her regular medications: Xarelto, ferrous gluconate, Dexilant, Tylenol extra strength, Duloxetine 120mg, Lyrica 150mg, and Bupropion 300mg)  May 3rd: A biopsy revealed the macular hole in her left eye. She was slowly losing vision in her left eye as well.   May 6th: She was discharged from the hospital and pronounced as blind. The participant's daughter describes that she can only see about 5% from of her left eye and is completely blind in her right eye.
ae_relevant_info: She had a biopsy on her right eye during the hospitalization as well as a CT scan.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

The participant was experiencing abdominal pain and went to a walk in clinic on Friday August 28th 2020. The clinic took a blood sample. On Monday August 31st, the participant was called and told to go to the Emergency Room because her hemoglobin was quite low (in the 60s). She went in for a blood transfusion, which lifted her hemoglobin levels, and they also conducted a CT scan and X-Ray. These scans revealed a cecol mass and the participant was diagnosed with bowel cancer. She stayed in the hospital for 5 days and was released on Thursday September 3rd  2020. Her family physician does not know about the diagnosis yet so treatment has not started, but she will be meeting with her physician on September 18th 2020.    *UPDATE* RA Hailey Wright called on 12-Nov-20 to consent to CovidIAMH study and participant explained they just received a cancer diagnosis. Participant was in tears and the diagnosis was quite fresh as RA spoke with her on 09-Nov-20 and she did not have this news.
ae_relevant_info: Blood test  Blood transfusion  CT Scan  X-Ray
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Patient was low on potassium, calcium, magnesium and other electrolytes. She reported issues with her heart monitor and required hospitalization on March 7th, 2020.    No additional details were provided by the patient.
ae_relevant_info: Patient was feeling better and checked out of the hospital on March 9th, 2020. She will be followed up by her non-psychiatric care team next week.    RA found out about this SAE during a decision support call around 5:00-5:15pm EST on March 10th, 2020.  RA debriefed the incident with a Toronto site investigator Dr. Alastair Flint around 10:15am EST on March 11th, 2020 and with investigator Dr. Benoit Mulsant around 12:51pm EST. Dr. Mulsant, upon reviewing the participant's medication list with the RA, suspected furosemide as a likely influencing factor for the hypokalemia incident.    The SAE detailed report was drafted and given approval for submission around 4:17pm EST.     SAE Detailed Report (Participant: UT10136, Step 1, Acute Phase)  A 71 year old female provided consent for the OPTIMUM Study (Step 1) on November 19th, 2019. She was randomized to Augmentation with Aripiprazole on December 11th, 2019. She began the study medication on January 27th, 2020. This participant is currently in the acute phase of step 1.   During the participant's extra decision-support call on March 10th, 2020 at 5:01 PM (EST), the study staff (Research Analyst: Kathy Zhang) became aware that the participant was admitted to Lady Minto Hospital in Cochrane, Ontario on March 7th, 2020. The participant described that she was low on potassium as well as calcium, magnesium and other electrolytes. She described having problems with her heart monitor and having to stay in the hospital for care. She reported being well enough to leave the hospital on March 9th, 2020. The participant reported that her care team from Lady Minto Hospital will follow up with her next week.   The participant reported taking the following medications:  Psychiatric:  Aripiprazole 5mg, QD  Duloxetine 60mg, BID  Trazodone 50mg, PRN    Non-psychiatric:  Novorapid insulin (insulin aspart), as per sliding scale  Lantus insulin 50 units, QHS  Pepto bismol, PRN  Transdermal nitro patch 0.6mg/hr, QHS  Bisoprolol fumarate 10 mg, QAM  Atorvastatin 40 mg, QD  Aspirin 81 mg, QD for heart disease management  Pregabalin 150 mg, BID  Furosemide 40 mg, QAM for blood pressure management  Pantoprazole magnesium 40 mg, BID  Ticagrelor 90mg, BID    The study staff informed the study investigator Dr. Alastair Flint at 10:15 AM (EST) and about the event and plans for SAE reporting. The study staff contacted Dr. Benoit Mulsant at 12:51 PM (EST) about the SAE. Upon further discussion, Dr. Mulsant suspected furosemide as a likely factor influencing the participant's hypokalemia event. The SAE was appraised as unrelated to the study intervention, unexpected and of moderate severity. We do not believe the SAE changes the cost-benefit of the study interventions.    Because the participant is not a patient at CAMH, the study staff does not have access to her health records for her recent hospitalization. The study staff will verbally ask for the participant's consent during the next point of contact (i.e. scheduled extra decision-support call on March 23rd, 2020). When consent is obtained, the study investigator can access further details about the incident through ConnectingOntario (e-records system).
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: UT10136 Detailed SAE Report  A 71 year old female provided consent to the OPTIMUM Study (Step 1) on November 19th, 2019. She was randomized to Step 1 (Augmentation with Aripiprazole) on December 11th, 2019. Currently, she is in the Step 1 continuation phase.  This participant completed their Step 1 month 12 follow-up call with Hailey Wright on May 6th, 2021. When she was called on May 12th, 2021 to complete the month 12 MADRS, we were informed that she was in the hospital.  The participant's husband described that around 5 or 6pm ET on May 11th, 2021, the participant fell and hit her head, creating a lump on her forehead. To be safe, the husband called an ambulance to take her to Lady Minto Hospital, where she was admitted that same evening. At the time of the call, the husband mentioned that the participant was still in the hospital as they are continuing to run tests, and that she would be discharged the next day, May 13th. He has been in contact with her over the phone since being admitted to the hospital, and he reported that the participant is well and in good spirits.    During the SAE and in the past few months, the participant has been taking Duloxetine (60mg BID), and Aripiprazole (7mg QD).  The study RA (Hailey Wright) informed the study investigators Drs. Benoit Mulsant, Daniel Blumberger, and Alastair Flint at 3:50PM (EST) on May 12th about the event.   This SAE was appraised as possibly related to the study intervention, expected, and of moderate severity. We do not believe this AE changes the cost-benefit of the study interventions.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Please see the Participant Tracking Form and Running Clinical Notes for additional details about the psychiatric consults and follow ups provided for this patient. As part of following up with Dr. Blumberger, the patient was implored to visit the ER to further investigate her physical symptoms. The patient was against going to the ER, fully understanding the risks explained to her, but decided to consider the decision. On May 25, 2020, the participant decided to go to the local ER to be assessed for brain bleeding.
ae_relevant_info: The result was negative, no brain bleeding. She left the ER on the same day, no inpatient hospitalization. Since her follow ups on May 21st and 22nd, she has been followed by Dr. Blumberger at CAMH. Dr. Blumberger provided updates about this patient's progress to the research team and investigators during an internal meeting on May 29, 2020. The patient will be followed by Dr. Alsanad, psychiatric fellow at CAMH on June 3, 2020.

ae_narrative: During a consent call for the CovidIAMH study, the participant described a recent AE. In mid-September 2020, the participant began experiencing horrible pain on their ribs and experienced a difficulty breathing. She described visiting the ER 3 times due to these symptoms, but that they would only give her morphine and send her home. On September 23rd 2020, the participant's physician called an ambulance to take her to the Royal Victoria Hospital in Barrie. They discovered that she had Pleurisy and that the left lung was so inflamed that it was pushing against her ribcage. She was discharged with no overnight stay, and was prescribed 400mg of Ibuprofen 3 times per day for 2 weeks. Around day 7 she reported feeling better. On day 8 after discharge, she received a phone call from the cardiologist who said she had an abnormal stress test and there was damage to her heart. Please see the next AE instance for a description of this second AE.     This AE was described to be potentially due to lying on her left side with little movement from August-September 2020.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

uku_sym_cat: Other Side Effect That Does Not Fit Any Above
ae_narrative: During a consent call for the CovidIAMH study, the participant described 2 AEs that they have recently experienced. Please see instance 14 for a description of the first AE.    8 days after the participant was sent to the ER by their physician on 23-Sep-2020, the participant received a phone call from a cardiologist who described that the stress test done in the ER yielded abnormal results and it appeared that the participant had damage to their heart. The participant is being sent for an Angiogram to inspect the damage, and will possibly require an Angioplasty. The cause of damage was deemed likely due to lying around inside from August 2020-September 2020.
ae_relevant_info: Participant is going for an Angiogram on Friday November 13 2020. Participant was put on blood thinners.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: AE Detailed Report (Participant: UT10143, Step 1, Continuation Phase)  A 61 year old female provided consent for the OPTIMUM Study (Step 1) on December 18th, 2019. She was randomized to Step 1 (augmentation with Aripiprazole) on January 7th, 2020. Currently, she is in the Step 1 Continuation Phase.   During the participant's OPTIMUM Step 1 Month 12 phone call on April 23rd, approximately 10:00AM (EST), she shared that she had a suicide attempt in February 2021. She described that in February (1 month after her month 8 call) her depression had worsened; she couldn't sleep, was losing track of the days and was alone for over a month and a half. One day in February (exact date unknown), she took all the sleeping pills (zopiclone, 7.5mg QHS) and benzodiazepines (clonazepam, 1.5mg QHS & 1mg BID) that she had on hand, wrote a note, and did not plan on waking up. She described this attempt as being very impulsive as she did not have a plan and it all happened very quickly. When she woke up the next morning, she went to the hospital as she felt unwell from the meds. She was not admitted to the hospital.  After her attempt, she spoke with her family physician and she created a contract that states she will not harm herself again. She mentioned that this attempt made her realize how deeply her death would impact her loved ones, and that she does not have a desire to attempt again. Additionally, her family physician is now prescribing her medication weekly through blister packs to prevent another overdose.  During the SAE and in the past few months, the participant has been taking vortioxetine (Trintellix) 20 mg/day and mirtazapine (45 mg/day).  The study RA (Hailey Wright) informed the study investigators Drs. Benoit Mulsant, Daniel Blumberger, and Alastair Flint at 12:30PM (EST) about the event.   This AE was appraised as unrelated to the study intervention, unexpected, and of severe severity. We do not believe this AE changes the cost-benefit of the study interventions.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

She had decreased her Lithium to 150mg on Friday evening and has continued to receive it in the hospital. Reports no progress or new information since being hospitalized.     8/25 Going to have surgery today- has two more vertebrae. Doesn't know how she broke them. They think this has caused her to lose her ability to stand.  She reports she's still getting 150mg of Lithium and wants to increase it back to 300mg. She reports feeling more calm through this process which she attributes to the Lithium.    8/29 reports being transferred today to Oak Dale SNF. ae_narrative: SAE Detailed Report (Participant: WU10029)  69 year old female participant signed consent for the OPTIMUM study on September 12, 2017. She was randomized to lithium augmentation on September 13, 2017 and began taking the study mediation on September 21, 2017. She completed the ten week acute phase of the study on December 5, 2017. She is currently in the continuation phase of the study.  The participant developed a urinary tract infection and was hospitalized on March 15 for her UTI, failure to thrive, acute kidney injury, anorexia, hyponatremia, leukocytosis, and multiple sclerosis. Upon hospitalization the participant reports she had not been eating due to nausea without vomiting, no appetite and was becoming dehydrated. Her creatinine level on March 15 was 1.63, WBC's 29.6, sodium 127, potassium 5.5, and urine with 4+ bacteria. She was also found to have a soft tissue infection to her left pretibial surface. She received antibiotics intravenously with rapid improvement in leukocytosis. Lithium level was taken on March 16 at 05:57 and her level was 1.8 mmol/L. Lithium was then discontinued per hospital staff. She was discharged back the SNF where she lives on March 20.   The participant received follow up psychiatric care with Max Rosen, MD. On Mach 26. He recommended she continue to take Venlafaxine IR 150mg/300mg. He plans to hold the lithium at this time (although did not feel contraindicated if needed in the future) and hold Adderall in hopes to improve diminished appetite.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: Admit Dx: Nonintractable N/V.  4/22 5d N/V/abd pain and anorexia with prominent epigastric and substernal pain with reported brash and globus sensation. 6lb weight loss in past week. Dr. Lynch suspects she developed escalating abd/substernal pain from dietary indiscretion causing aggravation of chronic gastritis/GERD complicated by functional overlay. She also endorsed watery stool.  Plan:  She was started on pantoprazole IV for 24 hours then convert to PO Premedicate with lorazepam and Zofran before meals.  She has a hx gastric sleeve  Will obtain H pylori stool  Fluid d/t dehydration.  Also has modest transaminities that is stable secondary to hepatic steatosis. She is a Hep B carrier and antivral therapy has been indicated. Slight leukocytosis c/w leukemoid response.   She continues to take Bupropion 300mg/Cymbalta 120mg for depression and Dr. Lynch restarted her buspirone on 4/11/18 d/t heightened anxiety.

01/30/19 NRH: I called pt for DSC, but her husband answered and said that she had a stroke on November 12th and is in extended care undergoing therapy. They have no idea when she will be released or how much she will improve. I will get additional info from husband. Serious AE.    Additional info from her husband: She is in extended care at McKnight place. The stroke was on the right side of her brain, so her left side is impaired. She is undergoing physical, occupational, and speech therapy 3 days/week. She cannot walk unassisted, but she is able to walk if people support her on each side. Speech is normal and she can carry on a conversation, but she is having some STM memory troubles, like remembering what day of the week it is or if she did her therapy that day or not. No previous hx of stroke, but her husband said they found evidence of a second stroke so she probably has had a TIA in the past that went unnoticed.    03/12/19 NRH: I spoke to pt's husband today for an update, and he said not much has changed since I spoke to him at the end of January. Dora is still staying at McKnight Place, and he has no idea when she might be released to come home. He told me there is a pause in her physical therapy because she had to have a brace put on her left leg. I will call him again in a month or so just to get another update.

ae_narrative: She describes her mood as pretty good and used the word 'fantastic'  Her sleep is decreased, she is waking up at 3:00am and is unable to go back to sleep and starts doing things around the house and booked the trip to China because she saw 'a good deal'  She describes faster thoughts   She is a little distracted and feels hyper  Reports an increased in goal directed activity such as working in projects about the house, running errands, doing Christmas shopping and is  more sociable.   She also feels less inhibited and more quick to make decisions whereas before she used to be very analytical regarding decision making.     She has a distant history of suspected bipolar and was on lithium for some time but apparently the diagnosis was not fully made.     MEDS: Prozac 20mg/day ( was on 10mg until 3 months ago), aripiprazole 5mg (am)    I am concerned about hypomanic symptoms, and I instructed her to lower Prozac to 10mg/day, stay on the aripriprazole 2mg and I would like to call in a prescription for ambien 5mg HS to help sleep.     Please let me know if this is amenable to you.     Pilar
ae_relevant_info: Hi Pilar,  You asked me to check in with Lynn after she went back on Fluoxetine. She said she has been doing really great the last two weeks! She has been alternating between the 10 and 20mg doses, like you suggested, and she is going to stay at 20mg now. She reported having better sleep, better concentration, and less 'jitters'. Her PHQ-9 score was 5, down from 21 two weeks ago.  She is going to England for two weeks to visit her sister, so she seemed to be in very good spirits. She did not report any side effects from the medication. She said that feeling of constant hunger had subsided, and she has only had a few days over the last two weeks where she felt the need to overeat, so she is very relieved that feeling is mostly gone.  - nrh       I am glad she is doing well, does not seem to be experiencing hypomanic symptoms.     Thanks,     Pilar

ae_narrative: From notes on Epic -   65 y.o. female with h/o atypical meningioma s/p resection in 2009/2017 (A. Kim), recurrent VTE on Eliquis, Epilepsy (was on Keppra until 2011) and DM2 that presents with 6 weeks of arm and leg twitching and altered mental status.     Patient was brought in by daughter and was initially very sleepy in ED. Per daughter, she noticed personality changes in the past couple of weeks and has been more lethargic/sleeping more and complained of arm twitching. Neurology and Neurosurgery were consult for c/f progressive intracranial pathology or seizure activity.      Neurology saw that patient in the ED, who noted that these bilateral arm twitching is worse when she uses her arms and causes her to spill things; these are not similar to her old seizures. Patient also states that she has blurry vision that comes and goes. Per daughter in ED there is also some concern for urinary and fecal incontinence in recent weeks. Stat EEG was performed in ED; intermittent bilateral twitching movements were captured but no EEG correlates were seen with these movements. Per Neurology, this is likely multifactorial in the setting of Lithium toxicity (started 8 weeks ago as part of a clinical trial per patient) with AKI and UTI.      Neurosurgery also saw patient in ED. Noted that she had no new focal neurologic deficits nor acute changes on head CT. Will discuss elective operative planning with Dr. Kim, but noted it was unlikely during this admission and requested brain Mri with brain tumor protocol.     Patient states she started lithium ~8 weeks ago as part of a clinical trial. Per research note on 2/21/19, patient is enrolled in OPTIMUM study for treatment resistent depression. She was started on Cymbalta 90mg + Lithium 300mg for her mild depression (PHQ-9). She states the last time she had a level checked was around a month ago.     Patient today denies F/C, N/V, CP, abdominal pain. She states she has intermittent SOB for which she uses 2L O2 at home as needed. She also states she had chronic diarrhea. She denies numbness/tingling or acute weakness in any of her extremities. She does endorse dysuria recently.      Discharge Instructions:    As recommended by the psychiatry team, we recommend stopping your Lithium until you are able to follow up as an outpatient as it was most likely the cause of your altered mental status and muscle twitching (in conjunction with your urinary tract infection.) The inpatient psychiatry consult team will be in touch with your outpatient psychiatrist to update them on your admission. We also held other sedating medications like gabapentin and temazepam while your mental status and kidney function improved.      For your urinary tract infection, you will need to take cefdinir 300mg for 2 doses tomorrow (take 1 tablet in the morning and one in the evening), and you will have completed your antibiotic regimen for this UTI.
ae_relevant_info: Hospital Course:    #Myoclonic Jerks: Patient's history and clinical presentation felt to be most consistent with myoclonic jerks 2/2 lithium toxicity. She was seen by neurology who ruled out a seizure with EEG (captured myoclonic movements but no EEG correlates) and exam. She was seen by neurosurgery who ruled out increased size of her recurrent meningioma as cause of her presentation; HCT without acute intracranial abnormality and MRI with interval increase in size of meningioma but no mass effect. Patient was then seen by psychiatry who followed her throughout admission. Neurology, neurosurgery, psychiatry, and primary medicine team were all in agreement that most likely etiology is lithium toxicity, and while she had therapeutic lithium levels, these did not reflect her peak level and her symptoms improved as they trended down (1.1 --> 0.9 --> 0.8). Patient's home lithium was held during admission with resolution of myoclonic jerks and marked improvement in mental status. Psychiatry recommended holding lithium and gabapentin for now as they discuss her treatment further with her outpatient psychiatrist.     #Toxic Metabolic Encephalopathy: Patient presented with AOx2 with improvement to AOx4 following 1L LR and 1 dose of CTX. Most likely toxic metabolic in etiology 2/2 polypharmacy (duloxetine, lithium, gabapentin, Percocet) and UTI. Patient's home gabapentin 800mg QHS and temazepam 15mg QHS were held; she was continued on her home Percocet (but half of her home dose) for chronic, severe headaches of unclear etiology. Patient's mental status markedly improved by hospital day 1 and she was discharged home with instructions to stop taking the gabapentin 800mg until she follows-up with pain management, who prescribes her pain meds.      #UTI: Patient was started on empiric IV CTX 1g qD in the ED, which was continued once she was on the floor. Urine culture positive for E coli; sensitivities pending. Patient discharged home on cefdinir 300mg PO BID for 1 day. She remained afebrile throughout admission.      #AKI: Patient presents with Cr of 1.2 with baseline 0.9-1.1. Most likely prerenal azotemia in setting of nausea and emesis. Improved to 0.91 with IVF.      #T2DM: Patient has history of T2DM on home metformin 1000mg BID with most recent HbA1C 7.9 (03/21/19), BG 160 on arrival. She was managed with QID accuchecks and placed on a LDSSI as well as a diabetic diet. Her blood sugars ranged from 106 to 164 while inpatient and she did not require any insulin.      #Recurrent VTE: Patient with history of PE (2009) following first meningioma resection and recent saddle PE and R DVT (03/2019), currently on apixaban 5mg BID for a total of 3 months. CT PE in ED without e/o acute PE. She was continued on her home apixaban 5mg BID and coagulation panel was wnl.      #Depression: Patient has a history of resistant/refractory depression with multiple treatment failures. She was followed by psychiatry while inpatient with recommendations to stop taking the lithium at discharge, continue her home duloxetine 90mg qD, and to follow-up outpatient for further management. Patient and daughter were advised to find a therapist for patient - daughter will call insurance company to see which therapists are covered and will take her mother to appointments.      #Meningioma: Patient is followed by neurosurgery with planned repeat resection this year. HCT showed postsurgical changes and residual/recurrent meningioma (R frontal & temporal lobes). She was followed by neurosurgery while inpatient with MRI W/WO contrast showing interval increase in size of dural-based right clinoid/greater sphenoid wing meningioma. She will follow-up outpatient with NSGY for management, and NSGY consult team noted that they would discuss her latest scans with Dr. Kim

66 y.o. female with pmh of brain tumor, dvt/pe, dm, seizure, osteoarthritis, depression, chronic headaches and recurrent uti who presents to the ER with the above complaint. Pt states she has been feeling slight dizziness and has had two falls in the last two days. She cannot remember her fall this morning but does c/o pain in her posterior head, right shoulder, right hip and leg. She was helped up by family. Pt also c/o headache that is chronic in relation to her meningioma. Pt takes scheduled roxicodone and prn oxycodone. There medications have not helped her musculoskeletal pain. Pt had a recent MRI done on 12/26/19 and is to follow up with her oncologist this week. She follows at WashU with Dr. Campian at the Center for Advanced Medicine. Pt additionally c/o periumbilical pain and has been treated recently for UTI. Pt does report diarrhea but states this is a 'lifelong problem' for he. She denies any chest pain, sob, nausea, vomiting, constipation, dysuria, hematuria, melena, fever, chills, cough, headache, blurred vision, lightheadedness or dizziness. Due to the above she was transported to the ER for further evaluation.    T12 compression fracture (CMS/HCC)  New since 10/2019. Possibly 2/2 recent falls. Ortho/spine has been consulted for which we appreciate their evaluation and recommendations. Prn analgesics. Fall precautions. If non-surgical would benefit from PT/OT.      Recurrent UTI  Given IV Rocephin in ER. Will continue. UA with positive nitrites, 4+ LE ad >50 WBC. Urine culture pending.      Diarrhea  Chronic per pt. Stool studies ordered.      Type 2 diabetes mellitus without complication, without long-term current use of insulin (CMS/HCC)  Holding orals. SSI. Check a1c as last from 9/2019 was 6.9.     Meningioma, cerebral (CMS/HCC)  S/p resection in 2009 and 2017 and gamma Knife in 2013. S/p right frontotemporal craniotomy 10/2019. Follows outpatient at WashU with next appointment this week. Recent MRI with   1.  Recurrent diffusion restricting enhancing soft tissue mass along  the right temporal pole/sphenoid wing, consistent with recurrent  disease.  2.  Evolving post operative changes of right parietal craniotomy and  resection of the right frontal lobe mass with improved surrounding  edema.  Enhancing tissue along the posterior aspect of the resection  cavity with associated chronic blood products and diffusion  restriction is decreased and favored to represent evolving  posttreatment changes. Attention on follow up is recommended.    Headache  Chronic r/t meningioma. Continue home medication regimen.      History of DVT (deep vein thrombosis)  S/p IVC filter placement. On Eliquis.      Major depression  On Cymbalta.      Possible right hip fracture  Xray as noted above. Non-surgical. Prn analgesics.      DVT prophylaxis.

ae_narrative: 66 y/o/f with recurrent atypical meningioma s/p multiple resections (most recent 10/2019) + ETCTN trial, PE/DVT s/p IVCF on Eliquis, DM2, T12 compression fx, recurrent UTI p/w AMS. History per patient's husband.     Per husband, patient has had progressive AMS over the past 4-5 days. At baseline (over the past 3 weeks), patient's mental status does fluctuate a bit but she is usually A&Ox3. Now over the past several days, she has had progressive encephalopathy & lethargy that is also fluctuating. She has been saying non-sensical things, been very slowed cognition & mobility, with difficulty ambulating & feeding herself. Able to swallow pills. Patient's husband is unable to provide a clear history, but also reports episodes where she just stares at the ceiling, appears awake but does not respond to husband's voice. He reports that she also has generalized shaking movements that are ?associated with the staring spells, but then also says 'she's always done that' and that the shaking is not new. Otherwise, has had no fevers/chills, other complaints. Poor PO intake over past 2 days.
ae_relevant_info: DISCHARGE NOTES:    Hospital Course:  GOALS of care  Dr Campian had a goals of care discussion with the family explaining future options.   Meningioma very aggressive, progressed despite radiation, surgery, currently no plan for surgery or radiation, Avastin potential option, but Dr Campian very hesitant to initiate it in the setting of hx of recent VTE. She will reasses the patient after discharge       Tachycardia   Sinus tach, tsh WNL, euvolemic, hds, asx   Started on carvedilol 3.25 mg BID, increase to 6.5 BID at d/c      Acute encephalopathy  Fluctuating, currently A&Ox2. Broad differential; secondary to UTI + polypharmacy + underlying progression of meningioma in setting of tapering off dexamethasone. Chart h/o sz as well. Head CT with known R temporal lobe meningioma & craniotomy changes. UA was concerning for UTI. Continued cefe (prior organisms susc to cefe, h/o E.aerogenes resist to CTX) 3/18-3/23. Urine culture was  positive for recurrent E.aerogenes. Continued Dexamethasone 2mg BID. Continued Keppra 1 q12h. rEEG show ed right focal slowing in temporal region, possibly related to prior craniotomy; there is also mild-moderate generalized slowing, possibly from metabolic/toxic encephalopathy. Held sedating meds (oxycontin & oxycodone). bMRI tumor protocol 3/19 showed right sphenoid wing meningioma that was unchanged in size compared to MRI dated 02/20/2020 but had increased compared to MRI dated 12/26/2019. There was unchanged adjacent cerebral edema and mild local mass effect. Post surgical changes of right anterior fossa meningioma resection with minimal unchanged linear enhancement along the posterior resection cavity.   NSGY was consulted no surgery planned   Continue cipro oral 500 mg BID for a total of 14 days , start cipro 500 mg oral daily after treatment for UTI prophylaxis in the setting of recurred UTI      AKI (acute kidney injury) (CMS/HCC)  Likely pre-renal secondary to poor PO intake. IVF were given, I/Os were monitored and trended BMPs. Avoided nephrotoxins.     Meningioma, cerebral (CMS/HCC)  Recurrent atypical meningioma s/p multiple resections (last 10/2019) + ETCTN trial. 2/20 bMRI with increase in size of meningioma. ETCTN trial d/c'd secondary to tumor progression. Continue dex until seen by NSGY      Headache  Severe daily HA. Held oxycontin & oxycodone.     Hx of pulmonary embolus  S/p IVC filter. Transitioned to apixaban to Lovenox 1mg/kg q12 given questionable swallow in setting of AMS.  Continue Apixiban 5 mg BID as OP      Type 2 diabetes mellitus without complication, without long-term current use of insulin (CMS/HCC)  On metformin at home. SSI was given while IP.

ae_narrative: 4/13/20 SP: Pt was admitted for right frontal craniotomy for tumor resection.
ae_relevant_info: Hospital Problems/Diagnoses:  Principal Problem:    Meningioma, cerebral (CMS/HCC)  Resolved Problems:  No resolved hospital problems.     DETAILS OF HOSPITAL STAY     Presenting Problem/History of Present Illness:  Kathryn L Estes is a 66 y.o. year-old female history of recurrent right sphenoid wing meningioma status post resections in 2009, 2017, and 10/17/19, status post radiosurgery (2009, 2013, 2020), and chemotherapy, on Eliquis for PE, who presents electively for tumor resection.      Briefly, Ms. Estes underwent resection of her WHO grade 2 atypical meningioma in 2009 and 2017 by Dr. Ralph Dacey, with adjuvant radiotherapy completed in 2009, GKR x1 in 2013, and was on avelumab trial until September 2019 MRI showed rapid progression. This prompted resection by Dr. Kim 10/17/19. Brain MRI 12/26/19 again showed tumor progression, and she was enrolled in the ETCTN trial (SRS+Nivolumab+Ipilimumab). She underwent 3 treatments of SRS in January and was on chemotherapy until repeat MRI showed rapid tumor progression. Per discussion at tumor board in February, she is no longer a candidate for RT, and palliative surgery was reportedly planned for 3/2.  she presented to the hospital for altered mental status on March 18, 2020 where she was found to have a UTI.  She had fluctuating mental status with decreased responsiveness, staring episodes, confusion, difficulty walking, headache, hallucinations, increased tremors in her extremities.  She has since been treated with ciprofloxacin and has had improvement in her mental status.  She continues to take dexamethasone 2 b.i.d.     Since discharge, she has held her Eliquis for approximately 1 week.  She endorses baseline headache and nausea but nothing more.  She endorses some urinary burning and frequency which is consistent with her known UTI. She otherwise denies any fevers, chills, cough, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain.  Of note, she fell 1 week ago and has multiple bruises on her arms and legs and abdomen.     Hospital Course:  Ms Estes was admitted to Barnes-Jewish hospital on 4/1/20. On 4/2/20 she underwent a right frontal craniotomy for tumor resection. there was a minor injury to the MCA that was successfully repaired. The incision was closed with nylons. She was taken to the PACU for recovery and then transferred to the ICU for further observation. Patient's roommate was exposed to a COVID positive patient.      Problems addressed during this hospitalization:     1.	Possible COVID exposure: Roommate was exposed to COVID. COVID testing on 4/4 with results - not detected. CTM for any sings and symptoms. Upon discharge, per infection prevention patient does not need to be quarantined.       2.	Brain mass: Resection on 4/2/20. Dexamethasone weaned to off on 4/10/20. Continue Keppra 1000 mg BID.      3.	Acute Pain: Controlled with oral pain medication.      4.	Chronic Depression: Continue duloxetine DR.      5.	Sinus Tachycardia: Started on Coreg 6.5 mg BID on 3/23 at discharge from prior admission. Continue dose in setting of tight SBP control. On 4/6/20, patient heart rate jumped up from the 80s-90s into the 140s after being laid down flat. Patient HOB elevated and heart decreased to the 120s-130s; EKG performed. HR maintaining in the 120s. Medicine consulted. Recommend continuing home Coreg of 6.25 mg BID and follow up with PCP outpatient as needed for further up titration.     6.	DM Type 2: Patient on Accuchecks and SSI while inpatient. Resume home metformin on discharge.      7.	Hx Recurrent PE: Patient on home Eliquis. Per neurosurgery holding for 3 weeks. Medicine recommended lovenox 40 mg daily as a bridge until patient able to resume Eliquis.      Procedures:     1.	4/2/20- right frontal craniotomy for tumor resection.     Consults:     1.	ID- for questions regarding Covid exposure  2.	Medicine- consulted for hx sinus tachycardia with episode of HR in 140s after position change     GI/GU Concerns:     1.	Tolerating a diabetic diet  2.	Last bowel movement was on 4/6/2020.   3.	Foley removed on 4/3, now voiding spontaneously.      Therapy recommendations:     Rehabilitation but family took home      Incision:     Non-absorbable sutures     Surgical drains:     JP removed on 4/3/20.     Notable medications:     1.	Pain medications: Gabapentin 300mg PO Q HS, Acetaminophen 650mg PO Q4 PRN, and Oxycodone 5mg PO Q4 PRN  2.	Steroids: Dexamethasone off by 4/10    3.	Antibiotics: None  4.	Anticoagulation/antiplatelet agents: eliquis 5mg BID restart in 3 weeks on 4/23  5.	Anti-epileptic drugs:Keppra 1000mg BID     Follow-up:     - Neurosurgery: Dr. Kim tasked for 2 weeks for nylon suture removal.     Active Issues Requiring Follow-up:  - Surgical Pathology is pending      Test Results Pending at Discharge:  Pending Labs    	Order	Current Status   	Surgical pathology	In process           Operative Procedures Performed:  Procedure(s):  CRANIOTOMY For Tumor Resection     Other Procedures:  None     Pertinent Test Results:   - 4/4/20 MRI- Interval resection of right sphenoid wing meningioma without evidence suggest recurrent/residual tumor. Evolving postoperative changes of right anterior fossa meningioma resection with minimal unchanged linear enhancement along the  posterior resection cavity.     - 4/2/20 CTA- Postsurgical changes of right frontal craniotomy for resection of the right anterior fossa and sphenoid making meningioma with moderate to large size pneumocephalus along the right frontal craniotomy and  pneumocephalus and hemorrhage in the right middle cranial fossa with adjacent encephalomalacia and edema. Irregularity of the right MCA from recent repair with narrowing of the M2 branch which remains patent

ae_narrative: 4/13/20 SP: Pt presented to ER for confusion and failure to thrive.    Hospital Course:  Problems addressed during this hospitalization:     1.	Lethargy/confusion- CT showing postoperative changes, nothing acute. UA negative except some yeast. Patient urine output low and fluids given. Patient became more alert and back to baseline at discharge. She was eating and drinking with encouragement. Had lengthy discussion x2 with daughter Deedra regarding importance of encouraging/forcing fluids and she voiced understanding and wanted her to return home instead of snf placement.      2.	Yeast on UTI- given a dose of diflucan. Repeat UA showed no yeast.
ae_relevant_info: Presenting Problem/History of Present Illness:  Kathryn L Estes is a 66 y.o. female with a history of recurrent PE on eliquis that is currently being held who was recently admitted to the neurosurgery service for a repeat resection of a recurrent right sphenoid wing meningioma on 4/2/2020 with Dr. Albert Kim. The patient's post operative course was complicated by sinus tachycardia for which medicine recommended continuing her home coreg, and by exposure to a COVID+ roommate; a COVID test was sent and returned negative. The patient was discharged home on POD#5 with her daughter, Deedra, who is a psychiatric nurse.      The patient now presents to the ED after experiencing failure to thrive at home, and new confusion and speech difficulty. The patient is unable to effectively participate in interview, so all information is obtained via phone conversation with the patient's daughter.  The patient has reportedly been having difficulty with eating and drinking since being discharged from the hospital.  It became especially bad on Friday evening, when the patient also developed worsening confusion.  The patient's daughter believes that the patient's confusion is related to her decreased p.o. intake.  The patient has been complaining of headaches and generalized aches since discharge but has not had any associated vomiting, new weakness, or obvious seizures.  Today, the patient had worsening difficulty with speech and has been having trouble with tasks such as how to hold and use a fork or how to use a water bottle.  The patient's daughter noticed that the patient had some facial flushing earlier today, and reported increased temperature of 100° F today.  The patient has not had any difficulty with new cough or shortness of breath.  The patient has been compliant with all of her medications, including her Keppra.  Notably, the patient's Eliquis is currently being held in the setting of her recent craniotomy.

ae_relevant_info: HPI:  78 yo male with a history of falls for years presents from home where he had another fall last night and was too weak to get himself up from the floor. States his walker rolled out from under him, landed with the legs upright.  When he fell, the legs of the walker jabbed him in his right anterior lower ribs.. He had hit his head and bruised his arm and back 3 weeks ago during that fall.      Wife states he has complained of headache for weeks. Also patient notes constipation, has not had a bowel movement since Friday and has been moving bowels every 4 days. He notes mild mid abdominal pain. He also notes he had a nosebleed Saturday morning lasting half the day. And the wife notes decreased oral intake since he had a tooth pulled out 2 weeks ago and another dental abscess treated with root canal. Wife thinks he may have lost weight. She also notes that when the patient was taking pain medications for back pain one year ago, he was having more frequent falls.      In the ED, lab was notable for GFR of 55 consistent with chronic kidney disease stage 3, elevated MCV but normal hemoglobin, WBC 11, negative head CT except mildly enlarged ventricles with cortical atrophy

ae_relevant_info: Notes from PCP visit on 1/14/2020:    'Generalized anxiety disorder with panic attacks  Assessment & Plan:  Let try taking no more than 1 Xanax (alprazolam) per daytime and lets try adding Buspar (buspirone) with a range of 5-15 per dose in place of when you would use the Xanax (alprazolam) traditionally, such as panic attacks or insomnia.  I would take 5-10 mg of melatonin at bedtime if the buspirone isn't helping.  Give us feedback on how things are working.  There may be a time period where the other sleeping medications aren't as effective as you are on not taking the high dose of Xanax (alprazolam) 2mg at bedtime.  I MADE IT VERY CLEAR TO PATIENT THAT THE COMBINATION OF MEDICATIONS THAT SHE WAS TAKING IS DANGEROUS AND CAN LEAD TO A FATAL APNEA FROM A CENTRAL SLEEP APNEA.'

ae_narrative: Newly diagnosed with diabetes (type II), started on metformin; Per Ginger: there are case reports that blood sugars do worsen on antipsychotics if people were already on the path to diabetes. In this case, she technically was already diabetic (you only need one fasting glucose of >126) when starting the study and the worsening of blood sugar would have occurred regardless of antipsychotic exposure.
ae_relevant_info: Fasting glucose 8/8/18 was 140. Fasting glucose 6/21/19 was 143, 7/18 was 273, 7/19 was 246, and 8/16 was 172.    Started aripiprazole on 4/6/19; stopped aripiprazole 7/24/19.

Hospitalized for diarrhea and weakness
ae_relevant_info: Presenting Problem/History of Present Illness:  72 year old woman with severe rheumatoid arthritis (on MTX) with h/o of multiple fractures and orthopedic surgeries including bilateral knee replacements, bilateral shoulder replacements and back surgeries. Patient has a history of infected hardware in left TKA an has been on suppressive therapy (cipro 500mg PO BID + minocycline 100mg PO BID) since 2009.     Patients initial left total knee arthroplasty (TKA) took place in 2002. In 2009 she had left knee prosthetic joint infection, treated with with 6 weeks of Vancomycin for 6 weeks x2 followed by suppression with minocycline and ciprofloxacin, she had recurrent infection in 2012 and 2013. She does have chronic skin discoloration as a result of the minocycline. Patient has history of multiple falls most recent in December 2018. She reports she was in her usual state of health up until 3 days ago when she began having  episodes of  diarrhea, loose stools, non-bloody, crampy diffuse epigastric abdominal pain, no mucus or pus noted. She reports some nausea but denies any vomiting. She reports having usual daily bowel movements, formed stool prior tol.  Reports that the day prior to admission she felt generalized weakness and had difficulty transferring to toilet, and called EMS.  She reports she last ate yesterday afternoon without vomiting. Patient has a significant history of 3 small bowel obstructions s/p 3ft resection of small bowel and anastomosis. At baseline patient is wheelchair bound and lives at home with her husband who is disabled due to stroke, they have home health services at home daily.     In the ED patient was afebrile, hypertensive to 170s/100s, given Coreg 25 mg, 1g tylenol, IV Zofran for nausea and placed on IVF maintenance 100 ml/h.  Labs notable for lactate 2.2, WBC 10. CT AP obtained in the ED which showed  postsurgical changes of small bowel resection with anastomosis. The colon is normal.  No evidence of obstruction.      Hospital Course:  Felicia Buchlotz is a 72 year old female with significant past medical history of severe rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis, and chronic antibiotic therapy (managed by Dr Kirby Surgery) who presented to Barnes Jewish Hospital ED with watery, non-bloody diarrhea (4-6 times/day) for the past three days and generalized weakness due to dehydration.        Acute diarrhea.   Patient presented with three-day history of non-bloody, watery diarrhea (occurring 4-6 times per day), generalized weakness, diffuse abdominal cramping, and nausea. Upon admission to the ED, patient was afebrile and hypertensive (170s/100s). Given chronic history of immunosuppression, concerning for infectious diarrhea with differential including c. diff and viral gastroenteritis. In ED, patient was given IV Zofran for nausea and IV fluid volume repletion and maintenance therapy, and placed on a clear liquid diet. CT abdomen and pelvis showed postsurgical  changes of small bowel resection with anastomosis.  The colon is normal.  No evidence of obstruction. Patient reported 1 soft bowel movement on late Monday night, which was negative for occult blood On Tuesday, patient reported that abdominal cramping and nausea had resolved. Diet was advanced from clear liquid to regular diet, which patient tolerated well with no diarrhea, abdominal cramping or nausea. Generalized weakness has improved since admission. C- diff stool assay was negative. Lactate down trended from 2.2 to 1.1.     Hypertension  Patient has a long history of HTN that is currently controlled at home with carvedilol 25mg, lisinopril 20mg, and furosemide 20 mg. During hospital stay, Lasix were held due to low volume status and lisinopril was held in the setting of AKI. Continued carvedilol 25 mg twice a day throughout hospital stay. Plan to restart Lisinopril on discharge, further management per outpatient pcp.     AKI  Patient with Cr. 0.65 at baseline. On presentation, BUN 53, Cr. 1.01, likely in the setting of poor PO intake due to abdominal pain and diarrhea. Patient placed on IVF and Cr. resolved to 0.61 on day of discharge.     Prosthetic joint infection  Patients initial left total knee arthroplasty (TKA) took place in 2002. In 2009 she had left knee prosthetic joint infection, treated with with 6 weeks of Vancomycin for 6 weeks x2 followed by suppression with minocycline and ciprofloxacin, she had recurrent infection in 2012 and 2013. She does have chronic skin discoloration as a result of the minocycline. She is followed by Dr. Kirby Surgery. She was continued on her home regimen of Cipro 500 mg bid/Minocycline 100 mg bid. Wound care was consulted for R lower leg wound, who recommended using Dakins damp gauze, cover dry, secure with tape. Change BID and PRN. For 3 days.     Major depression  Patient was continued on home regimen of Bupropion 150 mg BID, and her mood remained stable throughout admission

ae_narrative: Fell when transferring from toilet to wheelchair
ae_relevant_info: Felicia A Bucholtz is a 72 y.o. female with h/o HTN, RA on MTX, prior left hip, left knee and right knee replacement, spinal stenosis presenting with right leg pain after her right leg 'gave out' causing her to fall while transferring from toilet to chair. She denies LOC or hitting her head. She reports denies other recent falls. She has scattered dark areas on her skin from minocycline-induced hyperpigmentation. Currently she c/o right hip/upper leg pain. She has not ambulated since this fall since she could not get up unassisted. She was able to call EMS right after falling. She also reports recent chest pressure and dyspnea with exertion but denies fever, chills, cough, n/v/d, abdominal pain, dysuria, weakness, numbness.

ae_narrative: Patient presented to ED on 8/20/2019 after experiencing a fall likely caused by viral URI/viral pharyngitis. She was admitted 8/21/2019 with generalized weakness. She was found to have NSTEMI with left heart catheterization on 8/23. Transferred to ICU on 8/27 for persistent hypoglycemia and systolic heart failure. Pt elected to change code status on 8/29/19 and requested hospice care on 8/30/19. She continued to decline and was pronounced dead on 9/2/19 at 21:23. Cause of death: Acute systolic HF 2/2 takasubo's cardiomyopathy
ae_relevant_info: HPI assessed 8/20/2019: 72-year-old female with extensive history including rheumatoid arthritis status post multiple joint replacements including bilateral shoulders, bilateral knees and right hip with course complicated by osteomyelitis/prosthetic joint infection now on chronic antibiotics, minocycline and follows with infectious disease presents with 3-4 days of sore throat.  Patient has had decreased p.o. Intake secondary to the sore throat.  She denies fevers or chills.  Symptoms of sore throat a been getting worse for last 3-4 days.  Today while she was going to the bathroom she felt her right leg started to give out on her so she lowered herself down to the ground and then was unable to get up.  She was in between her wheelchair and the wall.  She denies any pain from the fall, did not hit her head or lose consciousness.  Patient called EMS with difficulties getting up because she was pinned between the wheelchair and the wall.  She is also believes that she has urinary tract infection.  She is currently asymptomatic with no hematuria, dysuria, urinary frequency however she last time she was in the hospital she was diagnosed with a UTI  and given Cipro which is a medication that she is chronically on as prophylaxis for her osteomyelitis and joint infections.  Patient has also had clear rhinorrhea     Patient otherwise denies headache, facial pain, neck pain, chest pain, cough, shortness of breath.  She has had no nausea vomiting or abdominal pain.  She denies change in bowel or urinary habits.  Patient denies new weakness compared to her baseline.  She is endorsing some back pain but it is spasmodic in nature and has been experiencing spasms for the last 1-2 weeks, no acute changes today.

Pt with long history of persistent atrial fibrillation, ongoing prior to study. A-fib failed to respond to medication. Pacemaker placed 9/5/19 due to marked increase in SOB and dypsnea with minimal exertion. After placement, pt denied chest pain, lightheadedness, and syncope.
ae_relevant_info: Note from cardiologist on 9/5/19: She is quickly developing worsening heart failure symptoms. Her heart rate control is poor despite increasing doses of metoprolol. I am very worried that she is developing a tachycardia induced cardiomyopathy. The only treatment option left available is AV node ablation and permanent pacing to allow for definitive ventricular rate control. We will plan to perform an echocardiogram at the time of her procedure to determine if a biventricular device is appropriate. Because of her decompensating heart failure symptoms this will be performed tomorrow.'    Cardiology history from 9/5/19: The patient is a 61-year-old woman with a long history of atrial   fibrillation. She has undergone multiple ablation procedures in the past.   She has failed all antiarrhythmic drug therapy to maintain sinus rhythm.   She has been treated with ventricular rate control and anticoagulation for   approximately the past six months. Unfortunately, adequate ventricular   rate control has not been able to be obtained. Over the past month, she   has complained of a marked increase in her shortness of breath and has   dyspnea with minimal exertion. Echocardiogram shows mild global LV   dysfunction with an ejection fraction of approximately 45-50%. She now   undergoes AV node catheter ablation for definitive ventricular rate   control and implantation of a biventricular pacing system.

LEFT HEART CATHETERIZATION WITH CORONARY ANGIOGRAPHY
ae_relevant_info: Presenting Problem/History of Present Illness:  63 y/o male with a history of Peripheral vascular disease s/p balloon angioplasty to the right superficial femoral artery in July 2019, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea on CPAP, HIV, well controlled, partial colectomy in 2016, Rectourethral fistula s/p repair 2003, Depression  and obesity who is experiencing angina with decreasing exertion. He underwent a myocardial scintigraphy which did not reveal and ischemic defects. He persisted with symptoms even though his medicines were titrated. As a result he is being referred for coronary angiography./     Hospital Course:  Mr. Typer underwent LHC via the R radial artery. He was found to have severe CAD in his LAD and his second, small OM. He underwent 2xDES to the mid-LAD for a 90% lesion. He was admitted for observation afterwards due to chest pain during the procedure. He was chest pain free by discharge. He was prescribed clopidogrel on discharge.      Active Issues Requiring Follow-up:  Continue aspirin indefinitely  Continue plavix for at least a year  Defer increasing his statin dosage to his primary cardiologist due to interaction between statins and his HAART     Test Results Pending at Discharge:     Operative Procedures Performed:  Procedure(s):  LEFT HEART CATHETERIZATION WITH CORONARY ANGIOGRAPHY AND WITH OR WITHOUT LEFT VENTRICULOGRAM 93458

Patient presented to St Luke's ED on 7/16/20 with severe, persistent right flank pain. CT scans indicated a kidney mass. Surgical removal took place as scheduled on 7/23/20; however the mass had grown even since the scan one week prior. The patient's kidney, adrenal gland, and portions of an artery were removed and found to indicate Stage 4 cancer. She recovered from the surgery without issue and was discharged home on 7/25/20. She continues to receive follow-up monitoring. Her surgeons have indicated that the surgical removal was successful. Records are not immediately available since all care occurred outside of WU/BJC system.

5/4/20 SP: Hospitalized for small bowel obstruction on 5/2. Surgery on 5/3 (EXPLORATORY LAPAROTOMY, Possible bowel resection REPAIR INCISIONAL HERNIA)
ae_relevant_info: Hospital Course:  The patient is a 60 y.o. F with PMH of HTN and multiple prior abdominal surgeries including C-section x3, prior weight loss surgery x4 with reported biliopancreatic diversion in 2001 along with subsequent hernia repair who presents to OSH ED w/ 2d Hx of N/V and abdominal pain.  At OSH  she was found to have acute renal failure CR 1.27 on admission WBC 23.0, Hb 16.0, Cr 1.27 and Lactate of 2.4. CT A/P showed significantly dilated small bowel - appearing to be BP limb with proximal dilation to level of anastomosis in RLQ. She was transferred to BJH for further care.  The patient was NPO & NGT to Low intermittent suction.  IVF resuscitation: 1L LR bolus, MIVF @ 125ml/hr.  COVID screening questions negative.  PPX: SCD, SQH, PPI.  The patient was taken to the operating room and underwent a Exploratory laparotomy, adhesiolysis, small bowel resection with revision of ileoileostomy, and incisional hernia repair.   The patient tolerated the procedure.  The patient was placed on pain medications which controlled the patients pain.  The patient was placed on Heparin and SCD for DVT prophylactics.  The patient was started on a Bariatric 1 liquid diet and advanced to a Bariatric 2 diet , then Bariatric 3 diet which the patient tolerated.  The patient was seen by the dietician for diet education.  The patient had return of bowel function.  The patient had lactic acidosis on admission which resolved. Acute renal failure on admission CR 1.7 which resolved after fluid resuscitation  And Cr 0.59 at discharge. The patient has home blood pressure cuff at home and instructed to take blood pressures at home and keep a log as the patient had on low end blood pressures and is only on home metoprolol.  Amlodipine 10 mg q d, losartan 25 mg q d and spirolactone 100 mg q day were stopped at discharge and patient to follow up with PCP in 1 week.  Once the patient was tolerating diet, ambulating in hallway, pain controlled the patient was stable for discharge.

ae_relevant_info: Phoebe Pinkerton is a 70 y.o. female with history of lymphoma presenting for evaluation of new onset atrial fibrillation/flutter. Earlier this morning, the patient was visiting Dr. Cayabyab-Loe (primary care) for evaluation of cloudy urine, urinary frequency, and urinary urgency. During triage vitals in the office, the patient was found to be in atrial fibrillation/flutter; rate 156. She did not have chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or back pain at that time. The patient was sent to the ED for evaluation. For the past 6 months, the patient has experienced gradually worsening dyspnea and low back pain with exertion. The patient also complains of bilateral pedal edema over the past few months. Currently in the ED, the patinet is resting comfortably in the stretcher; heart rate is 100-110s. Denies any shortness of breath at rest. Denies any chest pain or palpitations. Denies any lower extremity pain. Denies any nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Denies any hematuria. Denies any fever, diaphoresis, or chills. Denies any recent travel or trauma. Denies any anticoagulation therapy.     Time: 02/11 1553  Comment: She remained in a sinus rhythm here.  Labs unremarkable, than a mild leukocytosis.  D-dimer, though greater than 500, was still less than 10 times her age.  Per Dr. Cayabyab-Loe, urinalysis in the office revealed pyuria, and she requests that we start the patient on Cipro.  Patient will call the office and will be referred to cardiology.  She was discharged from the emergency department with a 48 hour Holter monitor.  By: Samuel A. Ockner, MD

ae_narrative: 4/13/20 SP: Pt presented to ER on 4/10 for body aches and fever. COVID test negative. Diagnosed with viral pneumonia
ae_relevant_info: HPI   66-year-old male referred to the ED for evaluation of body aches as well as fever.  He also states he has been extremely fatigued for the last several days and has also had difficulty walking.  He also has decreased appetite and states food has no taste.  Patient states the fever started earlier this evening around 0930.  He states he is having body aches across his back shoulders as well as his abdomen.  He states he spiked a fever to 102.8 and took Tylenol.  He denies any cough chest pain shortness of breath nausea vomiting diarrhea.  He states he is urinating more frequently but denies any dysuria.  No sick exposures he has no history of diabetes coronary artery disease he immunosuppressive state.  He does take antihypertensive medications     ROS:  ENT: No sore throat,  ear pain   CV: No chest pain, syncope  Pulm:  No shortness of breath,  cough  GI: No abdominal pain, no vomiting  GU: No dysuria, no hematuria  MSK: No back pain,  neck pain  Integ:  No rashes  Neuro:  No headache,  focal weakness     Review of systems per HPI and otherwise all other systems are negative unless otherwise documented        Exam:     Vital Signs reviewed.  Genl: Non-toxic appearance  HEENT:  EOMI, Mucous membranes moist. Neck supple w/o LAD or meningismus.  CV: RRR, no m/g/r; 2+ radial pulses b/l.  Pulm: CTAB, Respirations unlabored.  GI:  Soft, NT, ND.  Ext:  No tenderness, no edema.  Neuro:  Grossly non-focal neuro exam; face symmetric, speech clear, moves all extremities well.  Skin: warm, dry.  no rash.   Psych:  Normal mood and affect.      Family Hx :NC     MDM:     High probability:  Viral syndrome URI pneumonia COVID-19 UTI dehydration a KI electrolyte imbalance plan for blood cultures basic labs chest x-ray COVID-19 swab IV fluid reassess anticipate likely discharge home if workup is negative.

ae_narrative: 4/13/20 SP: Pt presented to ER for abdominal pain, diagnosed with typhlitis
ae_relevant_info: HPI:     63 y.o. male who comes to MBMC ED for evaluation of abdominal pain since last night at 8:00pm. The patient reports sudden sharp epigastric pain but denied fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, cough, shortness of breath, or recent travel. He has been constipated for the past 2-3 days and took some OTC stool softener w/o relief.      In the ED he presented with a potassium of 5.8, serum Cr of 8.00, normal liver enzymes, WBC of 16,000, Hgb of 9.6 g/dL, and normal PLT. CT scan of abdomen/pelvis showed air in the intra-hepatic portal venous system with pneumatosis involving the cecum, distal ileum thickening, and bladder thickening. Colorectal surgery and nephrology were consulted in the ED. The patient is being admitted for further evaluation and management.      Past Medical History:   Significant for OSA on CPAP, Morbid obesity, ESRD on HD, Hypertension, anemia of CKD,  S/p Left AKA, type 2 diabetes mellitus, Depression, PAF, and dyslipidemia.      The patient does not have advanced directives but wishes to be Full Code.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

ae_narrative: 63 y.o. male admitted from ED with with worsening buttocks rash, and pain. Diarrhea has been chronic, but now patient has fecal incontinence. Pt was found to be septic in the ED, started on antibiotics after blood cultures were obtained. Patient had CT pelvis which shows concerning areas for necrotizing fasicitis. Pt had debridement procedure on perirectal absess on 7/13/2020, then incision and drainage of same on 7/20/2020.
ae_relevant_info: Discharge Summary:   Patient is a chronically ill 63 yo male with an underlying history of esrd on HD, morbid obesity, left aka, dm 2, chronic diarrhea who presented to MBMC on 7/13 with a chief complaint of a buttock rash.  Patient had reported diarrhea and incontinence.   Patient was admitted with significant cellulitis including a necrotizing fasciitis.  Patient was taken to the OR for the first time by surgery on 7/17 and had excisional debridement of left and right buttocks.  Patient had been followed by ID as well during this time.       Patient went for a second debridement on 7/20 with good results. This second surgery and ongoing diarrhea led to crs consultation for diverting colostomy.   Patient has been on pip/tazo since 7/13, and received vancomycin once on 7/13 as well. He is off zosyn upon transfer to LTAC per Dr Chamber.      Patient has been receiving his routine dialysis.  Pain management has fluctuated as, patient had altered mental status early on and initial narcotics were stopped.  Patient had been doing well on tramadol, but this also eventually was insufficient.  Oxycodone was then added with good pain control and no altered mental status.      Patient had Laparoscopic end sigmoid Colostomy on 7/24. Wound vac was applied to the complex wound.      His BP is borderline low thus some of his bp meds were held and starting gradually.     Discharged 7/30/2020 to long-term acute care facility, Select Specialty Hospital Town and Country.
ae_expected: No, it is an Unexpected AE

Participant is a 63yo white non-hispanic male  who consented to the study on 12/27/2019. Participant was randomized to switch to bupropion but discontinued it after 6 weeks of treatment due to side effects (dizziness and tremors). At his last assessment (9/1/2020) he was taking duloxetine 60mg and mirtazapine 15mg as prescribed by his PCP.
